content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a gem within the Elder Scroll series.What was good about Morrowind was brought over to this 4th installment of the series, and of course, what was bad. Was either taken out, or refined and polish for a much smoother experience.This game is huge, then what the game let's on. From quests just about almost everywhere you go. With impress lore and backstory. Not to mention the various challenges in these dark and creepy dungeons. Another great thing about Oblivion is it's class system. Unlike in Skyrim where you play as you want. Here you play based on a set of class. And therefore the game experience for you could either be hard or easy, Depending upon what class you play as. To add on the 500+ in Oblivion you got a stable (still active) modding community plus DLC quests like Knights of Nine and Shivering Isles. Which that place adds even MORE hours into Oblivion.  To add on this amazing experience is these beautiful towns and cities filled with the sam- der i mean different variety of characters each one having their own set schedule, personal opinon, and even the way they see you (through fame or infamy status) the world is very active around you within this game. There are at least two negatives about this game, that i can point out.1. NPC's are literally forgettable, this being the reason why Skyrim's NPCs are vastly superior than Oblivion's NPCs, and more flexiable than Morrowind's NPCs. The Oblivion character models are literally the same, except with a few minor face tweaks with the hair, nose, eye color and so on. Plus with the same voice acting it doesn't really help who is who in the world.2. Combat is sluggish, Yes. Even though it's a class based system. It will take a while, a long while before finding the right tune for your character to even remotely survive in the combat. Really it's just: block, lung, block, fire a spell, block. Rinse and repeat. Sometimes you are on the defensive the entire time or not even bothering going through that dungeon and just drinking buffer poitions outside the dungeon. Can you say it's because of the player level..perhaps. But even then the combat is still sub-par.If you love a cross between Morrowind and Skyrim. I highly recommend getting this game. This is the one to have in your RPG collection.

number of helpful: 42 of 43 people (98%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Fantastic game! Oblivion is one of those games that only comes from time to time, just imagine how much the developers put into this game, time, ideas , money. Thank you Bethesda! I confess it was the first game in the Elder Scrolls series I played, so I can not compare to Morrowind, and Skyrim I barely played, then I'll make a review based solely on impressions of the game.It took a while until I get to continue on a character and finish the main quest, the game requires dedication, Cyrodill world is vast , the possibilities in a TES game well, you need to explore,  learn about, otherwise you will getting lost as I did several times and so I abandoned the progress with other characters.The wealth of detail is impressive, the plot of the main quest not, but everything else makes up for this fact, the quests are very well written, some are so smart that I was surprised. The possibilities are endless too, this is a true Role Playing Game, you can make a character and be what you want from a killer thief going through a heroic warrior to a simple traveling merchant, or all together.The graphics are outdated and mechanics are strange at first sight, especially the combat and movement, and the animation of NPCs give the impression that they do not have emotions. Despite this the game is still very good, the graphics can be improved with mods, you get used to the mechanics and also the sound effects are well done. The community is huge and active, there are thousands of fan-made mods that help solve problems, improve gameplay, graphics and add content that make it practically a new game.I highly recommend it, but as said, you need to devote to it, it takes a while to get a feel and learn how the gameplay works, how the skill system and leveling for example. But there are wikis for it with everything you can know about TES: Oblivion, I recommend consulting to aid, but being careful with spoilers, of course.9/10

content:
Posted: February 25
												Oblivion makes some arguable improvements over Morrowind, as well as some massive steps backwards. Some of these mistakes would be fixed in Skyrim, while others will be ignored or worsened in some sense. As a full experience, Oblivion is a big open, sometimes annoying, technically and gameplay wise, but still mostly enjoyable overall. However, unlike Morrowind, where if you looked past the graphics now you could likely get immersed, Oblivion has numerous barriers preventing it from matching Morrowind.Compared to Skyrim, the combat feels somewhat choppier. It is faster at some points, but it manages to feel a lot more simplistic. I definitely prefer non-magic combat over Morrowind's dice roll simulation however, as combat finally feels responsive. Magic crafting also returns from Morrowind, and still feels very powerful at higher levels. However, I actually, for whatever reason, prefer magic in Morrowind to Oblivion. Learning a school of magic however, unlike Skyrim, is still worth doing regardless of playstyle due to the ability to cast regardless of whether both hands are occupied or not. Oblivion is, combat wise, the halfway point between Morrowind's more traditional style and Skyrim's faster combat, so benefits and pros of both apply here. I don't actually mind it, as like I said, magic feels superior to Skyrim, while in most other areas, combat feels more responsive than Morrowind.Location-wise and graphically, Oblivion is very green and bright. It has a better colour pallet than non-modded Skyrim, and there are definitely graphical improvements over its prequels. However, the location itself is generic. It's all greens and old elven architecture and medieval towns, rather than the alien lands of Vvardenfell's plains or Skyrim's cold mountain ranges. My main problem with Bethesda worlds has always been the very small population, and the Imperial City, although more populated than anything in Skyrim, still feels empty, and the NPC's all have very funny looking faces. Character models in Bethesda games always feel like the lack, and Oblivion is a prime example here. What feels like a let-down is that the beast races no longer have unique animations either for movement. This is more an immersion thing, and animations never affect your gameplay experience, but if you had played Morrowind before Oblivion, you'll likely notice it.The soundtrack is quiet and peaceful. The scores are always nice in Elder Scrolls games, and although I don't have anything in this game I prefer over Morrowind (which Bethesda seemed to like as they were re-using the compositions even before the Dragonborn DLC in Skyrim), the music all fits and helps build on the games atmosphere, which is all you need a soundtrack to do.The guild quests in Oblivion are some of the best in the series. Although the main quest becomes a bit of a drag, the Thieves Guild and Dark Brotherhood in particular have some of Bethesda's best quests and plotlines to them. Highlights include the Gray Fox and his final heist, and The Dark Brotherhood as a whole. There aren't any quests in Skyrim that compete with the quests here. The Fighter's Guild also has a few interesting ones and the Mages Guild suffers from the same problem that the College of Winterhold suffers from in that you can be hopeless with advanced magic and become the archmage in a few days of joining. The Arena is a massive missed opportunity, as fights never feel that big and the questline can be dusted off in about 30 minutes, which is massively disappointing. Guilds are definitely stripped back from Morrowind, due to the removal of skill barriers between the low and high ranks. Although this means that the player will be able to see everything, it means that unless you force yourself to roleplay, you can see everything on a single character. This is something even Skyrim dodged with its Civil War questline. This becomes even more self-defeating if you originally played it on the XBOX 360, and you were allowed to pick up every achievement on a single character.The Shivering Isles expansion included is brilliant. You have to play it more than once to see everything, and although a bit short, gives a far more varied world than Cyrodiil to explore, and Sheogorath and the residents of the isles have fun, over-exaggerated personalities that fit perfectly with the theme of madness and misery the expansion is going for.Overall, Oblivion has very nice ideas. The best ideas of Skyrim seemed to appear here, albeit somewhat under-developed, and although not as focused as Morrowind, it still maintained the RPG gameplay that Bethesda seems glad to phase out more and more as they release more games themselves. Worth a buy, and with mods, just like all the other popular Bethesda games, if it doesn't crash, you can go on and on, possibly even fixing your own personal problems with the game.

content:
Posted: March 11
												★★★★☆"Live Another Life in Another World".  If only every game could boast that as a key feature.  + Ragdolls+ Fitting music+ Captain Picard+ Optional difficulty+ Fast Travel & Quick Save+ Immersive and varied world+ Loot everything from everyone+ Interesting quests and locations+ Fully voiced endless NPC dialogue+ Countless ways to complete quests+ NPC and Faction relationships/alignment+ Unique and detailed spell crafting system+ Varied equipment, both visually and functionally+ NPCs.  While they can occasionally get laughable, this is probably the most alive NPCs have ever been.  They have schedules, they have conversations with eachother, they have unique appearances and stories, you can fully interact with all of them, and they react somewhat reasonably.  There isn't a single civilized NPC in this entire game that is just a copypaste non-interactive background filler, aside from maybe city guards.  + Considering this game is 10+ years old, the graphics hold up pretty well.  With a few extra settings forced on from your Nvidia control panel, it can even compete with most modern indie releases.  Aside from faces, ohgod the faces.  +- Can't kill important NPCs+- Mage is by far the best playstyle+- Levelup skill categories by using skills relevant to that category.  While this is an interesting idea, it causes some lame issues, like AFK running into a corner, or spamming spells at nothing to grind exp.  - UI is painfully clunky- Inventory weight limit- 3rd person is not viable- Graphic performance varies greatly, between 30 and 300 FPS- So many "come back tomorrow" quests, which don't even update when tomorrow is ready* Mods

number of helpful: 64 of 82 people (78%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
Pros:-Amazing open world gameplay-Beautiful graphics-Massive content-Comes on steam with all expansion content-Varying character build paths-The best thieves' guild plot arc-Oh come on, it's basically Skyrim Lite, just buy it already.Cons:-Persuasion wheel.  Ugh.-Horses are disappointing-Occasional voice acting issues-Occasional glitchesOverall: Skyrim lite.  Pre-Skyrim.  If you're here and you haven't bought this yet, but you got any amount of enjoyment out of any other Elder Scrolls game, just hit the purchase button.  The graphics are a little outdated but still beautiful.  The world is every bit as expansive as you might expect from an Elder Scrolls game, and honestly, I think I prefer a lot of the guild plots for this more than for Skyrim.Oblivion improves on so much of what was introduced in Morrowind, and when played, it's easy to see what was kept and refined for Skyrim.  The game is fun.  With a world this massive, and mechanics this complex, there are bound to be a few bugs.  And there are.  But they are remarkably far and few between for such a huge game, and the polish really shows.  My biggest gripe is when talking to an NPC, and the voice actor for the pre-assigned sound bytes changes between conversation topics.  You can't sound like an angry cowboy one moment and a hoity toity nobleman the next without ruining immersion.  This doesn't happen often either - but it sticks out enough to be memorable.Still, if you're here, you know what this is.  Just buy it.  Or wait for a sale.  But you owe yourself this experience if you ever loved playing any sort of role playing game in your life.  There's something here for everyone.Bottom Line: Obvious recommend.

content:
Posted: February 9
												I originally bought Oblivion because I couldn't afford Skyrim when it first came out, and this was on sale. I was immediately sucked into Tamriel, and I can honestly say that this game has aged immaculately. I did go on and play Skyrim for a long time, but Skyrim requires so many mods to fix lackluster questlines and glitches. Oblivion's only con is that the people's faces look like potatoes, but it's really not that big of a deal. The Oblivion quests that are available are so much more interesting; you really feel like you're there. It's so immersive and the writing is incredible. You don't have to force yourself to feel empathy for the Emperor, and this game is never too easy. I don't find myself looking for ways to make this game more immersive or interesting; I don't find myself searching for mods to fill the void left by poorly written quests and plotholes. I started playing Oblivion again because I wanted to see if I'd find it as interesting as the first time I played. I can tell you I'll be playing this again and again and again... 10/10 game. Worth every penny, and then some.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												Oblivion was one of the first games I ever got for the Xbox 360, and remains my favorite in the series-- not as poorly aged as Morrowind, not as unnecessarily trimmed as Skyrim.  It has the core of the Elder Scrolls games intact, a memorable world, graphics that still hold up decently, and the full physics of the 7th gen Gamebryo engine.I sunk hundreds of hours into the game back on Xbox.  The thing is, I never even beat the game.  The main questline was interesting, and very well-done overall, but it pales in comparison to not just the amount but the quality of the sidequests and guilds.  That's something Skyrim simply hasn't impressed me in-- the quests all feel like their own set of explorations and fights, rather than "go to x and kill y to get z."  The quests of this game all feel like something special, whether it's reading from an old journal to follow the path to a lost village, jumping into a painting to find a missing person, or helping someone fake his death to avoid paying debts.  The sheer amount of variety and quality in each of these quests will give you massive amounts of content that, unlike Skyrim, are actually fun to carry out rather than an excuse to walk around a frozen tundra for a bit longer.That in general can summarize Oblivion; there's attention to detail in pretty much everything.  Those random burned-up books in Fallout 3?  Every single one of them is a text, fully written and readable, which can be collected.  Random plants you harvest?  Craftable into poisons and potions.  House you bought for a too-good-to-be-true price?  Secretly haunted by a necromancer!  There's always something to surprise you about the game, whether it's just how much of the world you interact with or some of the downright strange things that can be found.Even the random events can completely catch you off guard.  While walking to Weynon Priory with the priest from Kvatch (early part of the main quest), I came across a regular looking cabin in the middle of the forest, with no-one around.  When I walked in, there were skeletons everywhere inside and a charred corpse on the furnace.  This has nothing to do with the rest of the game, is never explained, and completely caught me off guard.  This was 8 years after first playing the game!  There are other strange things you'll come across, but the less spoiled, the better.Speaking of strange, the Shivering Isles DLC is included with these versions of the game.  That's important, as the Shivering Isles is a massive DLC.  Originally going for $30 alone on Xbox Live, the DLC adds a massive new map and storyline where you get thrown into a world that's downright insane.  Two new sets of armor and weapons, memorable and insane characters, even more great quests, and overall just a brilliant addition to the game.  While I haven't played Knights of the Nine, and little needs to be said of the Horse Armor that you don't know already, the DLC for this game based on that alone is fantastic.Overall, what makes Oblivion special is that it holds up.  Yes, the combat can feel a bit spongy, but Skyrim has a very similar problem with its enemies.  Unlike Morrowind, the combat has a very important part: consistency.  No more RNG hit-and-missing, no more weapons divided into a thousand different types; the skills, gameplay, and controls finally make sense, especially compared to Morrowind and Daggerfall.  Even the visuals are great, though as a now decade-old game, you should expect some pop-in and lifeless faces with Bethesda's infamous awkward zoom-in angles that thankfully aren't present in Fallout 4.So yes, I do recommend Oblivion-- quite easily, in fact.  It's still to this day one of my favorite games of all time, and I don't know why I waited so long to start playing it again.  I've picked an entirely different build from my old character, and was honestly surprised at just how different of a game it feels like now.  This game has not only aged well, but compared to its other entries now stands out as an example of how to make an open-world game timeless.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2013
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is an absolutely great title and is one of, if not, the best titles in the Elder Scrolls series. Oblivion was my very first introduction to the Elder Scrolls and I enjoyed the game so very much from start to finish. The sense of immersion along with the well balanced gameplay and epic storyline was quite enjoyable for a roleplaying enthusiast like me. This title is so chock full of adventure and combat that it will keep you busy for hour upon hour which will eventually compile into weeks and months before you realize it. Graphically, you have to remember that this title was released quite a few years ago, it pales in comparison to some of todays RPG's but even so I found the basic game to be quite beautiful with a uniqueness of it own that completely fits the fantasy world and story that it places you in. I said that graphically "it pales in comparison to some of todays titles" but I think this game still looks as good if not better than alot of the current roleplaying games available...this title was ahead of it's time and the work that the developers put into it definitely shows. Of course, as with many of Bethesdas RPG's, after you finish the basic game the first time you have the ability to modify the game to your liking for many more playthroughs by way of the Oblivion Nexus. You can mod the game from the start but I as well as others agree that playing through the base untouched game the first time is a wise thing to do. This title is simply fantastic and is highly recommended!!!

												Oblivion one of my favorite games of all time.Morrowind is were it all began and Skyrim is the result of years of refinement, but Oblivion is the ambitious middle game in the modern Elder Scrolls games. Why? I first started playing Oblivion about a year ago, this was after i played Skyrim.When i first started the game it felt a little off. The controls were weird the graphics and the animations were a bit lame.After i played it for a while i actualy noticed that this world felt much more alive than Skyrim.I forgot the time and it really gave me the drive to explore the game.The Quest were just unique from one another and there wasn't a single quest i thought was boring. When i was deep in the game i forgot about the animations and realised i actualy liked the graphics from Oblivion more. They are much more alive instead of all the depressing and boring snow from Skyrim.In terms of physical appearance Skyrim is ofcourse alot better, and well it does look nice but i actualy like the positive environment from Oblivion more.Its just such an awesome and fun game even today.You just have to get into it, and when you do you will not get out.I never know what to expect in this game and it always keeps me excited.If you have the money go buy it, i am so glad i started it once when i just was bored. Its totally worth it!Oblivion- Awesome questing - 14 Guilds - Positive and nice environment- Fun Combat - Amazing SoundtrackFor an old game, it just never ceases to amaze me every single time.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Story? Great, but morrowind's was better.Gameplay? It has aged. I won't hide it. Skyrim really has better mechanics for basically everything, but this game is a lot simpler to pick up and has better quests and storylines.Atmosphere? Best out of the series. Although they couldn't afford to hire more than 8-12 voice actors.Graphics? Good for a game from 2006, but it still looks amazing on max settings. Still, graphics mods polish it.Physics? Try decorating your house. It's painful.Leveling up and build system? Complex, but dumbed down from Morrowind, for the better.Game length? Doing every quest and completing every guild + all the DLC = More than likely 200+ hours. Very rich.Better than Skyrim? Absolutely. But it has aged, and won't live up to the more modernized style of Skyrim.Has it aged well? Not quite, but you can still play it if it doesn't crash. From what I know, some cards actuall aren't compatable with the game. Mainly AMD cards, but see what cards can run this game before you buy it. It may be 20$ thrown out the window if your card isn't compatable.Most negative reviews are either about how it can't run on their computer or how people like it for nostalgia. Don't listen to those reviews. The game is well worth the 20$ if you are really into vintage games like this that are heavy with roleplay elements that aren't dumbed down.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is one of the greatest games I have ever played. Made in 2006, the game still continues to amaze me, to this very day! Back those days, this game was considered as one with the most realistic graphics (Even today, they are not bad). And it was a HUGE leap from it's predecessor, Morrowind, by all accounts. But, of course, it is not perfect. Nothing is.Well, here's my pros and cons of this game:Pros: - the main storyline - the world's size and details- character customization- the guilds and their respective quests - the spells (better than Skyrim's if you ask me)   - the ability to make your own spells (Not available in Skyrim)- the look of the cities- the soundtrack- Mods, the possibilities are endlessCons: -  the lockpicking system! - armor and weapons can break and need repairing (OK, this is probably made to add realism, but I still find it annoying)- too little amount of voice actors- fast travel made it too easy (you have access to all the cities in the beginning so that really kills the exploration feeling)- combat was a bit dullBut despite it's minor flaws I still enjoy the game. And recommend.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												Right after its release, Oblivion divided people on many patterns. I've heard friends who felt it was not a big step above Morrowind. In other words, they were disappointed with how little was changed. They wanted more of new game design decisions, and Oblivion, following all basic guidelines of the previous games, was not such a huge leap forward that someone expected. At the same time there were others, who felt lost and enraged with the amount of obscurities in compare with their beloved TES 3. "Conspiracy of simplification", some people called new trends, shown in the Oblivion. "They trading deep, thoughtful gameplay for WOW moments!"...It's been almost a decade since then. We saw Skyrim, Fallout 3 & 4, many other open-world RPG and wanna-be RPG titles. While it's a common thought that Oblivion was not a bad game, the main question is - Is it worth something now? If you haven't played it before, by what conditions would you like that game and will be motivated to actually play it? Simply put - should you buy it now?In the line of Elder Scrolls games, despite common lore, every volume is quite unique. Morrowind goes with oriental motives, religious cults and huge, comprehensive and insane magic sandbox. Skyrim is about Nords, snows, dragons and their powers, and really huge open world to explore. Really, like hundreds of hours of adventuring...TES IV has its own focus - the Central province of Empire, being overrun with hordes of demons from the lower plane called Oblivion. The problems of central governance and very dramatic main storyline, with all adventuring and other freeride activities pushed away in favor of highly orchestrated quests. The Empire in perils, the one and only Emperor dead, along with all legal heirs... The high dosage of Pathos seems unavoidable. Is it a bad thing? No. The Oblivion still much more free-play oriented than, say, Dragon Age Origins or Witcher. And those "orchestrated" quests are not giving the feeling of moving in the narrow intestines of scenario where you're more of the observer rather than actual actor. Some of those quests will be memorized as perfect examples of quest-writing and performing. You know, the gold book of RPG quests, bonfires, fanfares, all that stuff...Sure, the creators of Oblivion dropped many of the gameplay mechanics that Morrowind fans were proud of. On other hand, we've got a world much more alive and reflecting with your actions, than it was before. All those things that were simply nailed to the one place in Morrowind, including god-like beings like Vivec - in Oblivion have not only a place to be, but the duties to perform and some logic to praise or disregard the course of current events in the game plot. Although... less static doesn't necessarily means good dynamics. It is safe to say that the world of Oblivion is not that capable for providing player with adventures as Skyrim. Besides main story line and some of fraction quests (like assassins or Daedric quest lines), some of us could even find that Oblivion is somewhat dull. On the contrary, the world of Skyrim is noticeably less colourful, so there certainly will be others, who like Oblivion More than Skyrim...You know that? You should try it for yourself. Placing yourself in the sabatons of the knight-by-fortune, saving the Empire from fires of Abyss...My mark will be 7.1/10. I'd give it more, would there not been all those useless pricy dlc's like shiny "armored" skin for horses. They downgraded my overall expression out of the game, but it is still a nice piece of work, well-worth of attention from any RPG fan.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												This game...what's there to say that hasn't been said?My steam hours on this game are pitiful, but my love and years with this game PREDATE steam.Sitting at the family computer at 10 years old in 2006, scared deathless of how dark the sewers in the prologue were.And I never stopped playing. Even 5 years later when Skyrim was released, I returned to Oblivion after Skyrim satisfied me.This game was my first RPG, it's home.RIGHT, sentimentals aside, how's the game:+ It looks amazing, there's something about the graphics style that even today stands out to me, despite the vast improvements graphics have made over the years.+ The soundtrack is honestly the single most beautifully composed game soundtrack of all time. Fantasy orchestral symphonies for every mood and atmosphere and moment.+ The story is fascinating and wonderful, plunging you deep into the world of Tamriel and all its rotating elements, from the seperate guilds to the conflicting gods and deities, with smatterings of political intrigue thrown in but not so much it feels heavy.+ The voice cast is just absolutely stellar, the celebrity castings of Patrick Stewart, Sean Bean, Terence Stamp, and others, still standing out as spectacular work. They are a voice cast deserving of better facial rigging software than they were given.+ Fully customizable fantasy RPG character developments. Laid out and easily manageable and, if you desire, exploitable.I'd give a negative list, but honestly, I love the flaws in this game:+ The ragdolls are ridiculous. I love them.+ The character models are so, god, damn, ugly. I love them.+ BY AZURA BY AZURA BY AZURA. IT'S THE GRAND CHAMPION.+ Among the scariest facial rigging I've ever seen in a game. Many of the expressions wrenched out by certain lines of dialogue, haunt me.+++ The absolute best piece of DLC ever created for a game. Ever. Shivering Isles.Rating: 10/10 Still wishing Bethesda updated this instead of the far newer Skyrim. Seriously Bethesda. Wtf.

content:
Posted: March 12
												It's taken a long time for me to think of the correct words I wanted to use to describe Oblivion.I first played Oblivion on my friends Xbox 360 and was immediately hooked - I went straight to our local game store (Our town still had one in those days) and in there was a guy who was being made by his parents to sell all of his games to cover his ridiculous phone bill that he had wracked up, it was hundreds of pounds. I got his copy, a battered old case with a cigarette burn on the cover. And I loved it. It was probably the game I spent most time on, ever, on my good old 360. Now that I have evolved into one of the PC master race, it was time to do it all over again.Now, I will start here with Oblivion's flaws. For as much as I like it, it does have them and it would be unfair not to mention them. As the game world itself is huge, of course the associated bugs and glitches come with them. There are hundreds, and I suspect not all of them have been found. Some of them are quest breaking and some of them are literally game breaking, so they can be highly frustrating. On PC, this is not so much of an issue due to the all godly console commands. Combat is clunky, and especially in melee combat - you can get stuck in a hit cycle from multiple enemies and just have no way of defending yourself. The voice acting in itself is quite literally a cultural phenomenon. Yahtzee (our lord and saviour from Zero Punctuation) was 100% accurate when he described characters talking, to themselves, about the shop, owned by themselves. Its a solid attempt at a procedurally generated NPC conversations but it just falls short of the mark. The speech skill/persuasion is baffling in this game, and often I just ended up bribing people to tell me what I wanted.It hasn't aged terribly well in line with modern RPGs, but this does not matter to me so much - however, this could be an issue if graphics are your marker of a good game. The upcoming Skyblivion mod will seek to remedy this, and good luck to the development team on this - if you're ever in the UK, I'll buy you a drink. It does occasionally crash for no reason, but that could just be my particular set up.I could sit here and write pages about why I love Oblivion, so I won't. Its not just a game, its an experience. It is a lush, huge world with many different areas to wander, and has hundreds of dungeons, forts, caves, even shipwrecks to explore.  The quests and quest writing is miles above other Elder Scrolls games, the guilds in particular are fantastic - The Dark Brotherhood blows Skyrim's out of the water. I've never managed to complete all of the quests, I still find new NPCs, locations and quests to this day. It has a good chunk of DLC available - including the much derided horse armour (Seriously, give it a search - it was a bit of a mess). However, the available content also includes the legendary Shivering Isles DLC, often considered to be one of the best ever DLC packages made. It adds well over 30 hours of new content, and its not just new weapons or armour but an entire new world to explore, set in the Alice in Wonderland-esque realm of Sheogorath. That, Bethesda, is how you should be doing it. I'll stop gushing now. Seriously, if you let it drag you under - you won't come out for weeks. Cheese for everyone!

content:
Posted: February 18
												Oblivion is my favourite game and in my opinion the greatest game of all time. When i first picked up a copy of oblivion i was only interested in FPS games. After putting in the disc and hearing the theme song  i knew this was something special. I watched the beautiful intro spanning over the imperial city in awe. I dived head on into the character creation and spent a good half an hour tampering with these (at the time) weird and facinating races. I chose a nord and proceeded through the tutorial, talking to Patrick Stewart's Uriel Septim and feeling some importance. My first battle was with the rats at the crumbling door that took me by surprise but i still won. I proceeded through the dungeon slaying beasts and looting as i went. I saw the death of Uriel which still tugs on my heart strings to this day.i remember leaving the sewer for the first time and just being in awe, the beauty of cyrodiil is unmatched to this day. The size of the cities dumbfounded me. There are critisims for them being too generic however I love the way they look it feels medival yet fantasy. I remember seeing the imperial city and being taken a back. i plowed through the oblivion gates which are a stellar contrast to the soft features of cyrodiil.after completion of the campaign i felt lost, i didnt know what to do, (the ending is very sad). Luckily the side quests had enough ti keep me entertained for hours on end, as with the lore. With over 1000 hours of gameplay compared to my 800 in morrowind and 200 on skyrim it is safe to say this is my prefferd elder scrolls.sometimes i like to turn it on and just walk through the forest with the enchanting sound track and just reminice. i beyond reccomend this game

												I hope I dont get hate for this, but i think this game is better then skyrim. Posted: April 9, 2016
												Oblivion may not be as advanced as Skyrim, but in my opinion it's still much better. When you join a guild or faction in Oblivion, you slowly work your way up to the top. When you join a guild in Skyrim, you are super important right from the start. For example, The Dark Brotherhood in Skyrim has you as the listener right after the first couple of grunt quests. In Oblivion, you don't become the listener until the very end, after you've poured your heart and soul into completing every quest. This is just one example, all of Skyrim's guilds are like this. Oblivion makes you work for your success, its storyline is better, and the overall feel of it is much more memorable. Skyrim is a good game, Oblivion is a FANTASTIC game, 10/10 would erase my memory and play Oblivion all over again. So before you buy any other game, STOP RIGHT THERE CRIMINAL SCUM, get Oblivion GOTY Edition.

Posted: November 15, 2015
												It says I only have 3.5 hours on this (as of written review), but that's through launching it with steam, I've sunk at least one thousand on my old 360 back in 06-07.I know more people are familiar with skyrim, so if you've played skyrim and want to check out oblivion, here are some things you need to know.-Lock picking system is very different and can be much more challenging at the higher ranked locks.-All the npc's kinda look fat and ugly. (you'll have to get used to it)-The terrain is a lot more lush with green forests, not like skyrims winter tundra.-Every NPC ♥♥♥♥ing hates your guts and doesn't suck your♥♥♥♥♥♥ You're no dragonborn here, your practically a nobody until the near end of the game.-No duel weild magic and swords.-Dark Brotherhood, at least I think, is a lot more fleshed out with better quests.-Modding community is not as alive as skyrim (but it's there) and oblivion doesn't have the steam workshop supporting it. You'll have to use nexus if you want to mod, although the vanilla game is tolerable.-Voice acting I thought was a lot nicer, I can only hear that one male nord voice for so long.There are plenty of other differences but to me both games are just as good even with their differences.9/10

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												What is there to say about Oblivion, aside from it possibly being the last great RPG that Bethseda has made, or possibly ever get around to making. It comes from a time when Bethseda was changing markets, from PC based RPG's, to more casual easy to pick up games. It also came at a time when games were first marked with the treachery known as DLC. It would be a lie to say that Oblivion does not suffer from this casualization to some degree, the forefront simply being that system requirements for consoles forced the devs to reduce content in a lot of areas. namely spells such as levitation or jump from Morrowind as players would be able to fly over city walls that simply had to be closed off. It also brought along click and go fast travel. Morrowind was all about exploration, getting lost and killed was all part of the game. This lost feeling never really happened with Oblivion. However, along the lines, Bethseda never really was sure about everything. they still had proper enchanting and spellmaking, they still had very good quests and something that Skyrim was never given. Character building. Simply being able to set up your character made the game feel whole. Bethseda's has always been bad with supergod main characters over agent of change characters for RPG's... but in the sense of the universe, it makes sense, for who the character is. Skyrim didn't give you the opportunity to set up your character. You could be anything. Oblivion, you could be anything as well, but at least you still had skills you were mastered in, attribute's about your person you can change. Morrowind, you better make damn sure to use the skills you started with until you had the gold to start training in them. before that, well, you better select some Magic skills if you wanna even talk to someone from the Mage's guild. And the quests. If I said gravekeeper would you know who I was talking about? what about this 50 gold for a set of nice silverware. mother? Ayleid statues?Cheese, Yarn and lettuce? if you don't, well, you should. if you haven't played it, you would instantly know why you remember these once you do. because, unlike future games. questing involved questing. not going into a dungeon dodging skinwalking jerky geezers who occasinally yell at you so hard you roflcopter the floor whilst saving the day from bad dragon. or another settlement needs our help.

number of helpful: 18 of 19 people (95%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												I have been wanting to review this for a while on Steam. When I first picked this game up in 2007 for the Xbox 360, I fell in love with The Elder Scrolls at a level Morrowind could never install upon me.62 hours played? That's on the Steam version. I have well over 1500 hours invested in this game. And there is STILL a bit more ccontent I haven't covered.  Mostly small things, like fetch quests and in 100% honesty I have never gotten around to finishing the Knights of the Nine DLC.Visually, the game hasn't aged very well. Combat wise, the game is rather simplistic. Let's talk about those.Now I usually don't take visuals too seriously, but keep in mind a game of this scope back in 2006 didn't have high requirements for visuals. A lot of people complain that the faces of most of the human races look really odd with questionable colouring, and that Orcs just look like green humans with different lips and teeth. Completely true. However, that doesn't really do much to your immersion, in the long run. The enviroments are huge, the number of running proceses overturns the 300 mark, and in 2006 you couldn''t have good graphics, a huge world AND good performance all at the same times as loading areas smoothly and quickly with no FPS drops. For what it has to work with, the visuals at the time were very good. Well done, lads.Segmenting towards gameplay, let's talk about the combat. If you have played Morrowind, it will feel dumbed down, if you have played Skyrim it will feel rigid and overly fast-paced. The combat AI is pretty bad. I'll give you a rundown of every enemy's AI:Melee Weapon equipped, no Shield.:If the enemy is visible, attack it. Between every 3-5 basic attacks, use one of 3 power attacks. If low on fatigue or have just used a power attack, block for a few seconds. Successful block means it's time to basic attack 2-4 times. Restart cycle. Never block if you are a monster like a zombie, troll or bear, but do block if you are a Ogre, Spider Daedra or Mountain Lion.Melee Weapon and Shield: If the enemy is visable, charge in. Do same formula as with no shield equipped, but block before each cycle and power attack if the opponant attacked you while blocking.Ranged Weapon:Fire when visable. Step aside between each shot. If enemy is close, switch to melee weapon if one is in inventory. Magic User:If it breathes, cast a spell at it. If it is close, use a touch spell. Use melee weapon when they are close, then back up after 1 cycle. Yeah, not the smartest combat AI ever. If they have a low movement speed, you can literally just kite them with a longsword, spell or bow, and they will never once change tactics. Bad AI is bad. But when not in combat, they are generally interesting. They react to your crimes, reporting them to he guards or shrugging it off depending on how much they like you and what factions you belong to, and each and every civilized NPC has a full in-game month's worth of routines - shopping, sleeping, talking, running around on a horse until they get killed by highwaymen... very detailed stuff. The rest of the gameplay is what makes up for the poor combat. Oblivion was designed as a story and world-centric RPG, rather than a combat-based one. You can spend 200 hours just shopping and decorating your house alone. Did I say "house"? I meant "houses". There's 8 of them, without DLC. I personally wish the Shivering Isles Expansion - the biggest expansion for the game - had a house you can buy within the Shivering Isles. It's a new map to explore, with crazy good quest lines, and possibly the best Daedric Prince of them all, Sheogorath, Prince of Madness. Let me give you some of his Scottish-voiced lines:"I once dug a pit and filled it with clouds....or was it clowns.... it doesn't matter, it didn't slow him down. But it really began to smell! Must have been clowns. Clouds don't smell, they taste of butter. And tears.""I'm a little busy here! I'm trying to decide what to have for dinner. Oh, how I love to eat. One of my favorite things to do. Go talk to Haskill, he's got more brains than a brain pie! Ooh...brain pie... perfect! ...Care to donate?""Wonderful! Time for a celebration... Cheese for everyone! Wait, scratch that. Cheese for no one. That can be just as much of a celebration, if you don't like cheese, true? You've run a maze like a good little rat. But no cheese for you yet. Well, maybe a little."Sheogorath is a riot. He'll keep you coming back trial after trial, just to hear some of his amazing rants. He's easily my favourite Elder Scrolls character.You cannot trade between shops to earn income like in Fable, which is unfortunate, but also stops getting the best items early from being too easy. However, with a lot of trading done, you can buy and sell for the exact same price, making late-game adventuriing fill you up with so much cash that you won't have anything to do with it all... except buy more houses and fill them with the rarer spoils of your journeys.The map, like I mentioned, is HUGE. the outter map is almost the same exact size as Skyrim, however there are much, much more dungeons and caves to explore. The map is litered with them, all of  them unique in one way or another. I just there were more old forts and ruins with bandits and marauders instead of monsters, vampires and spectral-kind. Finding the correct armour peices can take quite a long time. Needless to say, at the very least this gives you more incetive to explore. Once you finish a dungeon, don't forget about it entirely. Give it a few in-game weeks and the place will be full of new inhabitants, ready to be cleared out of your favourite treasure trove once more. Class specifications can be a bit... pointless. 90% of the time, unless you are hardcore into RPing, the best class is a Thief-Battlemage-Assassin-Warrior-Illusionist-Bard-Healer. Yeah... lategame you just kind of stop specializing because there is a poor integration for choosing your specific, well-thought custom class. You eventually will just start specializing in everything, rather than being solely a mage or a theif. Because  the game is so unstructured, the only way to get your perfect fantasy is to handicap yourself with strict RP rules.Speaking of RP, this game is a goldmine of oppurtunities. I have been streaming my RP playthrough of a theif who uses non-combat magic to get away with his endeavors. Using Invisbility spells to pass by unnoticed, life-detection to know where the enemies are behind walls, and should I run into a pickle, I can dice them up and place them on a hamburger with my dagger fit for Chef Ramsey. (I don't know how Chef would respond to a Argonian Meat Burger, but I'd imagine it would be something like "THIS LIZARD IS SO UNDERCOOKED A SKILLED VETERINARIAN COULD STILL SAVE HIM!") You can live a life as a dashing warrior, a powerful wizard, a simple townsfolk who is secretly the guy murdering all of the beggars and sucking their blood from the neck... you name it, you cann RP it. Except Werewolf. Sorry, Twilight fans, no re-enacting New Moon for you. Oh, and tons of small bugs. Double-equip a scroll that you have multiple of and drop an item. Bam, unlimited gold if you sell them, and duplicates of your favourite decorations. A few rare, but still present, glitches that make quests uncompletable. The game is massive, the game is immersive, the game is unbalanced. The game is exciting, the game is relaxing. My wife's legs really need waxing. I do like this game, Sam I Am.A solid 9/10 Final Verdict. The game hasn't been aging well, so play it while it's still a technical marvel. Not out-of-date yet, but then, what or who truely marks a game as timeless?

Posted: January 10, 2016
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients: 1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs3 tablespoons sugar3 tablespoons melted butter40 ounces softened cream cheese1 cup sugar3 tablespoons flour1 tablespoon vanilla1 cup sour cream4 eggsDirections:For The base:.If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.For the batter:.Make sure everything is at room temperature.Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.Release the sides of the springform.Eat.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												First off, I own Oblivion as a non-Steam game and I've spent well over 75 hours playing it.Secondly, this is probably my favorite game ever made. It's definitely on my top five games ever. Oblivion was my first Elder Scrolls game, so the outdated graphics and gameplay didn't bother me even though I got it in 2014. The combat is basically like slicing butter, but it's fun. I love how vibrant and human the "potato-head" NPCs are, and how colorful Cyrodiil and the Shivering Isles are. The soundtrack is the best ever for any game. I actually bothered to purchase it on iTunes.Oblivion is a game I'd want to live in.Buy it. Buy it now. Even the horse armor.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												After playing Oblivion, I can see why many people love this game. It has many features missing from Skyrim, such as equipement decay and spell making (that's awesome). One thing I don't like about it, is the combat, it's very slow, and well I like faster combat. The quests are very nice and creative, such as the one where you go inside a painting. The guild quests are very nice. The Fighter's Guild was very boring in my opinion (The Companions had a better questline), the Mage's Guild was okay (The College of Winterhold is sort of similar), the Thieve's Guild actually made me feel like a thief, the Dark Brotherhood was also nice with lots of twists and murders. Then you have two great DLCs, one with a short but good story with good rewards and the big one that gives you a new land, weapons, spells and laughs. Buy this game, don't let its age fool you (there's plenty of mods to change your mind).

Posted: June 18, 2016
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

number of helpful: 15 of 16 people (94%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10
												(This review is going to be astronomically long, so bear with me! TL:DR; is at the end.)I remember the first time I played Oblivion. It was at a friend's house when I was seven, back in 2007. I didn't understand it much, but I got to watch him play it on his old television and I got a small turn for a while. Eventually, I got my first Playstation 3 in 2009. Oblivion was one of the first games I ever bought for the system.Between the endless interesting quests, to the big open world that was the best for it's time, it was one of the best experiences in video gaming that I have ever experienced.Now it's 2017, and I have just started playing Oblivion again.I have two hundred or so hours on the retail version, and roughly 30 hours on the Steam version. Time and time again I find myself returning to Oblivion just to play through the Dark Brotherhood questline or to just explore all the dungeons and forts that the game had to offer.I would even daresay that this game beats Skyrim. Skyrim's graphics are certainly much better, but to me, the game dumbed down on a lot of the elements that made Oblivion great, including a mediocre story, poorly made (and much less) side-quests and a broken vanilla follower system.But enough about Skyrim, this is about Oblivion. I'm going to list all of the positives, negatives and other features that are a little in-between.POSITIVES+ Excellent main story.+ A plethora of side-quests that are even better then some of the main quests.+ The Thieves Guild and the Dark Brotherhood's questlines are excellent.+ Good controls.+ The Shivering Isles and Knights of the Nine are EXCELLENT DLCs and NEED to be purchased with this game.+ An all-star acting cast who do a very great job at their roles.+ Very well detailed dungeons, forts and caves.+ Many different cities with dozens of quests, along with many interesting characters.+ A lot of well-written books inside the game.+ Many different weapons to choose from.+ Customise your own class and what skills level up your character.+ A lot of spells to choose from, including many other ones that can be bought.+ The Mage Guild and the Fighters Guild. Their questlines were pretty good, however, they didn't return in their same form in Skyrim. The Companions in Skyrim represented the Fighter's Guild and the College of Winterhold represented the Mage Guild.+ An amazing soundtrack. From the quiet songs while you're trading with a merchant in the Imperial City, to the heart-wrenching song playing when you enter an Oblivion gate, this soundtrack is quite possibly the best in the Elder Scrolls series.+ Weapon degradation. You can use repair hammers to repair your weapons, where in Skyrim, you couldn't do that.+ Alchemy. I enjoyed the alchemy in this game a lot, especially when I needed to upgrade my Alchemy tools whenever I levelled higher!+ The voice acting is on-par with 2017 video games to date. With the famous 'Lucien Lachance' scene being one of the best scenes in the entire game, just because of how the actor portayed Lucien in that very scene.+ The visuals are pretty damn good. Skyrim's visuals were excellent, but felt very drab. Oblivion's visuals were perfect for how many players envisioned Cyrodil. From the beautiful green trees, to the snow near the Blade's temple at Bruma, the scenary and visuals are excellent.+ The end of the main quest. The end is very well done, and it's short and simple. Much better than Skyrim's in my opinion.+ The Arena. It may be repetitive sometimes, but for me, this was one of the best questlines in the entire game (taking a back-seat to the Dark Brotherhood). From the Gray Prince realising his true identity, to the many battles you will have to win to become the 'Grand Champion', this is another reason why Oblivion is so good.+ Random encounters. They may be less of them than Skyrim, but coming across a Highwayman when crossing a bridge near the Imperial City, or M'aiq the Liar outside of Leyawiin, I just found more enjoyment in those encounters.+ The Ayleid Ruins. Skyrim tried to replicate the Ayleid Ruins with the Dwemer Ruins. To me, I found them a lot less interesting than the Ayleid Ruins in Oblivion. The beautiful arcitecture and design, (along with the value of all the Welkyd stones that you could collect) made them a lot more fun to explore, then Skyrim's substitute.I think that covers all of the positives. Now, onto the features that are a little positive, and a little negative.AVERAGE~ All of the guards have the same voice actor, so good luck trying to find a certain guard if it involves a quest.~ The game stutters infrequently (at least for me) and it breaks immersion.~ The AI isn't very good, especially the Bandit and Mage AI, where they will just run right into my blade instead of being tactical or running away.~ Glarthir. That entire quest is absolute garbage. The only thing that's good about it, is being able (you can choose not to) kill him and take the reward.~ Merchants seem to have infinite gold. It makes no sense that if a Merchant has 800 gold, you can sell 795 gold worth of potions to them, and be able to sell them more as long as you keep the amount to under 800. The gold never depletes!~ Lucien LaChance's ending. I don't want to talk about that.~ I'm not going to say that the Zombies are hyper-realistic, but they are too scary for me.Now...onto the negatives.NEGATIVES- The UI. It is clearly designed with the Console in mind, and it can be extremely frustrating and sometimes un-usable due to it's awful inventory interface and merchant inventory interface. The only way to really use it, is if you download a UI mod for the game from the Nexus.- Levelling up. Being able to level up your stats while you're sleeping? Overall, the levelling up system is good, but I just found it really curious as to why we need to sleep to level up.- The Lockpicking. It is a good minigame, but the problem with it is, you can just Quicksave in front of a locked door, then reload whenever you are caught or break a lockpick.- The intense lag. The game can range from 30 to 200 FPS (only up to 90 in my case, and that's with a GTX 970). For a game that is over ten years old, intense lag in some places (such as Bravil or the Arena) is unnacceptable. Download mods to fix this and greatly reduce your lag.- The Adoring Fan. You know what I'm talking about if you've finished the Arena questline.- Invisible walls. Like in Skyrim, Oblivion has a LOT of invisible walls. Couldn't big mountains have been put in place to force the player to stop and not be able to hit an invisible wall? The only positive to this, is that when mods open up new lands to explore (Elsweyr Arquenia, etc), all you need to do is disable the invisible walls.- The fame and infamy system. Fame isn't such a problem to me, as it makes a lot of sense, but infamy seriously annoys me. I want to be able to complete the Dark Brotherhood and Thieves Guild questline, but I can't because each mission or murder grants you infamy (even when nobody sees you doing these crimes) and eventually, guards will attack on sight if your infamy is high enough.That's all I could think of.Oh, also, a massive positive.MODS. Enough said.TL:DR; Oblivion is an amazing game and is the best Elder Scrolls in the franchise and it is definitely worth picking up (ASWELL AS THE DLCs) and should not be missed at any cost. It overcomes it's shortcomings with an amazing story, world and cast of characters, that are unforgettable.GET. THIS. GAME.

												This is probably the best Elder Scrolls game ever. It has very nice looking graphics and all...The main storyline is awesome.There are several factions like The Dark Brotherhood, Thieves Guild, Mages guild and The Fighters Guild that you can join.Also there is a lot of side guests to do.There is an arena you go and fight on or then you can go and wager on it.There is a lot looting to do and caves to rob...You can also make your own potions, enchant items and make your own spells!You can buy and decorate houses as you like or then you can just break into someone else's house and pretend it's yours...You can get robbed too.You can kill people stealthly with poison apples...Or then you could just go hunting or just talk to everyone...And if you have Game of the Year Edition Deluxe you will have many awesome DLC's too.The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion: 10/10 Best game of 2006 and one of the best games of all time.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												An epic, truly epic. Of all proportion  The game will draw you in and take you into its self, it is so immersive and in my opinion the greatest of all role playing games. The feel is so geniune, so original and so magical.. it's like watching a medieval fantasty film from perhaps the seventies.. if you can imagine that and have a splendid feeling, then you must be interested.  There is no comparison to this. Absolutley not. It is far too spectacular in its glory for that. Now you must understand that this game brought me into the world of role playing games, my favored genre, for their humming realism and grand feats of imaginative speldour, I got the game of the year edition, and that disk span in my xbox for well over well, my save game had 657 or so days there. I would say around three thousand hours I have played Oblivion.  Now one who has the skill to tell a detailed tale of their adventures in life may do so wonderfully. I belive it would take me much more practice to do enough justice that would suit my liking to this game. I will only ramble on at things that come into my mind.  So for the overall aestheics... oh man. words really cannot do justice on this. It is something very very special. Now this does give me nostalgia and so I am being biasedly complementary here, I remember the smells of snack food like oranges and the smell of meat and pasta, or any other combination.. and dust.. dust gives me much nostaligia of earlier days. This goes well with the theme, a quite colourful and dainty civilisation, obvious fantasy articles and easy lovely heads up display : ). Please man, if you like, check out a video of some menial gameplay from someone else, to get a feel of what this is like  I shall get into some gameplay descritions now, (which I must say are not entirely top notch) as I say, you must be imaginitive! That is the magic touch, for me at least.. well they go so well if you add your own self to it :), so they work simply, and add no mess, like they are working real time and are a glance at the world, moving you ever further.  Now I hope I do not have to tell you what you can do! As with many other games of its kind, you can... go foraging in the forest for example, find fruits & berry leaves for example, and go to a station of which you can work to boil up potions... you can do the vast array as normal, with no taints, no faults.  I am telling you, this is a super extrodinary game. A pioneer! I suggest that you must own this game, you know there is a balance of, mountains and snow, swamp and rivers, grassy hills with nearby caves, farmland and noble cities.. creatues galore, none out of place or without a story intertwined. The serenity.  Oh my I could call this perfect. I do love it. Well that is all I shall say, for if you do not know of The Elder Scrolls then, I say get to.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Mini-Review for Oblivion, requested by an user.The question I've received: With skyrim having a great modding community, is there any reason to still pick up Oblivion?Well, Yes. But allow me to explain.Skyrim has the better graphics, better soundtrack, better combat, better ai, yada yada. All the stuff expected from having a better engine.While vanilla oblivion in itself can offer you a lot:A main quest that's of a grander scale as the one in Skyrim.Far, far more side quests.A plethora of explorable areas.Actually more in-depth factions, reputations and guilds.Better item distribution and item quality dispersion(when do you get this/that type).Enfin, the real question is: All that vanilla stuff is great, but it can be modded into skyrim as well!Well... Oblivion's mod-database is still far greater than the one skyrim has to offer as of now.Graphics and Music can be easily improved, especially in the realm of character textures.I'd personally also recommend many of the city overhauls and terrain improvements.However, the real treats are in the more complex mods. Oblivion has had a far larger amount of time to develop it's mod pool and thus has far more complex mods for whatever tickles your fancies.In short: If you're in love with modding your Bethesda games, Oblivion is certainly worth picking up and is easily moddable to your heart's content. Even if you're not into modding the game itself holds its own unique charm and well worth experiencing, especially if it happens to go on sale!So, hereby answering the request: Oblivion is a must have if you're fan of the TES series, well worth considering if you love modding games, worth a try if you started at skyrim and wondered what events lead to it, and if you're new to Bethesda's TES series a fair point to start.~Rose

number of helpful: 12 of 12 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												First off, I have over 300 hours in this game on Xbox so don't be fooled by my low playtime on steam. Secondly the fact that I have over 300 hours should tell you that this game is worth playing, if it isn't enough I break down what makes this such a great game and where its strengths and weaknesses are in this review.      Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is an open world role playing game that emphasizes on player freedom, exploration and creativity.  You play a prisoner of the imperial army who meets the emperor while he is trying to covertly get out of the city when a cult of assassins are killing members of the royal family to wipe out their bloodline. During the games tutorial you get recruited abruptly to help guard the emperor during this escape. Here you will get some insight on how to play the game and how the character progression system works as well as a taste of the lore of the elder scrolls universe. Once this brief but effective tutorial sequence is over you emerge a free man/woman free to do WHATEVER you want.  You can take part of all number of activities and explore the vast province of Cyrodil; you can sink hundreds of hours into this massive very in depth game.      The things you can do are extensive in Oblivion. There is the main story which is engrossing and varied though a little on the shorter side. There are four guilds you can join complete with their own quest lines which are all fantastic and very interesting with cool characters and feel distinctly different from each other. There is the "Fighters Guild" the "Mages Guild" the "Thieves Guild" and the "Dark Brotherhood". There is also the arena where you engage in gladiator style fights with some of Cyrodil's greatest fighters and most viscous beasts. You can also visit shrines of the various gods in the game and do quests for them, these are some of the best in the game and all are unique and yield cool rewards. There is also a plethora of quest's to do for the citizens of Cyrodil which are amazingly mostly unique and quite fun. There are countless caves, castles, and other locations to find and explore. There are houses through out the game you can buy and decorate ranging from shacks by the water the exquisite manors. Of course you can also spend hours on hours training your character and interacting with all the npc's in the game. The amount of content in this game feels endless and can be binge played all day, day after day with always more content seeming to pop up all over the place.      Oblivion takes place in Cyrodil as I mentioned earlier in the review, the central province in the continent of Tamriel. Cyrodil is the seat of imperial power where the Septim bloodline has reigned as emperor for generations. The Septim bloodline has a power, related to the gods themselves and they now face being wiped out by a sinister cult whose motivations are dark and mysterious. The Elder Scrolls series is rich with lore, Bethesda invented gods both "good" and "evil" with personalities and beliefs all unique from each other. The relationships the gods have with mortals are very interesting. You can spend hours reading the various books in the game learning about Tamriels history and learn more about the various groups and their own history, it's insanely extensive.      The gameplay is an interesting but mixed bag. The graphics look dated, the animations are clunky and the voice cast is extremely small for a world with so many people in it but it's pretty easy to overlook with all the goes right in the game. For combat you can use melee weapons ranging from swords to maces to axes as well as ranged weapons like bows. Magic is also very prominent in combat as well as for utility in the game. Combat is kind of stiff at times but it works fine and is easy to get the hang of. The leveling system is one of the elder scrolls’ biggest strengths and weaknesses simultaneously. You level your character by leveling your skills, these skills vary from "Blade Weapons" too "Lock picking". Leveling you skills increases your overall level, so if you spending all your time leveling utility skills like "Alchemy" and "Athletics" but without leveling your combat skills like "Destruction" magic or "Archery" your character will be poor in combat which will make getting things done difficult. It’s also important to think clearly about what kind of character you want to make, this will determine what skills you should focus on leveling in the early game, once these skills are at an adequate level you can then branch out into other skills that are catch your interest. Leveling up other skills will allow making your character more malleable in different situations. Remember, solving all your problems by swinging an axe into people's heads isn't the best way to handle all situations. Also all the music in the game is fantastic.     In the end, when you take all the good and the bad together you have an imperfect but very awesome RPG. You can lose all your spare time for a long time with this game, and you will love every minute of it. The two DLC's that the game of the year edition comes with, "Knights of the Nine" and especially "The Shivering Isle's" are fantastic extra content, the latter is one of the best DLC's I have ever played. It's like a whole game in itself almost. This is a fantastic experience and I would recommend it to anybody. 9/10

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Here I am, in 2016. This game is 10 years old. (Roughly half my age.)This was the first real RPG I had ever played.At first, I thought this game was horrible, mechanics were too complex, animations were too stiff, and the zoom-in-on-your-face dialogue was a real suprise.But after continuing to play, I fell in love. Every faction, every city, every dungeon, and like 70-80% of the characters are beautifully made. Character progression is flawless, you can actually see and feel yourself get more powerful throughout your playthrough. NPCs will have conversations with eachother,(that may or may not be centered around the main character.) I know of at least one NPC who even will actively try to steal things from other NPCs. And the stories packed into this game are just great. Bethesda manages to inject even the most simple bear pelt-gathering quest with life and personality. And if that isn't enough, this game has two add-ons that could easily be full games on their own, equal in depth, and life.

Posted: December 4, 2013
												I loved this game on the 360, and I love it even more on the PC. With ~30,000 mods and plenty of Official DLC's, this game has massive replay value, and can be a brand new experience every time you play. If you've never played it, loved Skyrim, but disliked Morrowind, Oblivion is a great in-between-er, and well worth your time and money.The main quest, as with all Elder Scrolls titles, isn't the main focus of gameplay here, and is fairly short in comparison to the whole of the game. But even without the Official DLC's, and all the mod possibilities, the "vanilla" game itself can give you hundreds of hours of game time. With a plethora of quests, choices, and almost unlimited possibilities, I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: January 10
												The Elder Scrolls: Oblivion is an open world adventure experience that (for its time) opened up to a world of incredible proportions. Get over the dated graphics and awkward dialogue and you'll be immersed in this wonderful RPG that allows you to wander with no strings attached. The game rewards your curiosity and desire to see what is over the hill and what that village you see on the compass contains. Quests of differing demands are around every corner, everything from guilds, demonic gods, counts, common folk and lowly beggars are awaiting your appearance as their everyday hero. And it comes with one of my personal all time favourite soundtracks.The game's biggest flaw lies in its level progression, like any RPG you level up with the skills you use often but the main problem arrives as the further your strength grows, the stronger the enemies of the world gets (i.e. bandits will run around with rare armour and weapons that you went through hell to acquire yourself). The combat itself is unsatisfying with magic being boring to throw and most melee combat to be block'n'slash (I heard there are mods to fix that). But once you get used to it you see a magical world with lots of adventure and people in distress to save.9/10 - "Hey, you're the one they call the hero of Kvatch!" Get used to that phrase, it's less impressive than it sounds.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
The life and times of a boy lost in CyrodiilSo one day I was casually cliff jumping my way up the Jeral mountains, and I stumbled upon two Imperial Hunters having a casual archety competition. In an attempt to join in, the two of them started attacking eachother in a duel to the death. The next day, the Grey Fox decided to give me his hood for the rest of eternity. Giddy like a child opening their best Christmas gift, I put it on in the middle of town to let the whole world know that I look like the most wanted criminal in the world. 6 guards rushed up to me and said I was under arrest "for everything". Baffled and in the rush of the moment, I killed 5 of them. I then thought to myself, "♥♥♥♥♥♥it's probably the hood". So I took off the hood, and the remaining guard looked at me as if I was his best friend. We had a nice little chat about the Emperor's death, and we went about our business like nothing happened.I once stumbled upon a cave with a goblin's head on a spike at the entrance. I thought to myself, "I bet there must be some really nice people in here just trying to ward off enemies with that pike outside, maybe I should go inside". So I went invisible, just in case I was somewhere I shouldn't be. It happened to be a nest of vampires, so, as one does, I casually went up to one of them to make conversation. He immediately drew his sword, indicating that he wished to engage in combat with me. I killed him, and went invisible as to avoid any of the others bothering me. I then observed his colleague pass his body. He checked to see that his friend wasn't just sleeping. Realising that he was in fact void of any life, he blurted out "huh, must have been the wind".10/10 perfect AI, would change absolutely nothing about this game. Best game I have ever played. The story is fantastic, the side quests are genuinely fun and enjoyable, and the DLC adds more to the game that 10 modern DLC packs would to any modern game. This game has aged well, and with mods, can be maintained to modern 'standards' in graphics. I wish games like this were made today, and I cannot wait for Skyblivion (Oblivion remade in the engine that Skyrim uses).This game sacrafices a good combat system and sometimes poor environment for a truly perfect questing experience, and an incredibly diverse magic system. There is too many good points to explain in a review, so just buy the f$%&ing game. I played over 2000 hours on the PS3 version, and recently bought it in a Steam sale. Even after all that time spent, this game is still a joy to play and explore. You decide how you want to play it, and how you are percieved by everyone in the world. This is, and will always be, my favourite game of all time.

												Oblivion, the prequal to Skyrim and the sequal to Morrowind, released 20th of March 2006 was the fourth installment of The Elder Scrolls franchise.There are things i think that Oblivion did better than skyrim;1. The class system was better, you chose your star sign right at the start NOT JUST THE THIEF, MAGE AND WARRIOR, all of them, your attributes and class was chosen right at the beginning of the game as well as the star signs.2. content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Once the dust had settled I tried Oblivion for the first time in close to a decade, and I found a game I really didn't hate anymore.Oblivion strikes the balance between depth (Morrowind) and playability (Skyrim). It features very well designed quests and far more improved combat. With a world that is full of color, and a wide assortment of locations. From snowy plateaus to sandy beaches filled with twitchy Argonians.At the same time the game is still flawed. It's a game that hasn't aged very well graphically, and the RPG elements are very hamfisted and lacking. There are thankfully mods that fix all of this, and I don't recommend playing this game vanilla. If you do, all you'll find is a game filled with potato people. One where you are legitimately stronger at the beginning of the game due to how badly coded the levelling system is.
