content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												TL;DRBuy Oblivion right now.---------------------------------------10/10 would spam jump to win again.Play this game. I have in total about 700 hours of Skyrim (mostly not through steam). I bought Oblivion GotY edition while it was on sale a few months ago, but I never really played it. I just started to play it, and let me tell you, it's good. The lockpicking, magic, speechcraft, combat, side quests, humor, etc. etc. are all much more enjoyadble and overall better than Skyrim. It has so many cool and interesting features that make it super immersive, super RP-friendly, and really fun. Dialogue with actually funny jokes and combat that isn't "click to win" like some *cough* games are really appeals to me. Seriously, I'm surprised that it's this good. Everyone always told me it was super hard and that I shoouldn't get it, but I'm glad I did. Time to buy Morrowind.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												Personally, I would say Oblivion is one of my favorite games I've ever played. Sure, it might be a little old and it might not look as good as Skyrim, but honestly the game makes up for it in content. Plus if it bothers you that much, there are some good mods out there to fix that. I would say that no game I have ever played has ever given me quite the same experience. I don't want to spoil anything but I've owned the game on Xbox and loved it enough to buy it again.Oblivion has a huge world to explore full of ruins, dungeons, towns and castles. The main questline is amazing but to be honest, I loved the DLCs and guilds more than anything. Oblivion is a very detailed world that you can really get into. I've spent hours just doing side quests and admiring Cyrodiil.I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone who likes open world games. If you can get this on sale it's even better. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												While I don't like the way Bethesda is making their games easier and dumbing down their content, this game is still enjoyable.  I'd rather they didn't remove so many skill lines, or remove negative consequences. You can do it all in this game, you aren't forced to choose right vs wrong, nor is there any real depth to the characters. You can kill anyone you want without consequences. The point of a Role Playing game is your actions should result in game changing events, there is way too much hand-holding going on. This is more like an FPS in a Elder Scrolls setting.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This is by far my favorite Elder Scrolls game. I owned the hard copy previously and when I saw it on Steam I knew I had to get it. The environment in this Elder Scrolls is the best out of all the games. Tamriel has a peaceful air to it filled with vibrant color and good amounts of green. The story is easy to follow and maintains interest. All of the side quests and other distractions give this game 1000's of hours of gameplay potential.The only complaint I have about this game is the leveling system. The level of enemies is based on your level so if you focus too much on levelling non-combat skills, the enemies become very tough to kill. This is more then made up for by the rest of the game though, so I'd still give a 10/10. Shadow guide you.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												The game that defined the modern RPG and arguably the best game ever written. In the two years since escaping from the Imperial prison I have become a holy crusader, a gladiator in the arena, fallen from grace, spent an uncomfortable two weeks as a vampire, defeated at least one ancient evil, driven ghosts out of my home and been made into a god. Also, there's some problem in Kvatch, which people keep on referring to as the 'main quest'.Massive, I'm nearly 200 hours in and there are parts of the main game and bits of DLC I haven't even started to look at. With the 'unofficial' patches from the community this game has had most of it's bugs fixed and runs well on modern PCs. Other community mods make it an incredibly pretty game, fix gameplay issues and add oodles more content.Look at http://www.nexusmods.com/oblivion for mods and patches.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												This is the epitomy of the fantasy genre. It has perfect mechanics for getting into RPGs without being too streamlined or confusing. The environment is perfectly put together and will keep you invested for months at a time. The levelling is set up so that the game can actually get harder as you play, instead of easier and boring like another game in the series. This is the perfect game to play as a first RPG, and it will keep veterans just as entertained. This game is far over-shadowed by its comparatively mediocre sequel, and I highly recommend everyone to play this game and some of its predeccessors for an idea of what a true open-world fantasy experience should be.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Played this game for hundeds of hours on console recently got it on steam. Oblivion has always been my favourite game in The Elder Scrolls series and perhaps in my top 5 ever.The open world of Tamriel's central province Cyrodil is stunningly georgeous for a game made in 2005 and remains iconic to this day. The story is in my opinion the best the series has ever produced and this game is easily home to the best DLC from and Elder Scrolls game, The Shivering Isles.Oblivion unlike its younger brother Skyrim (Also a great game) Isn't easily mastered and does present a challenge at higher levels, Yes you get god like strong and epicly awsome equipment ans spells but so do your enemies. And the best enchantments on weapons eat up your soul gems.Oblivions class system is somethinng I missed in Skyrim, It makes you focus and develop your Character along the 7 skills you chose though you still can master all skills though any skill you did not chose as a major skill doesn't level you up.The combat at levels 15+ clearly rises in difficulty. Enemies start staggering you in close quarters and you sniping skills need to improve fast along with adding some poisons and preferably an enchantment on your bow to keep getting those one shot kills.I could write a novel on the game but in short Oblivion is an excelent open world rpg with a great story fun characters and factions and always gives you something to do 10/10 if you havent played this get it asap

content:
Posted: May 25, 2013
												You know, Bethesda doesn't exactly make really excellent games... you buy their stuff because they're the ONLY high-profile developer out there that makes their particular variety of open-world RPG. In a Bethesda game, you can go anywhere on the (typically) VERY large world map, and do just about anything you in-game character in capable of doing at anytime you please. That level of freedom to do whatever the **** you want goes a long way.SO, while Oblivion has a whole list of stupid/annoying mistakes and flaws, it's still worth playing through a few times or more. There's just SO MUCH you can do with it, especially if you start modding, which can really make this game shine.

												This game is my absolute favourite. No doubt, it was one of my first introductions to RPG and i'm greatful me and my friend stole it out of my brother room and spent the next three days playing it with little sleep. i still play it to this day, and have it on mulitple consoles including PC, obviously. The mainquest is cool but nothing too special, but it's the rest of the game that sets it apart. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												All in all, I find this game way more appeling than its more modern counter-part, Skyrim. In my opinion the guilds are a lot more immersive and in-depth as you work your way up the chain in a way that makes sense for that particular group; battling evil necromancers and getting recommendations for the arcane university, rather than Skyrim's cast a simple spell get into the arcane college. The main story is also pretty epic, as the invasion of the daedra draws near ever minute, you along with the local Blades need to take certain actions to stop this onslaught. Need a break from quests or need something else to do in the game? Well you can make your own adventures by clearing the local fort or dungeon, either by yourself or with a group of adept adventures behind your back. The only issues I came across dealt with the leveling up/character build mechanic. Cookie-cutter characters are hard to make as a wizard build has to be purely towards the most magicka to cast the higher tier spells; warrior builds and theif builds aren't as restricting, but are still a little rigid. Also at a certain point your character becomes "too good", as your attributes hit insane heights. You become really hard to kill, save for a room FILLED with top quality enemies or a named legendary enemy. I'll admit that the perk system of Skyrim is better, as it rewards using skills and allows for intresting characters to form. Would give this game around a 9.5/10. The DLC's are amazing btw.

												All in all, I find this game way more appeling than its more modern counter-part, Skyrim. In my opinion the guilds are a lot more immersive and in-depth as you work your way up the chain in a way that makes sense for that particular group; battling evil necromancers and getting recommendations for the arcane university, rather than Skyrim's cast a simple spell get into the arcane college. The main story is also pretty epic, as the invasion of the daedra draws near ever minute, you along with the local Blades need to take certain actions to stop this onslaught. Need a break from quests or need something else to do in the game? Well you can make your own adventures by clearing the local fort or dungeon, either by yourself or with a group of adept adventures behind your back. The only issues I came across dealt with the leveling up/character build mechanic. Cookie-cutter characters are hard to make as a wizard build has to be purely towards the most magicka to cast the higher tier spells; warrior builds and theif builds aren't as restricting, but are still a little rigid. Also at a certain point your character becomes "too good", as your attributes hit insane heights. You become really hard to kill, save for a room FILLED with top quality enemies or a named legendary enemy. I'll admit that the perk system of Skyrim is better, as it rewards using skills and allows for intresting characters to form. Would give this game around a 9.5/10. The DLC's are amazing btw.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												A wonderfully rich game in the series and has hours and hours of content.  I remember when I first saw Oblvion at the E3 XBOX Conference I was astounded at how good this game looked.  I first played it on the XBOX 360 and have since seen it on the PS3 and the PC.  This game on PC was a hog when released, but on more modern machines, including more modest ones today can run this game looking as good as the developed had intended.  Many of the screenshots uploaded show off the rich environments of the Provence of Cyrodiil.  Like many games in the Elder Scrolls series you start the game as a no one and find yourself in fortunate circumstances which enables you to wonder the world.  Upon the first part of the character creation where you have a myriad of options to taylor your character exactly how you want you do find just how deep this game can be.  Game play for Oblivion has departed a little from previous entries as it is now more action based, where your states do not determine IF you will hit the enemy but how much damage, if they block and so on.  So it is not the TRUE RPG experience that many might have expected if you love Morrowind.  But it enables a player to quickly get into the swing of things and as you progress through the story you find yourself sometimes feeling more powerful than you are and will undertake some foes that are just out of your reach, BUT, with the mechanics of Oblivion it is not beyond impossible, creative ways to get objects between you and your enemy, knowing when to run, are all options if you find yourself in a sticky situtation. Many of the objectives in the game are leveled to your character so none of the quests seem too difficult and other than a small handful of quests you can do most (the others will not unlock until you reach a specific level).Leveling is easy, you have major and minor skills, get your Major skill up a level and you will level yourself.  Minor skills level up as well, at a slower rate.  This is where it will be a good indication as to how you will want to play your character since if you pick a warrior load out but find you want to sneak around then sneaking skills will take longer to level.  So to increase a skill you use it, fight enemies with a sword to increase your blade, hit them with damaging magic and your destruction will increase, sneak around the dark corners of the world (and there are many) and you will get better at doing do.The music by Jeremy Soule is one of the best sound tracks he has done and I even love listening to it as I find myself looking over the vistas the game presents.  The music dynamics do over an insight if you have annoyed an enemy, but it is a good indication especially when you do not know from where they are coming at you.  The biggest let down with an unmodded version are some of the sound glitches that happen, where audio will cut out, it will come back after a period of time but you will find yourself wondering the wilds and making no footsteps, but the most difficult one is the weapon strike and knowing when you have hit your enemy as it can disappear to.  But I believe there is an unofficial patch can fix many of these issues.Under newer operating systems this game might just crash from time to time, I have found when the in-game dialogs display as white and not textured it might be a good time to save.  Save often, make sure the auto saves are also set, on PC this takes no time and you will be welcoming it after a few crashes.All in all this is a top addition to the series and would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys a solid RPG experience and a game that will sometimes make you just want to sit and enjoy the view.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												One of the best RPGs that I've ever played. You will have plenty of fun with this game and once you beat it vanilla, it's time to install mods! Mods for this game are soooo much fun. Anything that you can think of, they add to the game. Want new quests? Done. Want rebalancing of level? Easy. Do you want more weapons? How about a mod that adds 120 immersive weapons? Yes, there are many, many mods for this game.My only complaint with this game is that it may crash every once in a while, mods or not, because Bethesda games usually crash a whole bunch for no specific reason. Sure, you can have 8+ hour sessions where the game will run smooth and not crash whatsoever or you can be playing for about an hour and have it crash when you enter an interior. In my opinion, the game is badly optimized but that's the only con, and the pros outweight the cons by A LOT.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Oblivion. My favorite Elder scrolls game so far! I've played all of the main titles except for Daggerfall, and the Online one, but man, this game is fun! You can craft your own spells once you get to the Mages Guild in the Imperial City! I like Oblivion better than Skyrim, because you don’t feel like you’re carrying a backpack full of rocks, you can actually cast magic while holding a sword and a shield, and Cyrodiil is not as cold and miserable as the neighbor to the North!Another thing I like about ES4: Oblivion is once you level up your acrobatics and athletics a bit, you can run really fast and jump super high! I like this game better than Morrowind, because you don’t have to be a specific class build to actually land a blow, the only downside, is it discluded the levitation spell from Morrowind. I still have yet to beat the main quest line, but I beat the Mages Guild, beat Shivering Isles, and Started on the Dark Brotherhood, and it’s honestly one of my favorite RPG’s Ever! On a scale of 2, I give this game a 10. 10/2.Edit: So far, I see no need for mods, The game isn't as glitchy and broken as Skyrim, and the story and characters are fun enough, that I only play Vanilla!

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Game of the Year Deluxe EditionBe prepared for a detailed review of this game. If you're considering purchasing this, have a read and see what you think before doing so!Positives:+ Pleasant graphics for a game almost a decade old (2006).+ A huge assortment of quest to complete, such as the Thieves' Guild, Dark Brotherhood, Fighter's Guild, Mage's Guild and Daedric God storylines. Lots of miscellaneous quests too.+ Massive map to explore, lots of locations including caves, bandit camps, forts and ancient ayleid ruins. Snowy regions and lush forest, open grasslands and swamps, very varied terrain.+ Wide array of weaponry, many, many skills to level up, use magic, archery or melee combat to strike down foes. Mix your own potions with alchemy, become a master of acrobatics or conjure powerful beasts to do your bidding. + Hundreds of hours of gameplay to engage in. Fun for the first 100-120. Anything in excess of level 40 starts to see boredom set in. I recommend taking regular breaks to avoid the repetition, in which case it won't be so noticeable. + Large mod community.Negatives:- Extremely flawed and stupid monster levelling, giving you no sense accomplishment when you progress to higher levels. Many creatures will be levelled to you, meaning that, at higher levels, you'll be required to spam click attacks for ages to get kills (ogres, goblin warlords, gloom wraiths). Keep in mind this is using the best weapons available, with the highest skill level. Much to your disdain, you'll spend hours clearing out caves or forts filled with insanely high hitpoint enemies. Not fun, not a challenge, just a complete and utter waste of time.- Caves, dungeons and other places have a lot of loot potential and you'll have fun in the beginning collecting fragments of armour, potions and gold to pay for adventuring supplies and purchasing houses. However, after awhile there's literally nothing to spend your cash on. All of the equipment I've sold has resulted in stockpiling over 300,000 coins, with nothing practical to spend it on. Every elder scrolls (even the latest instalment to the series, Skyrim) has had this issue.- Dumb AI that gets stuck when you jump onto rocks and cast magic or shoot arrows. It doesn't understand how to reach you. The AI scripting for conversations is also ridiculous. There are only a limited number of discussions citizens can have between each other and these all feel very, very unnatural. It's as if the designers didn't bother to implement realistic dialogue. - Many textures for forts or caves are re-used and do not look unique. This gets dull later, rather than sooner, but it's still a great downfall of the title. The layouts of many locations are similar. They might have different pathways, include an underwater cave or a bridge, but for all intents and purposes, most locations have a familiar feel to them. There's little excitement in that regard.- Modding requires excessive use of complicated tools that are not only time consuming but annoying. Not to mention the countless glitches that conflict with gameplay.- Character levelling comes to a sudden halt around levels 40+, it becomes so infrequent that you feel like you're achieving nothing at all, apart from going on errands for a number of characters you don't care much about.The Shivering Isles Expansion:Positives:+ New textures compared to the base game, an entirely new environment, new colours, new armour and weapons, new characters, new monsters and new quests. Consequently, this expansion does have a feeling of freshness to it. +Around 30 hours of additional content, which is not unreasonable for an expansion.Negatives:- Despite the fact that there are various changes and new features, the dreadful monster levelling system remains, which never fails to detract greatly from the experience (unless you go to the Shivering Isles at a lower level, at which point it becomes bearable).- Rather horrible voice acting for Sheogorath, too try-hard in its approach, quite off-putting and didn't seem like a genuine portrayal of the characteristics the developers wanted to exhibit, which was a God of Madness.Knights of the Nine Expansion:Positives:+ A new and intriguing storyline (for the most part) based around the Nine Divines, where you must complete a series of tests to retrieve the ancient armour of Crusader Pelinal Whitestrake, in an effort to defeat the infamous Umaril, a Daedra who poses a threat to Cyrodiil. + Some extra locations to explore which have been added to the map during the expansion, but nothing really new other than aesthetics (the Crusader armour and weapons). + There's a real feeling of reviving the old Knights of the Nine Order, as people will approach you to swear their allegiance. You'll fight side by side at the end against Umaril's minions in a big battle, which is cool.Negatives:- Many of the places you'll visit are filled with the standard enemies you'll encounter in the base game, there is little difference in the design of these locations to other ayleid ruins or forts in the base game as well.DLC Add-Ons:Positives:+ A number of new houses for those interested. There's a Wizard's Tower, a Castle and an underground Cave that can become new homes, some of them include enchanting and spellmaking areas for convenience.+ A few additional activities to partake in, like collecting dwarven artifacts stolen by bandits, to repair an Orrery at the Arcane University. You can also investigate the caverns beneath anvil to find the resting place of a pirate ship and the mystery behind it. In the East of Cyrodiil you can travel to Sundercliff Watch, a fortress that holds the powerful Daedric item, Mehrune's Razor.Negatives:- Some bugs which interfere with how the house DLC works, causing problems with them being unable to be purchased or relevant questlines not progressing.Overall Score: 7.5/10The Elder Scrolls: IV Oblivion is almost a decade old as of 2015. It's still a very entertaining and fun game, but one should also be aware of the numerous problems it has. Worth picking up on sale for under $10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												the elder scrolls iv: oblivion is not realistic. if you're looking for realism, go away. the elder scrolls iv: oblivion is not graphically impressive. if you're looking for impressive visuals, go away. the elder scrolls iv: oblivion has a lot of content. if you expect to finish this game in your lifetime, go away. seriously, leave. you are wasting your time reading this.with that out of the way, here's my review. this is the game that quite honestly set a foundation for modern RPGs. it has everything you would expect in your average RPG: spooky dungeons, loot, exploring, a large amount of quests... but here's the thing. oblivion isn't an average RPG. it has a LOT to offer for what its worth now, and frankly i found this to be more engaging than skyrim. here's why!as i mentioned at the beginning of this review, it does not hold up well to todays standards. everyone has baby butt faces and it seems everyone, including the scrawny elderly beggars, is voiced by the voice actors that portrayed the intimidating imperial guards... it just looks goofy. but, if you strip it down to its core functions, you get a pretty solid RPG with plenty of features to occupy your mind.it may seem redundant at first: whack whack whack, slice slice slice. you start to realize dungeons look almost exactly the same. but fear not! there are plenty of treats to keep you occupied as you level up. dungeons start being populated by more frightening enemies, you start to get better tiers of armor and weaponry... you also start exploring some of the guilds and their special quests. i found myself forgetting about the main quest after 50 hours of gameplay involving side quests and world exploration... then realizing i still have the amulet of kings in my inventory. sorry emperor!!one of the highlights of this game--one of the reasons i find it TONS more exciting than skyrim--you can LITERALLY GO TO HELL. is that cool or what?! i think so!! bethesda games aren't known for having the most engaging main quests but this is honestly one of the main reasons why i prefer oblivion above skyrim. the story just feels more intriguing to me. in the DLC shivering isles, you can go to this crazy "other world" that has new enemies, new dungeons, and more content. i like that skyrim has naturally fixed the majority of what made oblivion so goofy (mods have fixed most of these problems anyway) but i find myself coming back to oblivion, a game nearly a decade old, and playing hour after hour only realizing that my entire day consisted of waking up, sitting down for 14 hours, and going back to bed.i really, really, super duper wish i could talk about this game for hours. thing is, the elder scrolls is a series you have to play for yourself to understand. still though, i hope this review was helpful for you RPG-goers <3

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												It is a great game. So far I have around 40 hours on it and I have completed the main quest, thieves guild, dark brotherhood, arena, mages guild and almost the shivering isles. The review will be in 6 sections- graphics, combat/magic, guilds, dlc, main quest, overall.Graphics:Obviously due to its age oblivion is not looking great but it has aged quite well and the graphics does not change the fact that it is a great game. Also this can be touched up with mods.Combat/Magic:The combat is not great and not particularly enjoyable. I therefore enchanted my self an OP bow early that does a ton of damage spread over a large radius(it one hits pretty much everything in a certain radius from the guy that was hit with the arrow). However I like the fact that you can cast spells whilst having other weapons equipped unlike in skyrim.Guilds:This will be an oblivion to skyrim comparisonthieves guild is better in oblivion- you steal more, get better rewards and it is less of the dungeon crawling.dark brotherhood I would say is equal. In oblivion it is long but entertaining whereas skyrim it is short but sweetmages guild is better thsn the college of winterhold. The recommendations can be tedious but the rest is a lot better.fighters guild is do not know about as I have not done it.Arena is better than the s**t bards collegeDLC:This will be a skyrim to oblivion comparisonOblivion has a lot of useless dlc that pretty much equals hearthfire so i will only be talking about Knights of the nine, dawnguard, shivering isles and dragonborn.Shivering Isles is amazing and the best part of oblivion. It at the very least equals dragonborn another amazing dlc.Knights of the nine looks great whereas I did not much like dawnguard.Main Quest:Oblivion main story was a better plot the skyrim and felt more important. However the oblivion gates mechanic and the dragons both got boring. I enjoyed playing through both of them a lot and to be honest if you enjoyed either of them you will like the other.Overall: If you like skyrim do not be afraid to try oblivion. It might be tough to get used to but it is definitely on par with skyrim and if produced tomorrow would probably be a better game.

content:
Posted: January 24
												Many mechanics are flawed, the graphics are out-dated, it's buggy as hell, little to no controller support, every enemy is an arrow sponge past mid-difficulty level, and combat is terrible. You may be wondering at this point why I gave this game a positive rating... it's because this game is beautiful. This is the game you bring home to your mother, unlike that trash Skyrim (I love Skyrim). This is the game you cuddle up on a couch to, playing all night on xbox or playstation because you can't cuddle with a mouse and keyboard. This is the game that taught many people, including myself, what an rpg could truly be. This game did not have the extroardinary success that Skyrim had, nor did it redefine how gigantic an rpg could be like Morrowind, but what it did do is further push the standards, raising the bar even further than ever believed possible. This game helped further shape what it means to be an open world rpg today and like all Bethesda Game Studio's games it is a timeless classic that no matter how ugly, old, or broken it may seem; you have to give it a chance. Escape prison, help what was believed to be a simple farm boy become the emperor he was born to be, become a professional thief, help and fight daedric princes, join a guild, explore the world, become an arena grand champion, become a lethal assasin, become a true madman, and CLOSE SHUT THE JAWS...      OF OBLIVION!

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												Oblivion>Skyrim. Morrowind>Oblivion. If you like Bethesda RPG's and are tired of the over simplification of their games, Oblivion is a nice medium between "I have no idea what I'm doing in this game(Morrowind)" and "I wish the game didn't hold my hand so much(Skyrim)". I have beaten every quest in the game twice now so I am pretty comfortable in my viewpoint. When it came out it was a 9/10 in 2006... by todays standards I'm gonna give it a 7.5/10.My only compaint is that the environment scaling to the characters level completely destroys any sense of looting and novelty when exploring things. For instance, in Morrowind you may encounter a cave populated by extremely high level enemies at level 1. 99% of people are gonna die and just not come back until a higher level. But if you are intuitive, or can just really design a good build maybe you make it past them. And find some insane Daedric artifact or weapon, something ACTUALLY WORTHWHILE. I wish TES would go back to that type of system, it added such a huge element of surprise to the game and made exploring things actually worthwhile.

Everything about this game just blew me the ♥♥♥♥ away. The music was amazing, the lands were fun to explore and the plot is still unique to this day. The story itself isn't very original: Ancient prophecy is broken so some duder has to unbreak some stuff so a bunch of duders don't kill all of the duders. That isn't what makes the plot unique. What makes this so different than normal is that you aren't the duder who's unbreaking things, you're a duder who breaks other things to help the main duder unbreak the stuff that wasn't supposed to be broken. You're just some ♥♥♥♥ that hits stuff with a sword when it gets in the way. You don't even play that big of a part in the story as a whole, you're just kind of there yet at the end of the day you feel more accomplished than you ever will in real life.Buy this game. If you don't then THIS IS THE PART WHERE YOU FALL DOWN AND BLEEED TO DEEEEEEEEEATH.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												How to level up skills:* means it can be done AFK-Sneak*: auto-run while crouching into a corner where you fight the goblin shaman in the tutorial, keeping the rats in the pen alive so that they can detect you-magic skills*: make minimum cost/effect spells of the 6 magic categories, find something to weigh down the cast magic button (for destruction, make the first spell effect heal you for the same ammount the destruction magic damages you)-alchemy: EAT ALL THE INGRDIENTS!-Armorer: you can find repair hammers as loot in unowned containers in dungeons and cities, which saves you money...-Mercantile: ...and then sell merhcants repaired, looted gear you won't use at 2-3 steps up in the haggle slider, selling everything one by one, instead of all at once-Athletics*: run everywhere until maxed...-Acrobatics: ...then bunnyhop everywhere until maxed-Block/Aromor skills: equip shield and armor from armor type(light or heavy) that you will use...-Blade/Blunt weapons: ...and block enemy attacks until they stagger, then hit them with the lowest damage weapon from the class you'll use(clubs or rusty iron daggers are my recommendation) until they aren't staggered, repeat until maxed-Marksmanship: use your maxed acrobatics to get to a spot melee enemies can't reach you, use a rusty iron bow and iron arrows, and turn them into pincussions-Security: get the Skeleton Key from Nocturnal's Daedric quest and this becomes useless-Speechcraft: spam the wheel choices in the minigame as fast as possible, or ignore this and use Charm spells from Illusion-Hand-to-Hand: Embrace your inner Rocky Balboa, only carrying a silver weapon until you reach skill level 50, which allows you to harm normal weapon immune creatures.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
Product received for free
												How do I describe a game that is so important? So life-changing? This game is the definition of a masterpiece; from the way characters talk to you, recognize your feats ("It's you! The Hero of Kvatch! This is truly an honor!) to the way that you can wander anywhere you like and still experience a challenge; enemies will test you throughout the game. Some people don't like this form of levelling, but I love it; it keeps the game entertaining right through, unlike other RPGs, by which the end of the game I feel like one of, or maybe all of, the Nine Divines. In this game, things are kept challenging and given enough variety with all of the enemy types (Minotaurs, Land Dreugh, and an army of demons). This game truly is special to me. GameplayA first/third person rpg in which you can be any character you wanted to be. Ever dreamed of being a lizard who had a penchant for eating whole rounds of cheese at midnight every Fredas?Ever wanted to be a mighty warrior who enjoys stealing plates and pulling cutlery from dead wolves(?) Or perhaps you want to be something a little more... regular? The combat is probably the weakest part of the game, though luckily it's easy to master and the enemies remain challenging. You can go and talk to any friendly NPC and chat with them about the rumors of the day. Sometimes it's nice to pick up a note about a deed that you've done. "Did you hear? The Fighters Guild is recruiting again." StoryThe gates of Oblivion have been torn open after the Emperor's assassination. All his heirs lie dead, and you hold the Amulet of Kings, the key to this entire dilemma. The world is about to end-! But the world can wait because someone just asked me to investigate a merchant who is selling wares far below the average price... ooh some flowers by the side of the road!Graphics, Atmosphere and SoundThe graphics are looking a little rough these days. The potato faced people look sort of freakish to first time players, but after some hours, you come to appreciate their strange charm and their samey voice actors. The buildings, trees and grass all look nice from a distance, but standing face to face with them, some textures leave room for improvement. The voice actors are indeed all the same pretty much for each species; almost every Orc is acted by the same person, and so on, but you can get past that. The music is beautiful, I can't choose a favorite track. Very peaceful stuff. The atmosphere is impeccable and I love the way arrows bounce off metal surfaces but sink into wooden and flesh, the way characters and their cities look like they are actually lived in. Skyrim does this, but not to the same effect. I feel as though I am right there, in the moment. I am in Cyrodiil as I play Oblivion. That's how good the atmosphere is. ConclusionWait, you mean I haven't convinced you of the merits of this game which makes my day every time I play it?Play it. jmcone's Personal Rating: Essential

content:
Posted: January 10
												For sure, one of the greatest fantasy games to-date.  I've cleared more than 300 hours in this incarnation, so time to write a review.I first purchased Oblivion while still in a life and death struggle (in more ways than one) with Morrowind, so I sat on it for a long time before I started playing.  When I did start playing, it was like a breath of fresh air.  The vanilla game was more than a little buggy but no worse than Morrowind.  It now looks very dated compared to more modern games (let's face it, it is ten years old).  It also frustrated me that the entire world levelled up with me.  As my characters gained in ability, so did the world around me, meaning progress quickly became entirely meaningless.This opens up one of Oblivion's better points.Since Oblivion was released, the modding community have updated and improved pretty much every aspect of the game.   Enhancements to textures and display features can transform the game's appearance.  The content of the open world has become even more open, with huge game-world additions, many of which being 'lore friendly', offering a deeper and wider world to explore.  Game mechanisms have also been updated and improved, and new spells, magical items, enemies and quests are available in vast numbers.  In my build, the world no longer levels with me.  Even the game's audio is open to enhancement.All of this choice will then introduce a dilemma.  These add-ons are not always stable, and the more one adds, the less stable the game becomes.  A gaming evening on Oblivion without crashes is unknown to me, and I have spent a great deal of time building the best possible platform I can.  Despite this, I count the crashes as part of the cost of having Oblivion with all of the extra content I have, and I would not want to play the game without that content.  And let's be clear:  Oblivion was not above random crashes even in its 'as shipped' state.So, what have I added that keeps Oblivion alive for me?I wouldn't play without Oscuro's Oblivion Overhaul, the Unofficial Patches, Better Cities, and Unique Landscapes.  Despite some issues, Oblivion Reloaded has also become part of my standard build.  CM Partners adds two new dimensions - many more characters to interact and quest with, and a whole new level of instability to live with (which means I currently have it disabled).  Add to this a raft of game-play modifications and you have my basic build.This build allows me to explore a large game-play world that is a thing of beauty.  The original content was very extensive but the Mods expand it further.  Most of that additional content is good, although there are some moments that make me cringe.  At 2.5 Ghz and with Nvidia 970M my frame-rates are good - especially during indoor game-play.  Avoiding the crashes (or saving when recognising the signs of an imminent crash) has become part of the game-play.The biggest negative - No network play (as designed, and no mods to allow it so far as I am aware)So, to sum up.  A vast and flawed masterpiece.  Not as vast as Morrowind but not so flawed.  Above all, a game of great beauty that influenced many that followed.  Even today, it is worth the time and effort needed to keep it working at the optimum level for me.  My optimum level may be something different to everyone else's but that is another plus.  With a little effort (and more than likely a lot of patience) it can be configured however you want it.To borrow a well used phrase:10/10.  Would spend hundreds of hours perfecting my modlist again.

content:
Posted: January 23
												My favorite game of all time, Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is truly a masterpiece. I have spent thousands of hours playing through it on the Xbox 360 back when that was a thing, and will likely match that feat again on the PC.The gameplay is stellar, the explorable world is massive, beautiful, and filled with interesting dungeons, quests, and fights, the AI is revolutionary, and overall it is just extraordinarily fun.My only gripes with it are the graphics, which are universally agreed to have not aged well (a problem solved relatively easily with mods), and that Bethesda has yet to remaster it (here's hoping).Don't get me wrong, Skyrim is amazing, a work of art in and of itself, but it doesn't quite compare to Oblivion for me. In fact, no game does, and I hate to think no other game ever will. But whether or not this is the case, I am glad to have played Oblivion in my lifetime.

content:
Posted: January 24
												Many mechanics are flawed, the graphics are out-dated, it's buggy as hell, little to no controller support, every enemy is an arrow sponge past mid-difficulty level, and combat is terrible. You may be wondering at this point why I gave this game a positive rating... it's because this game is beautiful. This is the game you bring home to your mother, unlike that trash Skyrim (I love Skyrim). This is the game you cuddle up on a couch to, playing all night on xbox or playstation because you can't cuddle with a mouse and keyboard. This is the game that taught many people, including myself, what an rpg could truly be. This game did not have the extroardinary success that Skyrim had, nor did it redefine how gigantic an rpg could be like Morrowind, but what it did do is further push the standards, raising the bar even further than ever believed possible. This game helped further shape what it means to be an open world rpg today and like all Bethesda Game Studio's games it is a timeless classic that no matter how ugly, old, or broken it may seem; you have to give it a chance. Escape prison, help what was believed to be a simple farm boy become the emperor he was born to be, become a professional thief, help and fight daedric princes, join a guild, explore the world, become an arena grand champion, become a lethal assasin, become a true madman, and CLOSE SHUT THE JAWS...      OF OBLIVION!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 29, 2012
												Pretty much the very definition of an open-world RPG. Cyrodiil is massive, and is a joy to adventure through and even too look at. There is a lot of detail in the world and it is clear that a lot of time and love went into making an authentic looking, immersive fantasy world. That being said, the most important part of any RPG is the depth of the character customization and leveling, and Oblivion does a fine job at that. You can choose your race and change your appearence with a good amount of customization. The skill customization is deep enough to be able to play as seperate playstyles as a nimble theif who is great at lockpicking and a bow, a knight who wears heavy armour and wields massive battle axes, or a magic using mage. Having your skills level up the more you use them just makes sense, and has your character develop naturally, evolving on how you're playing the game without breaking up gameplay. The other most important thing in any RPG are the stories and sidequests. There are enough sidequests to make your head spin, and a lot of them do have interesting stories to tell. A lot of them I don't want to give away, so you'll have to find them on your own. There is also a great amount of items you can find and loot. From different weapons like swords and axes to different sets of armour, there's a lot to find in this game.Now for the things it didn't do particularly well. The story of the main questline isn't really that interesting, atleast to me. It just felt too predictable, and the segments where you actually travel into Oblivion itself were all really boring. The beautiful thing is, however, if you don't like the main questline, you can just skip it. An open-world game this massive is also prone to have some bugs. There are not a huge amount of them, just enough to warrant a mention. There are also a number of quests that aren't too captivating, but again, with this much content, you can't strike gold everytime.  There also seem to be a lack of voice actors and actresses in this game. There can't be more than ten of them; you will be hearing the same actors speak for totally different characters constantly. Combat also isn't the deepest thing in this game, it's usually just mindless swinging at enemies until they die first. Ranged combat with bows and magical spells fare a little better, but not by much.Now, this is the Game of the Year edition, so it comes with the two major expansions for the game. Knights of the Nine I didn't particularly care, mainly because I didn't find the storyline particularly interesting and it didn't add very much content-wise. Shivering Isles, however... holy crap. That's one of the best expansions to any open-world game ever with a very interesting new world, lots of interesting stories to tell, and overall just tonnes of new content.This game is worth your time and money. Nothing beats going on an adventure that you craft yourself, and Oblivion does a fantastic job at that.

content:
Posted: April 8
 im only 5 hours in and thought i should make a first impressions review! i have grown up with the elder scrolls games and none have captured me as much as this. the start is fantastic. you awake in a prison, no idea how you got there. you get mocked and made fun of by a dark elf! Assasins have came and killed the emperors known sons and tried to kill the emperor! fortunatly he has been brought down to the prisons by the blades to escape through the secret tunnel in your cell. you are called out and questioned by the emperor but its ok he has seen you in his "visions". you are trusted to escape and follow them down the tunnel. you are then told to stop following and cut through a broken wall. along that way you fight skeevers and goblins. you acquire your first set of weapons and armour and head out. along the way you meet up with the emperor and the blades and help battle along side them.  ***SPOILER*** Unfortunatly the emperor is killed by mythic dawn / daedra and you are given the amulet and told to give it ito jaufree. so fast forward and you close an oblivion gate and dig deeper into the mythic dawn.... The Verdict so far.. so so far im enjoying how in depth thew game is. the combat is actually aged decently well and holds up. the story is capturing and brings you in quickly, the cities and towns actually give you feels. i remember walking around imperial city for the first time on xbox 360 and it meant nothing to me. i was young and only likes killing and stealing :D but now i get a warmish feeling from everyone greeting you and acknowledging who you are! Overall so far its an easy 9/10 only con is that camera angle sometimes and the slow movement until you level it up :D

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												A game that I will always come back to every now and then. This is in my opinion the BEST Elder Scrolls Game. This game has so many locations and quests that I still think I might not have some of them after all these years. I originally owned this game for PS3 and sunk well over 1000 hours in it. Later on I bought a DRM free copy for PC. Then one day I finally I had to buy it on steam. You can create any type of character you can imagine. You can craft your own spells, make your own potions, buy a house, buy or steal a horse, explore and find some really unique weapons just about anything you'd want to do in a fantasy rpg. The story is pretty long and doing most of the guild quests take a while so I'd say if you get invested into this game you'll be playing for at least 100 hours or more.Also this version of the game includes the mini-dlcs that bethesda made like Wizards Tower, Thieves den, Battlehorn(is that right?) Castle, and horse armor. For the price its definitely worth it if you've never played this game before because you'll get hours of fun out of it. 10/10 probably the only game that I think is deserving of this rating in a long time.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion PC ReviewThe Elder Scrolls IV might be one of the best open world rpg's of it's time so I decided to pick it up during the Discovery steam sale. This game consumed my life for 2-3 weeks while I was finishing guild quests, exploring this expansive world and getting immersed by the lore of this video game.Story: 9/10The Elder Scrolls IV has a mediocre main story but the Guild quests and side quests really make the story of this game one of the best in all Elder Scrolls games. If I was to do the main story of this game alone it would take me less than 8 hours and bore me to death but the side quests really where the majority of my 50 hours in Oblivion were spent. In some of the quests in the Dark Brotherhood I was having so much fun doing so many different contracts for them. Almost all the guild and side quests were exponentially better than the side quests of many other Rpg's because of their intriguing plots. Overall, The main story is mediocre but the side and guild quests are where oblivion's story shines.Gameplay: 7/10The gameplay of this is mediocre and could get boring at some times.Since I played through the game as a Warrior-Destruction mage most of the game was filled with mashing my mouse and keyboard while occasionally blocking just to get my block skill up. Even though the combat was mediocre the leveling system was horrible in my honest opinion because in this game you get weaker by leveling up. Even though the gameplay and leveling system were not so great all the other systems in the game were refined(Questing, Alchemy,Etc.). Another horrible aspect of Oblivion's gameplay is that the dungeons all look the same and also make you backtrack through them sadly. The only other gripe I have with this game is horrible map system that was really confusing to navigate. The gameplay might not be the best part of this game it isn't unplayable but can sometimes get enjoyable mashing away at hordes of dremora. Graphics-8/10The graphics in this game were awesome for it's time in 2006 however I can say that the graphics look beautiful some times however the character models look completely hideous at times really showing the age of this game. The dungeons also look horrendous as their is no variety in their aesthetics but some times as I'm riding through the world of Oblivion and the sun shines on the world making the game look awesome.Overall-8/10This game may not be the best rpg ever made but it's a must buy for gamers who like rpg's with expansive worlds like Skyrim and are willing to look past some gameplay and graphic issues. So this game gets a 8/10

												This game is literally the best game i've ever played. content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												Oblivion: it feels like a parody of Skyrim. Not only are Skyrim's graphics better, but the world itself just feels more serious and realistic than its predecessor. The game is sort of a more relaxed Skyrim, that was my first impression.But nonetheless, I can guarantee you that I had more fun with Oblivion! There are few games that made me laugh so hard. But don't think that Oblivion is all about laughing. The game is filled with very entertaining and well made side quests that feel as if they aren't side quests, but the main story itself. I actually did not play much the main story, just because the side quests were so good!The graphics? Nothing special nowadays, but definately playable!  The game is just so good, that you will probably get more immersed than in Skyrim, even with the simpler graphics. Hours will fly by and you won't notice. I guess that the graphics also helped create more complex environments. The cities in Oblivion are much bigger than the ones in Skyrim. There are endless hours of fun in the cities, from messing around with the guards to exploring sewers and doing quests. It just feels more complex than Skyrim! Don't get me wrong, both are excellent games, but have slight different approaches. Skyrim is a masterpiece of beauty and thrilling adventure, while Oblivion focuses on the complexity and fun of its world. My suggestion? Buy both!(Don't trust Steam hour record! I have endless hours of offline play in both games!)

												Oblivion is a near perfect RPG. It was the first game I played in the Elder Scrolls series and I loved it and is one of my favorite RPGS. Terrible voice acting, sometimes you will hear a conversation between two NPCs with the same voice. Other than those "classic Bethesda glitches" the game is amazing. Recommend to anyone who likes RPGs and sanic guards.

												This game could be summarized in a single word, good. The mechanics are good, the quests are perfect, and the story lures you in. Now, you might be saying it's just nostalgia, but the thing is, I played skyrim before oblivion and I must say, if you love rpgs, get this game. And to be honest, I must say that this is better than skyrim. I felt like skyrim lacked a lot of spirit, while oblivion has lots of spirit. The characters were amazing in oblivion while skyrim's characters seemed like they want to kill themselves whenever you talk to them. But, the bad thing with oblivion is that the characters all look like 12 year olds. And very ugly ones at best. The voice actors are amazing, but there is no variety. Every single npc sounds the same. Though, Patrick Stewart is an amazing addition. Some say the art style is terrible because it looked like a generic fantasy rpg to them. To that I say you have to get used to it, because when I started playing oblivion I hated the art style, but overtime I started to love it. And best of all, Sean Bean dies.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												This game embodies everything I love about RPG gaming. The near endless player choice, the beautiful landscapes, the interesting enemies and enjoyable combat, the campy dialogue and extremely limited voice acting. This game is a high medieval fantasy that stands the tests of time. The leveling system is just complicated enough to actually make character building matter (one of my major complaints with newer Bethesda games is that the character setup doesn't really matter, no matter what stats you choose, you can still be a overpowered killing machine using just about anything... that is not the case for this game. Get the character creation right, or you're in for a bad time). Yes it has come clunky elements and yes it can be glitchy and on modern systems it can be a pain to make it run, but through my extremely rose tinted glasses, that's just part of the gaming experience. I was able to sink hundreds of hours back in the day on this game before I bought it on steam, and since I've bought it again you can see I've played over 100 more. It's just that good.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion PC ReviewThe Elder Scrolls IV might be one of the best open world rpg's of it's time so I decided to pick it up during the Discovery steam sale. This game consumed my life for 2-3 weeks while I was finishing guild quests, exploring this expansive world and getting immersed by the lore of this video game.Story: 9/10The Elder Scrolls IV has a mediocre main story but the Guild quests and side quests really make the story of this game one of the best in all Elder Scrolls games. If I was to do the main story of this game alone it would take me less than 8 hours and bore me to death but the side quests really where the majority of my 50 hours in Oblivion were spent. In some of the quests in the Dark Brotherhood I was having so much fun doing so many different contracts for them. Almost all the guild and side quests were exponentially better than the side quests of many other Rpg's because of their intriguing plots. Overall, The main story is mediocre but the side and guild quests are where oblivion's story shines.Gameplay: 7/10The gameplay of this is mediocre and could get boring at some times.Since I played through the game as a Warrior-Destruction mage most of the game was filled with mashing my mouse and keyboard while occasionally blocking just to get my block skill up. Even though the combat was mediocre the leveling system was horrible in my honest opinion because in this game you get weaker by leveling up. Even though the gameplay and leveling system were not so great all the other systems in the game were refined(Questing, Alchemy,Etc.). Another horrible aspect of Oblivion's gameplay is that the dungeons all look the same and also make you backtrack through them sadly. The only other gripe I have with this game is horrible map system that was really confusing to navigate. The gameplay might not be the best part of this game it isn't unplayable but can sometimes get enjoyable mashing away at hordes of dremora. Graphics-8/10The graphics in this game were awesome for it's time in 2006 however I can say that the graphics look beautiful some times however the character models look completely hideous at times really showing the age of this game. The dungeons also look horrendous as their is no variety in their aesthetics but some times as I'm riding through the world of Oblivion and the sun shines on the world making the game look awesome.Overall-8/10This game may not be the best rpg ever made but it's a must buy for gamers who like rpg's with expansive worlds like Skyrim and are willing to look past some gameplay and graphic issues. So this game gets a 8/10

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												have you ever played skyrim and think to yourself that magic isint broken enough. if so then this game is for you. with enchanting you can say i dont need sneak skill and make 100% invisibility armor.in oblivion you can say who needs lockpicking and use a spell to open locks that is 100% effective.did you ever end up overweight in the middle of a cave in skyrim. in this game you can make your own ease burden spell and carry up to 500 extra weight. have you ever thought that alchemy was not broken enough in skyrim. in this game with just a carrot and an apple and a high level you can make over 100 gold potions and you can make them from anywhere.i mentioned it before but i was so sad when they didnt give me the ability to create my own spells in skyrim. i hope they add it again in the next game. and the best part is that you dont even need a free hand to cast spells in oblivion. i love having a two handed weapon out in this game and not even have to take it out of my hand to cast things. i also miss the spell wheel with the D pad instead of the list system they have now in skyrim.dont get me wrong though i loved skyrim i just dont like some of the things they did to magic in the game.also sorry if the english is off. i rate this game 10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												Oblivion is a wonderful game for many of the previously stated reasons. It combines decent combat with interesting quest lines and likable npc's. This, however, is not why I would suggest it. Any number of other RPG's have better combat, better fleshed out quests, or more realistic npc's. No, what sets this game apart is it's open world. With many other "open world" RPG's you are still pressed to follow the main quest line and, once it's done, you're done and left with little else to do. This adds to how immersive the game is and, above all else, stresses the "Role-playing" aspect of "Role-Playing Game".  So what the combat isn't as impressive as that of Dragon Age? You don't have to min-max in Oblivion: you just play and enjoy the beautiful vistas of Cyrodill. I would also like to add that there are literally thousands of mods that improve upon every problem present with the game and even improve on the good aspects. (P.S. There's no Workshop support, so you have to use a mod manager and stuff. I personally suggest OBMM (Oblivion Mod Manager) and the use of the Nexus mods webpage.)Just wanted to say, I nominate this game for the "Stands the Test of Time" steam award. After more than 10 years, it's still one of my favourite games.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												[Full Review of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion]Graphics:This game came out in 2006 so the graphics are obviously going to be dated by this point, but if you've played Bethesda RPGs before, you already know that the graphics aren't going to be the strongest aspect of the game anyway. Aside from graphical quality, the landscape is bright and beautiful as well as very detailed, considering it's size. Certain towns and locations obviously got more attention than others though and the characters look . . . not . . . good. However this game is huge and features a tremendous amount of content so it gets a slight pass. - 7/10Audio:Again, if you've played a Bethesda RPG before (specifically an Elder Scrolls game) you already have a pretty good idea of what to expect. The soundtrack is nothing short of amazing - it always is in Elder Scrolls' games. So, no surprises there - Jeremy Soule is a god amongst men and all that. Sound effects are also good but I wasn't too crazy about the voice acting in this one, though maybe that's just me. Extremely strong audio presentation overall. - 9/10Gameplay:It's your standard RPG with a whole mess of choices to make while creating your character including race, class, attributes, ect. There are many options but it ultimately boils down to the basic warrior, mage, and rogue classes - though you can use any style of weapons, armor, and magic regardless of class, which is a mechanic unique to Bethesda I believe. Combat is nothing special but, then again, it hardly ever is in RPGs. Exploration, however, is one of the strongest aspects of Oblivion and what ultimately makes the game as addicting as it is. You will feel like a real adventurer traveling across Cyrodil saving the world, as well as a few NPCs, along the way. - 8/10Story:So, basically, you are the chosen one and it's your destiny to save the world. Super original right? But in all seriousness, the main quest line is pretty interesting and I found myself completely invested in the story by the time it was over. In addition to the main quest line there are also several others (Dark Brotherhood, Thieves Guild, Mages Guild, Fighters Guild, ect.) in addition to TONS of other side quests. All in all, there is a lot of story here, most of which is pretty interesting. - 10/10Replayability:It's an RPG . . . and it's made by Bethesda. Just those two facts alone should tell you that you are not going to be leaving your computer screen for quite a few days, should you choose to pick this game up. I've personally played hundreds of hours of Oblivion across all platforms and still haven't completed all the quests. Also, there's real incentive to play multiple times since there are numerous races (all with special abilities) and some really fun quests that you'll probably want to replay but not a lot of key decisions to make throughout the game, at least for an RPG. So, yeah, there's replayability here. - 9/10Overall:Oblivion wasn't declared GOTY by everyone for no reason. The explorations mechanics, interesting storyline, and immersive universe all come together perfectly to, once again, give us an addicting role-play experience. If you've never played it for some reason, you need to pick up the GOTY edition like, right now. - 8.6/10

content:
Posted: January 1
												Do yourself a favor - and don't blast through the main questline. If you do, you'll have the game beat in like 8-10 hours. Oblivion is the game before Skyrim and has a great deal of content to offer you. Explore out in the wilderness, steal some stuff, kill a person because "mother" told you to. It's all there really. Magic is the most powerful of all things in this game, and made more powerful by the ability to craft your own spells. You can make yourself an unstoppable force with weapon/armor from enchanting.Go back to the days where you can find magical equipment that does it's own special thing like a "underwater breathing ring" and explore the vast underwater in search of chests and caves. This game is fun - seriously. The only difficulty I could see with folks, is if they played Skyrim before this - the graphics and such... well... they're worse, which is to be expected. Some find this acceptable, while others run away with eyes bleeding. But really - it was fun, took a good while before I got tired of it.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												As someone who almost spend 100h on this game, I can seriously say that to the elder scrolls series, this game is the mario 3 to the super mario games. A formula that works and is fun, but it's just better and a more refined game. I certaintly think Skyrim has made even more improvements to the franchise, but it'll still never catch the charm this game delivered. The epicly crafted open world of Cyrodiil is open, cozy, natural and rural, the way I like it. Dungeons and its loot aren't as unique as Skyrim, yet they still offer great fun. Great story, but I think no one can argue about that, in specific with the dark brotherhood. Character creation isn't perfect, but it's more open than SKyrim, music's top notch and for a 2006 game; it's graphics are great and detailed. So buy it and have yourself an immerive journey through one of the best RPG-games of the 21st century, it's worth every single penny!

content:
Posted: March 28, 2011
												I loved Fallout 3, and I loved Morrowind, but Oblivion has actually stuck with me more than both. A tour of its most recognisable locations and the early quests would be pretty uninspiring, but if you live in that world for a while, it has an incredible sense of place. And it does feel like living. The total freedom of what to specialise in, what goals to pursue, how to achieve them – none of those things are unique individually, but put them together and you have something that’s more of a world than a game. That will continue to excite me more than anything else in the genre until Skyrim comes along and does it all again.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												I recently wrote a very long review on The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind Game of the Year Edition so this time is the turn of the next chapter in the Elder Scrolls series, Oblivion. I must be honest I had never played Oblivion before I purchased it here. I had played Morrowind for years and ended up jumping straight to Skyrim (both on the Xbox/PS3 depending on which one you are referring too) I don't think this was as much a case of oversight as a little research showed me that Oblivion, despite it being a good game, was just released at a time where RPG games where becoming the norm and the market was flooded with a million sub-par attempts. The same could be said for the precursor to Skyrim, Dragonborn, which suffered a similar fate. Not that it really damaged its' reputation at all as Oblivion is still one of the most highly praised games of the entire Elder Scrolls series. I really settled into this game well. It didn't take long to get going with the first quests of the main storyline which I decided to complete first. It was well laid out and the actual storyline itself was gripping. From semi breaking out of prison to finding the hidden Septim son Martin all the way to the crux of the main storyline where you get one of the most amazing pieces of CGI in a cut scene. I won't go to far into it for those that have not played it yet or have not gotten that far but all I will say is Golden Dragon... (A wimpy girly moment led me to go "ooooh" LOL). Now would be a good time to mention the graphics and scenery which are stunning.After all of that though, which takes a fair amount of time but is no-where near as long as the mainline in Morrowind, you can then go on to do the two extra DLC's which come complete with the Game of the Year Edition. The first one was The Shivering Isles which is by far my favourite part of the entire game. I just loved everything about it. From the insane world created by Lord Sheogorath to the way the guy speaks. I literally had moments during this part of the game where I was in fits of laughter at some of the things he would say randomly whilst trying to help you prevent the Graymarch.The icing on the cake of this one is that you get to become Lord Sheogorath, but don't worry you aren't insane and you can come and go into Cyrodill and the Shivering Isles as you please. The last add on is The Knight of the Nine. This is by far the biggest let down of the whole game. All you do is pretty much run around getting blessings from 9 different shrines and then finding old relics of the Divine Crusader all of which together will allow you to kill Umaril the Unfeathered of which at the end leaves you with a rather large and heavy set of armour and that is pretty much the end of the DLC. This, to me, was just not worth the time put in to find everything (it took a while as this one has little prompt) and was just anti-climatic at the end. Of course after all of the mainline and add ons were completed I set about clearing up sidequests and doing things for the Fighters and Mages guilds. I also went to the Imperial City Arena and became Grand Champion because why not. But I felt that all of the side quests and the Fighters/Mages guild stuff was just all very mundane and boring and really lacked the kind of thought that had gone into the mainlines in such a way where it almost felt like the creators had, had enough at this point and just wanted it finished. All of this is good fun though, even if walking around everywhere being called Champion, lord, hero, knight, sister ect does get a little tiresome, but of course once the mainline and the DLCs are done there really isn't all that much left to do and really in my eyes at least I felt that the game had ended for me.My only major complaint though is that it seems that this game suffers from some pretty irking bugs in the quests. I got stuck numerous times where the game just wouldn't progress despite me doing what it asked only to look it up and find that countless others had the same problem. Of course most of the bugs had patches made to fix them but I didn't have time for that so opted for the slight cheat route of using the Console to force the quest along to the next point which works but of course can end up cutting out a huge portion of a quest or leaving you a little confused as to what to do next, in some cases it almost led me to do a quest backwards getting other journal entries about something I had done previously.I must add that there are hundreds of tutorials and tips and cheats online for the game which do help to make a bit of an interesting character or to get you through a rather tough patch but ultimately it is far more fun to run around and try and do as much as you can for yourself.One last thing.... Keep and eye out for the UNICORN. It's the only one in the entire gamePS. Why make riding the horses so complicated. You have to control it with the keys alone unlike the character which you can control with both the mouse and keys... This would have been a little more helpful as I spent a lot of time getting stuck on rocks and with the horse looking the wrong way despite what I was telling it to do. Also I'm pretty sure being on a horse was slower than running. On the plus side I did end up with a series of horses and people following me around all of which would fight/protect/get in the way if I was attacked which made for some interesting moments.

												Saved Bruma from being demolished by a Great Oblivion Gate... so I destroyed the gate, Daedra invasion stopped. However... that was not the end as the Empire descended into CIVIL WAR whilst Daedra were attacking them all at once, but they paused for a moment all because someone accidentally hit the Emperor, then everyone started to battle each other, slashing swords and clad at everybody and knocking any and all unconcious (or killed) whilst the Daedra just stand there literally watching, with me included.Thought I'd try to talk to one but I got the "BE QUICK ABOUT IT MORTAL" approach. He wasn't very interested in speaking.All I saw was hordes of guards from all the different cities rushing from each end and more and more began joining in the frey, including Imperial Soldiers. In the end, when the Emperor was knocked unconcious, everyone started clapping and celebrating and moved on with their daily lives, while Emperor Martin Septim just laid on the ground, ♥♥♥♥ing comatose. Then, the Daedra and the guards started fighting each other and it started happening again.The Elder Scrolls: Oblivion is just fantastic. lmfao_____So, I have completed the Dark Brotherhood questline. However, I was supposed to wait for someone to assassinate at a certain time in one of the cities. So, I used the waiting option. Ofcourse it wouldn't kill me for just waiting a bit (WROOONNNGGG).So, after waiting, battle music started and I was ontop of one of the houses. I saw someone at the last second, pulling out a bow and firing an arrow straight on my face when I was ontop of a three/four story building. It was such a strong blow that it lifted me off my feet, casted me down to the ground and I died. Bloody hell!Reloaded from the same waiting save, managed to get out the way before it would happen again (lol). Killed the lad, Lucius randomly popped out of thin air when I killed one person and started screaming that I was a traitor I "shouldn't" have exactly killed the person I should have. He preached on about how he was going to kill me and then started to say "Oh, you're confused aren't you. I should be killing you but something tells me I shouldn't be!"So ofcourse, Lucius is blabbering on about a plan to catch a member of the Brotherhood, so I inadvertintly agree, no doubt. So, as I pressed forth, I turn around to see him actually RUNNING OFF into the distance when he's describing his plan. So ofcourse, I wouldn't exactly figure it out because herp-a-derp master of stealthiness just decided to go for a jog.His voice got lower in sound and all I heard was: "The Dark Brotherhood will rise again! NOW GGGOOOooooooooo-" and he then leaves the city. So I do too, heading to my next quest location.So, I realized what I had to do eventually, but in the top left of my screen, it then stated that "Lucius <Insert second name here> is unconcious." atleast half a dozon times over, just after he stated he needed to go into hiding. He didn't get very far, then.Better than Skyrim. xD

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Bethesda did an awesome job as usual. Each game gets better and better. The scenery is fantastic. The realism awesome. The open world is the greatest invention to RPG games. Now you don't have to stick to the direct storyline. You can go on many different quests, explore the world and find many treasures. Meet many different people and monsters. Upgrade yourself as you go along, gaining experience along the way. I would really love to see Morrowind and Oblivion get a face lift to meet the quality of the Skyrim game.I did find the character design very bland. It definitely needs to be upgraded. Why must one have an ugly looking hero? lol - I guess we have to rely on the fantastic modders out there that are quick to take up the challenge to enhance the game. Thanks again to Bethesda on an awesome game. A must have in the collection to all RPG gamers out there.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Probably one of the best games I've ever played, kept me entertained for a long time on console, and finally got it on pc to give it a go here. Wonderful, personally find it better than Skyrim, because to me, Skyrim you are paying for graphics, Oblivion you are paying for a game. Oblivion can be very easily modded, but seeming that it doesn't have a steam workshop, it makes the process generally longer, but, as Gaben had once said ; ' Worth the Wait. ' Oblivion will more than likely keep you occupied for easily 200-300 hours, and is very easily replayable, because of the different races, and some perks that some races get. The map of Oblivion is easy to read, when Skyrim's map was rather awkward to read, because of the stupid angle. Oblivion's storyline is rather a small portion of the game, when there is guilds, e.g Fighters Guild, Thieves guild. Some of the quests in Oblivion can be quite lengthy, and some even require you to be a certain level to complete/start a quest. The combat system of Oblivion is rather simple, where Skyrim you couldn't use a spell with a sword and shield for example, where as in Oblivion, you can use a unlocking spell, and you can just rush into a building, loot, and complete a mission for a guild.I highly reccommend Oblivion, and would definately choose it over Skyrim.
