content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												This is a Western RPG essential! though you don't see my over 1000 hours played on xbox you must take my word for it. This game immersed me for hours! I would sit there playing it and then look at the clock and it would be four hors later. That being said it is a mssive time sink. So now I willtell you what you will like and what you will be looking for if you want to play a game like this.Pros: - Massive world- Plenty of quests- A very free and sometimes terrifying character creation system- A huge Modding community, but does not support steam workshop. Quarl's Texture pack is a must! The nexus is great too!- A brillant sense of adventure! I felt like exploring and continuing which is brillant!- A great starter RPG. It's a great RPG to start with!- The emperor is PATRICK STEWART! HE IS THE ONLY UNIQUE VOICE ACTOR AND HE DIES VERY QUICKLY BUT HE'S STILL PATRICK STEWART!Now heres the part where I give you what is not so great about the game, because honestly no game is perfect no matter how much the rosey glasses of nostalgia say they are.Cons- Combat sucks. Theres no two was about it its really drab and boring and redundant it gets the job done though. Luckily there are mods that fix that! They're just a google search and a little research away! - The cities can feel a bit small and under populated. The biggest city in the empire only has about 30 or so people. Though the issue is prominent in most Bethesda games it's still an issue that deserve acknowledgement.- There are only 18 voice actors so it can be a bit imerssion breaking when you here people talking to each other with the same voice. Also the ambiant speech can be very redundant after while but tha might just be because I've played it for so much time.- The system for making people like you is actually rather comical. Just a few presses of a button and you have new best friend!Though there are certianly more little things wrong with this game such as how it is very buggy (Unnoffical oblivion patch fixes this issue and is easily installed on the nexus) It is still a game worth buying UNLESS ANY OF THOSE CONS ARE SO OFF PUTTING YOU DON'T WANT IT! However I have to say this is a brilliant game and is certianly worth buying! The DLC is awesome so if you get the chance and its on sale for oh say 5$ or 7.50$ it is an easy insta-buy. You will get your money's worth I promise, or it will sit in your back log because ya know steam. So all and all a good purchase!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Ok. I've got over 200 hours on this game, and I'm pretty sure the time reset itself at some point. And I had it on the Xbox as well. I think that serves as an example of how much I like this game.Honestly? The vanilla game is brilliant, but it isn't perfect. But you know why you get this game on the PC? Mods. If there's a problem, grab Wyre Bash, BOSS and go on the Nexus. You're sure to find something to fix it. Or maybe you just want more content, or a companion that is pretty much an artificial person? Mods can do that.Of course, this isn't a review if I'm just gushing about it. I know most recommendations here on Steam are literally that, but I want to give you something to read. Because I love you.The combat is lackluster. Really, it's just clicking a bunch. It takes much, much too long to bring down an oppenent, and too long for them to bring you down. There's of course mods for that - I don't use them anymore myself, but try Duke Patrick's combat mods.The level scaling is... terrible. After you get to, say level 30, /all/ of the rats and wolves are replaced my minotaurs and bears. Bandits won't be wearing leather or fur, but high class glass. Ridiculous. One option to get around this is to choose major skills which will bring you to a specific level. For example, you might have 2 or 3 skills you actively use, and the rest you don't touch. This will keep you around level 20. The other option is, of course, mods. Frans will keep the scaling, but make it /sane/. OOO will remove it and make the world static, so one type of enemy will always be in the same dungeon. TIE is random, and adds a bunch of stealth related features. In the latter two, you will die a lot.The game is poorly optimised. It will run fine without mods, but if you use them, espect some crashes. Don't expect to be able to load up on advanced textures and the like no matter how good your system is - it's only optimised for one core. There's plenty of INI tweaks which can help. It's recommended to Pyffi the meshes located in the game's BSAs. Don't ask me how to do this, I've forgotten and I just keep the BSAs I've made, but look it up. It sounds more intimidating than it is. There's also a few mods which help for stability, including unofficial patches, Streamline, Quiet Feet and several optimised meshes and textures. All in all, expect it to run worse than Skyrim, but it's not going to be nearly as bad as the PC port of Saints Row 2.So, what's good about the game? Well, I can't say. I can't tell you why I love it so much. Maybe it's the freedom to do whatever you want and to explore? Maybe it's the almost humourous nature of the game, apparent whenever you see or hear an NPC? Maybe it's the world building, which isn't readily apparent to those who don't care to look, but read the books, or listening to the people, and you will know it.I much prefer this over Morrowind, which has an interesting setting, and Skyrim, which has much better combat and perks. Oblivion has a kind of spirit to it, and with mods, you can change that spirit to whatever you choose. Everyone's game will be different.The main shame, which I havn't seen fixed by any mods, is that Cyrodiil isn't the jungle setting described by previous games, and that the main quest is, unless you look into the lore, very black and white. I suppose a lot of people like clear morality, but not me. I find myself having to remind myself that deadra don't actually have a mortal's perception of morality at all.But, perhaps I've dwelled on the downsides of this game too much? I hope that the amount of joy I get from playing it shows that the positives, whatever they might be, outweigh the negatives. ;)

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion was my first introduction to the Elder Scrolls franchise back when it first came out on the Xbox 360. I had more time on this game across the 3 Xbox 360's than almost anything else, and there's a reason for that: this game is fantastic.I'm a guy that is most at home with RPGs, be it on PC or console and this is truly what I would consider a solid RPG. While it's true the graphics and many of the features are outdated, clunky, and annoying at times, many of these problems have been solved by the Steam and Nexus communities, and even some mods with features you didn't even know you wanted. I bought this with The Elder Scrolls Anthology and didn't play it off of Steam, hence the miniscule playtime, but I assure you, I've played this extensively. The graphics are old, but they look better on PC than they ever did on console, and with the game's low load on your computer, even mid-tier computers can play it on high settings, and even include mods for more beautiful scenery. While there's not as much "realism" and "grit" put into this game like Skyrim did, I feel that adds to it. Skyrim's aesthetic was simply to look realistic, which seems to take away from how utterly unrealistic the premises of Elder Scrolls games really are. Dwemer Ruins shouldn't look like something out of a hyper-realistic Steampunk gallery, they should look grandiose, colorful, and awe-inspiring for the work that went into them. There's no real aesthetic in Skyrim, but there is in Oblivion. A game has much more lasting power for me if there's a style to it, rather than realism, because realism fades quickly as graphics excel. Oblivion, despite having a very dark storyline and subject matter, was bright, colorful, and vibrant. The faces were much more realistic than most games that followed it for a few years, and even though there was never perfect anything with the graphics, the colors made up for it. Skyrim is so bland and has no real diversity in its fauna and flora. Oblivion's grasses were never the same across every region. The climate changed quickly and realistically when you fast traveled, but it was gradual when you walked through the lands, and you really felt like you were exploring. The map for Cyrodil felt so much larger than Skyrim because there were just so many things to do, places to explore, and quests to do. Sure, there weren't as many mini-quest dungeons and secrets, but I'll be damned if I didn't feel more rewarded when I did finished a Thieves' Guild Quest, or more powerful when I became Arch Mage. They gave you ranks and made you feel important, and the main questline was much more satisfying than Skyrim's. Destroying that last Oblivion Gate made me feel like a God damn champion of Tamriel. I'll admit I felt more important in Skyrim's quest, but it had such an anti-climactic ending, the whole thing just seemed silly. In Oblivion, people would refer to you as the Hero Of Kvatch or any various title you held in relation to them just in casual conversation, when you walked by, or when you interacted with them. It felt like you were recognized for your deeds and not just being some person with special powers. I could keep going about various other things, but for the sake of time, I'll leave it for you to compare and decide.In short, if you're looking for a true RPG that's both fun and satisfying, and you're willing to sacrifce graphical quality (or if your rig can handle intensive HD graphics and texture mods) then this game is totally up your alley. I'd give the game a solid 8.5/10, so it's definitely worth your time and money. Personally, I'd advise you to go buy The Elder Scrolls Anthology either online or at a local video game store, because you get Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim Steam Codes & data discs, with all the DLC, along with the first 2 Elder Scrolls (Arena and Daggerfall), all for $80. It's totally worth the money in the end, because you can have literally thousands of hours of content to play for $20 more than a brand new game. Or you can pick this up on a Steam Sale, it's up to you. Anyway, have fun with this awesome game!

content:
Posted: February 1, 2013
												Being a prisoner in the Elder Scrolls series is a favorable thing. Again, you start as a prisoner rotting in a jail cell, are freed by random chance, and become a renowned hero and leader of multiple guilds, if you so choose. The main quest chain is exceptionally short, but the real fun is found in the many, many side quests and player-made content and mods. Everyone in Cyrodiil has a chubby face and the khajiit and argonians were given plantigrade legs as opposed to the digitigrade legs they had before. PCs and NPCs aside, the environments, dungeons and cities in this game look fantastic. The soundtrack for the game does well in drawing you into the world and was done by Jeremy Soule, who also made the soundtrack for Morrowind and one of my favorite RPGs, Secret of Evermore. Just because you own Skyrim doesn't mean you shouldn't also own and play Oblivion!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Ok. I've got over 200 hours on this game, and I'm pretty sure the time reset itself at some point. And I had it on the Xbox as well. I think that serves as an example of how much I like this game.Honestly? The vanilla game is brilliant, but it isn't perfect. But you know why you get this game on the PC? Mods. If there's a problem, grab Wyre Bash, BOSS and go on the Nexus. You're sure to find something to fix it. Or maybe you just want more content, or a companion that is pretty much an artificial person? Mods can do that.Of course, this isn't a review if I'm just gushing about it. I know most recommendations here on Steam are literally that, but I want to give you something to read. Because I love you.The combat is lackluster. Really, it's just clicking a bunch. It takes much, much too long to bring down an oppenent, and too long for them to bring you down. There's of course mods for that - I don't use them anymore myself, but try Duke Patrick's combat mods.The level scaling is... terrible. After you get to, say level 30, /all/ of the rats and wolves are replaced my minotaurs and bears. Bandits won't be wearing leather or fur, but high class glass. Ridiculous. One option to get around this is to choose major skills which will bring you to a specific level. For example, you might have 2 or 3 skills you actively use, and the rest you don't touch. This will keep you around level 20. The other option is, of course, mods. Frans will keep the scaling, but make it /sane/. OOO will remove it and make the world static, so one type of enemy will always be in the same dungeon. TIE is random, and adds a bunch of stealth related features. In the latter two, you will die a lot.The game is poorly optimised. It will run fine without mods, but if you use them, espect some crashes. Don't expect to be able to load up on advanced textures and the like no matter how good your system is - it's only optimised for one core. There's plenty of INI tweaks which can help. It's recommended to Pyffi the meshes located in the game's BSAs. Don't ask me how to do this, I've forgotten and I just keep the BSAs I've made, but look it up. It sounds more intimidating than it is. There's also a few mods which help for stability, including unofficial patches, Streamline, Quiet Feet and several optimised meshes and textures. All in all, expect it to run worse than Skyrim, but it's not going to be nearly as bad as the PC port of Saints Row 2.So, what's good about the game? Well, I can't say. I can't tell you why I love it so much. Maybe it's the freedom to do whatever you want and to explore? Maybe it's the almost humourous nature of the game, apparent whenever you see or hear an NPC? Maybe it's the world building, which isn't readily apparent to those who don't care to look, but read the books, or listening to the people, and you will know it.I much prefer this over Morrowind, which has an interesting setting, and Skyrim, which has much better combat and perks. Oblivion has a kind of spirit to it, and with mods, you can change that spirit to whatever you choose. Everyone's game will be different.The main shame, which I havn't seen fixed by any mods, is that Cyrodiil isn't the jungle setting described by previous games, and that the main quest is, unless you look into the lore, very black and white. I suppose a lot of people like clear morality, but not me. I find myself having to remind myself that deadra don't actually have a mortal's perception of morality at all.But, perhaps I've dwelled on the downsides of this game too much? I hope that the amount of joy I get from playing it shows that the positives, whatever they might be, outweigh the negatives. ;)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Hello, Bonsoir, Buenas Tardes, ect.  Today, I will be reviewing the still-popular Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion.First of all, I'd like to say how well the Elder Scrolls series have progressed, take Skyrim for example.  It's been active for 4 Years, and there are thousands, and thousands of mods, those still coming.  I'd also like to say I did play Skyrim before Oblivion, and I'm not really sure why there's so much hate between the two games.  I rather fell in love (figure of speech) with Oblivion, and I almost play Oblivion more than Skyrim.Now there's many great things about Oblivion, Skyrim, Online, Morrowind, Daggerfall and Arena, but of course there will be bad things.  Okay, this is starting to sound like a review for all of them, and a discussion rather, moving on!The Graphics:The graphics are actually pretty well done considering how long ago this was made.  I was very surprised by how well done it was.  Now, I'm sure this will be a very considered factor in many gamers, how well it looks.  But, unlike most Skyrim Fanboys, I actually kept an open mind and remembered this game was made in 2006.  Take a look at my profile picture, which is a shot of my character in Oblivion.The Voice Actors:Yes, yes, yes this is a minor factor, but yes, I will include it anyway.  The voice actors in the game are very limited, so you will find perhaps a couple dozen of characters that sound exactly the same (but the Emperor is special, he's Cpt. Picard in Star Trek: The Next Generation!) But, given that there are a plentiful amount of characters in both Oblivion and Skyrim, you are bound to find some characters with the same voice actor.The Story:It may not be the best story in history, but it is really good, except for the later ones.  You're basically the new Emperor's delivery boy in those.  You may also find similarity with Oblivion's and Online's, as Tamriel is in danger in both (again), a Daedric Prince is trying to bring the realms together, and in both there are...gates...everywhere.The Combat System:This was an amazing improvement than the previous Elder Scrolls game's.  It's not based on the roll of dice, there's actually some stratedgy to it, such as if you're actually hitting it, how much power you're hitting, if you're decently skilled at it, ect.  This is starting to sound like a rage to Morrowind, moving on(!).Other content:You could easily spend 20 hours in Oblivion, and STILL not have everything done.  Especially with the Shivering Isles DLC, which probably adds another ~8 hours.  There's the Dark Brotherhood questline, Thieves, Fighter's, and Mage's guild, Arena Questline, only could take about an hour or so.Well, I'm outta time, so have a bonne jour.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												Buggy, Ugly, and Deeply Flawed.Yet when using my playtime as a rubric, I've enjoyed this game more than 90% of my game library.So what keeps whales like me coming back to this title?  Let me go through the pros first.  These largely compare the game to others in the series, but can be taken on their own.- Great bombastic musical score.- Incredible Mod List (although it takes some dedication to getting everything to work.  If you don't want to download from third party sites, you can discount this point.)- Customization of characters, from their bone structure (though a character's height is race locked) , to their hair cut, to the spells they cast, and the skills they employ.  Patrick Stewart will even ask your birth sign, which isn't entirely out of the ordinary for those in regular contact with him, but I digress.- Big world.  Contrary to what many Morrowind fans say (and I'm one of them), the main cities, while sharing some characteristics do tend to stand out with their own architecture and style.- There's no radiant ai or refilling quests (without mods that is...) but you probably won't be able to complete all of them anyway in under a hundred hours of playtime.  One quest or one dungeon crawl can take over an hour.  Quests are largely self-defined as in Morrowind.- Elder Scrolls lore, but that's largely subjective and a matter of personal taste.- Bigger, less stupidly easy-to-navigate dungeons than Skyrim.- Combat feels more fluid than Skyrim.  But there's no way natively to unnock your arrows after you've taken aim.- Spells can be used while using two handed weapons and shields.- No dual weilding.Cons:- No dual weilding.- A quest system that gives less in the way of directions than morrowind, and as a result relies heavily on quest markers.- Ugly, potato-faced npcs and pcs if you aren't good at character customization.- Spell creation is less complex than morrowind or daggerfall, but still better than the abortion of magic in Skyrim.  And better balanced into the bargain.  So again, not really a con as much as a comparison.- DLC that if checked when you play the game, will inundate you with messages as soon as you're free of the tutoria... er, beginning sequence.-  A game that almost requires mods to be playable for most isn't what most would call a good game.  Yet I've rarely enjoyed a game for long that didn't allow for modding of vanilla.  Subjective.- Mods aren't always professional quality, and can destroy either your game or your computer if you load too many or the wrong ones.- No proper beards.It's a long list, but in the end, I've enjoyed the game enough to give it a reluctant recommendation.

												Let me get the bad out of the way. This game has serious mechanical issues regarding levelling, scaling and how stat advancement is handled. I has some minor performance issues, and it is in dire need of a heap of mods to improve facial appearance of characters, textures etc. I recommend Oblivion Character Overhaul, natural environments, qarl's textures, and the unofficial patch. Enjoy the game, and in particular, the quests, best part of the game overall, since combat is nothing to write home about. Unless you like Diablo level mindless clicking and swinging your arms like a madman.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22
												I remember learning about the Elder Scrolls series from my older brother, who purchased Morrowind on the original Xbox. I was never really interested in playing it because I was 7 years old at the time, but I always liked watching him play. About 3 years later, a friend of my brothers brought over another Elder Scrolls game, this one called "Oblivion". We all played it together, and I participated this time. And I fell in love with it. I still remember times from when I was 11 years old, all the lights turned off in my house, nothin' but me and my Xbox in my living room, playing Oblivion for 6 straight hours. Time well spent...Elder Scrolls, for those who are unaware, is an Action RPG. Imagine Fallout set back in Medieval times, but way better because there's swords and magic! There's not a single complaint I have about Oblivion; it's damn near flawless, at least in my opinion. There's a bit of bugginess here and there, such as getting stuck on mountains, disappearing items/NPC's, etc. But that's a Bethesda game for you! Jokes aside though, the number of times those kinds of glitches have happened to me are few and far between over 7 years of playing this game. The level-up system is fantastic, combat is so good, great set of sidequests, and you can even go to literally HELL.The one Elder Scrolls game everyone knows is Skyrim. But for those who have only played Skyrim and no other Elder Scrolls game, I strongly encourage you to give Oblivion a fair try. You will not be disappointed.9.5/10

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I bought this game because it is the best in the franchise, I've bought the GOTY thrice, 360, PC(retail), and Steam, and played over a thousand hours on PC alone.  This is the most moddable game I've ever seen. More so than any GTA, hands down. I really bought it because back in the day when it came out, I didn't have a quater of the power in my PC as I do now. Now, oh NOW? I have maxed all settings, the largest Quarls texture packs, Kvatch Rebuilt, all the unofficial patches (over 1800 bugs Bethesda never fixed), all the official DLC (always have had that), all of the unique landscapes mods, Morrowblivion, Mart's Monster Mod, Ren's Beauty Pack, Signs retextured, Animated windows and chimneys, and that's before you consider that this game has overhaul mods that take everything to a new level. I'm talking new leveling systems, new spells, new monsters and giant monsters, new races, new weapons by the hundreds, new fauna and flora, better crafting and alchemy, more mounts, new quests and clans, new houses, new stores and merchants, enhanced UI for first and third person, attacking on horseback,  all on top of the original. Use Oblivion Mod Manager (OBMM) or Nexus Mod Manager (NMM) for best results. I have a modded version of this game on my PS3, and hand packing the mods into the game is worth it still. No Oblivion Script Extender support on PS3 though, so it really can only take mild texture enhancements like Ren's and simply scripted mods like better spells and additional merchants. Well if you've ever wanted a game that you would run more modded as The Sims here is your♥♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: December 30, 2012
												No, it isn't Morrowind, sorry. And in my opinion, it isn't broken without mods. If you want to, you can mod it to hell and back, but I played the entire game (all guilds, and main quest) for the first time just last year, unmodded, and it was excellent. Just let go of all the misconceptions and crap people talk about it, and just try and get into it and enjoy it for what it is. It's a good game. I had to play differently than I normally would, to really enjoy myself. Played a brawler sort, with a two handed sword, who would rush people. Also used Nighteye pretty much constantly, when in dungeons. Maybe some people like the creepiness. I, however, prefer to see, so I can rush my enemies easier, before they can get their spells off, or arrows fired, etc. Great game. Give it a real chance, and you just might like it.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												This is, in my own humble opinion, one of the best RPGs of all time. From lush grass lands, to swampy wetlands, to snow covered tundra this game has all of the terrestrial elements a gamer could ask for. It shows its age, of course. Nonetheless, it is a graphically beautiful as well as beautiful  in its story line. This game has some of the best lore I have ever experienced. The characters are surprisingly immersive, the music is great. The comabt is somewhat dated, but is perfectly functional, effective, and somewhat challenging to master. There are a myriad of different kinds of quests, which sets this game apart from its younger brother: Skyrim. There are so many places to be, so many things to explore, one will never get bored with this game. I promise 200+ hours of gameplay including main quests. I seriously recoomend this game to really any kind of gamer. For some it may be boring and slow. But for those that like to take there time sometimes, this can be the game for you.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Nominated this game for the "WHOOOAAAAAAA, DUDE!" award.Now don't get me wrong, I absolutely LOVE Skyrim and Morowind, but out of all the PC games I've played in my life I have never been as blown away by any of them like I was with Oblivion.To be fair, this was also the first ES game I ever played. I didn't get into Morrowing until afterwards, and then of course Skyrim years later. I got this on the day it was released for PC, so yes my game box has the "T" rating on it. The graphics were amazing for that time and the game was beyond anything I imagined could be possible in a game. The Main quest was epic and all the factions and side quests were great and never felt like they didn't belong in that world. This was also the first completely vioce acted game I ever played.... if you don't count FFX; and the voice acting, though only done by like 4 people, was superb. The sky, the landscapes, the lore, the rediculous number of items I could interact with; it was just so much. There is a place in my heart that hopes Bethesda revisits this title like they did with Skyrim. I would love to play this in updated HD and a few cheevos would not go unappreciated.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												Although I must admit Bethesda never made it up to their ladder since Morrowind, I cannot deny my endless weeks and years of holidays spend on this (smaller than morrowind but still) pretty gem. Oblivion is just like the rest of the Elder Scrolls games a game that relies on the core mechanics and principles of an RPG Sandbox. Which means easy to use and familiar gameplay, a big open world to mess around in and lots of magic and clashing swords. The things I like about Bethesda's Elder Scrolls is that each game has his own look and feel. You want to be inside that game, you want to be able to see and do even more than you already can. Oblivion also succeeded in this, making this game a true childhood piece of awesomeness.I still like it now I look at it from a different perspecive though, simply because of the (still familiar) easy to understand basics and smoothness of the gameplay itself. It's not hard, nor is it too easy. All the way in completing the quests you'll find easier and more challenging creatures. It's just so easy to pick up from where you left! And that is one thing that is very important. The game has some bugs and glitches, and the leveling system isn't that ideal, but it still doesn't fail to entertain even now I'm grown up and reaching for the Game Industry myself.The expansions and add-ons are sometimes a little unnecessary, though fun when you've completed the main quests.Oh, and the main reason for it being less awesome as Morrowind is simply because morrowind had everything. No really; it had EVERYTHING!Again, never get's boring, easy to lose yourself in, great setting, 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												As a long-time Elder Scrolls fan, I must say that this game is truly a masterpiece. I remember when Morrowind came out, how fascinated I was by all of its intricacies. I couldn't believe that a game could feel so alive, that I could be so immersed in a plethora of cultures, ideologies, races and factions all while exploring a beautiful, detailed world and the history that shaped it into what you see it now. It was the stuff epic adventures are made out of.Oblivion takes that core gameplay and expands quite a great deal upon it. The first thing you might notice is the graphical upgrade. Oblivion's graphics were so cutting edge at the time that they still hold up very nicely today. The main story arch is solid, with a well paced build up and a gripping finale. Sidequests, however, are where this game (much like its predecessor) truly shines. There are a lot of side quests, guild quests, artifacts to discover, spells/gear to craft. You will always have something to do, and I find it best to micromanage by assigning priority to your tasks rather than completing quests as you receive them. Thankfully, this game has a much better fast-travel system than Morrowind's, you can click on visited locations on your map to instantly travel there (does take in-game time, so vampires beware!) so back-tracking is manageable. This is a welcome upgrade, as Cyrodiil is a VERY big place. You will also find yourself trekking through the "instanced" dungeons and planes of Oblivion quite often. Your adventures through these creature-laden locales will be aided by a very good quest compass, use it!The expansions are quite good too, Shivering Isles adds Sheogorath's realm to the fold, which is a very interesting place- albeit a bit bi-polar. You'll know what I mean when you get there. A lot of extra treasure is also added in both expansions. An interesting thing to note: there is no linearity in this game, that is to say you do not need to do the main quest first, or keep doing it after you start it. You can just as easily do every other quest in the game, have a monstrous beast of a character and then embark on the main story. The possibilities are seemingly limitless, which is why I've played through this game multiple times with different characters- the "feel" of a Dark Elf heavy armor melee with destruction and marksman is fundamentally different than a High Elf deep magic caster with no armor but buffs/disrupts/nukes galore. Assassin-like characters are also great fun and very rewarding in this game thanks to a much better stealth system and huge damage bonuses in stealth. Pretty much every and any playstyle you can imagine is viable to play, and the ability to design your own classes is rewarding and in fact vital if you want maximum stat gains. My parting advice: Read up on how to properly design your characters in a general sense to have maximum stat gains (+5 in 3 stats at every level up or close to it) ESPECIALLY FOR ENDURANCE. Get your endurance to 100 ASAP, the earlier you do it the higher your character's max health will be for the rest of the game. Conversely, if you leave it low then as you level up the NPCs will outpace your health growth and become much more difficult to face. 5/5- Highly recommend to fans and newcomers alike.

												Ever since I was nine years of age, I have played 'The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion', I got it for my Birthday for XBOX 360;At first, I thought it was okay, because I knew nothing about it, but as time went on I started to love it, treasure it, by the time I was ten years of age I had gotten to level 50 on my Breton character, Level 50 for a Ten year old is quite an accomplishment... But at this time I was just running around killing people and getting loot from Caves, this was until I was eleven. At the age of eleven I started to open my eyes more, and appreciate the Game's beauty, I finally started to realise the realism of this game, the forests are beautiful, and the Oblivion gates to be feared, the detail of the enemy's and people is INSANE, for a game that started production in 2005 and oficially released in 2006, this game is a winner!                                                                      "E3 Game of The Year 2006"at the end of the day, if you are a guy for graphics, you'll find this game eight years later still HIGHLY PLAYABLE! But I just respect what The Elder Scrolls has done for me, even now in my teenage years, I play Oblivion, even Morrowind, or sometimes Skyrim. You'll find this game enjoyable, or even amazing, or partial on the fact that it is good, or maybe it just isn't your cup of tea, but I promise you, there is enough content in this game to last you a whole year! So you should purchase it on Steam, or hard copy, whatever suits you, and when you get bored of Vanilla Oblivion, go to TESNexus and get yourself Mods for things such as Quests, armor, weapons, or guilds!10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion was my first introduction to the Elder Scrolls franchise back when it first came out on the Xbox 360. I had more time on this game across the 3 Xbox 360's than almost anything else, and there's a reason for that: this game is fantastic.I'm a guy that is most at home with RPGs, be it on PC or console and this is truly what I would consider a solid RPG. While it's true the graphics and many of the features are outdated, clunky, and annoying at times, many of these problems have been solved by the Steam and Nexus communities, and even some mods with features you didn't even know you wanted. I bought this with The Elder Scrolls Anthology and didn't play it off of Steam, hence the miniscule playtime, but I assure you, I've played this extensively. The graphics are old, but they look better on PC than they ever did on console, and with the game's low load on your computer, even mid-tier computers can play it on high settings, and even include mods for more beautiful scenery. While there's not as much "realism" and "grit" put into this game like Skyrim did, I feel that adds to it. Skyrim's aesthetic was simply to look realistic, which seems to take away from how utterly unrealistic the premises of Elder Scrolls games really are. Dwemer Ruins shouldn't look like something out of a hyper-realistic Steampunk gallery, they should look grandiose, colorful, and awe-inspiring for the work that went into them. There's no real aesthetic in Skyrim, but there is in Oblivion. A game has much more lasting power for me if there's a style to it, rather than realism, because realism fades quickly as graphics excel. Oblivion, despite having a very dark storyline and subject matter, was bright, colorful, and vibrant. The faces were much more realistic than most games that followed it for a few years, and even though there was never perfect anything with the graphics, the colors made up for it. Skyrim is so bland and has no real diversity in its fauna and flora. Oblivion's grasses were never the same across every region. The climate changed quickly and realistically when you fast traveled, but it was gradual when you walked through the lands, and you really felt like you were exploring. The map for Cyrodil felt so much larger than Skyrim because there were just so many things to do, places to explore, and quests to do. Sure, there weren't as many mini-quest dungeons and secrets, but I'll be damned if I didn't feel more rewarded when I did finished a Thieves' Guild Quest, or more powerful when I became Arch Mage. They gave you ranks and made you feel important, and the main questline was much more satisfying than Skyrim's. Destroying that last Oblivion Gate made me feel like a God damn champion of Tamriel. I'll admit I felt more important in Skyrim's quest, but it had such an anti-climactic ending, the whole thing just seemed silly. In Oblivion, people would refer to you as the Hero Of Kvatch or any various title you held in relation to them just in casual conversation, when you walked by, or when you interacted with them. It felt like you were recognized for your deeds and not just being some person with special powers. I could keep going about various other things, but for the sake of time, I'll leave it for you to compare and decide.In short, if you're looking for a true RPG that's both fun and satisfying, and you're willing to sacrifce graphical quality (or if your rig can handle intensive HD graphics and texture mods) then this game is totally up your alley. I'd give the game a solid 8.5/10, so it's definitely worth your time and money. Personally, I'd advise you to go buy The Elder Scrolls Anthology either online or at a local video game store, because you get Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim Steam Codes & data discs, with all the DLC, along with the first 2 Elder Scrolls (Arena and Daggerfall), all for $80. It's totally worth the money in the end, because you can have literally thousands of hours of content to play for $20 more than a brand new game. Or you can pick this up on a Steam Sale, it's up to you. Anyway, have fun with this awesome game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Oblivion is a game that is now considered to be the awkward teen years of the Elder Scrolls franchise. People are either diehard fans of Morrowind or diehard fans of Skyrim, but I think that Oblivion has quite a lot of merit. It's world is very richly detailed, with cities actually feeling like cities instead of small clusters of buildings. The quests are the best in the series, progressing away from the classic "crawl through dungeon to grab thing at the end" trap that so many RPGs fall into. However, I think what Oblivion does best is something that no other TES game has ever really been able to do well; it lets you get lost. Nothing is quite as enjoyable as wandering through dense forests, taking in the game's atmosphere, and uncovering something new.My only real problems with Oblivion are it's leveling system and that it breaks lore by having Cyrodiil as a temperate forest, rather than a hot steamy jungle. Luckily, there are many mods that remedy these problems, and I'd recommend you find one that works for you. All in all, a good entry into the Elder Scrolls series and a classic example of a well made RPG. 9/10

												I've played all the Elder Scrolls games since Morrowind was released and I can honestly say that Oblivion was my favorite. Morrowind was by far the most advanced and in depth in the RPG genre and was more story driven, but Oblivion was the elder scroll game which I devoted the most playtime.It's graphics don't compare to Skyrim, but what do you expect for just short of a decade gap in technology. The graphics Oblivion has on max rendering and max settings (which can EASILY be run by modern graphics cards) is not cringeworthly to say the least. I still to this day prefer Oblivion to Skyrim for story content, modability, and GUI and skill advancement. It's truly a beautiful RPG game and is worth picking up when you're bored or looking for an RPG to play.10/10 would waste my childhood on this game again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												If you haven't played Oblivion yet, then now's the time.  Although it has been recently eclipsed by Skyrim (it's sequel), this game has a lot to offer, from a very dedicated and active modding community to 100+ of gameplay.  If you happen to own the previous Elder Scrolls game, Morrowind, you can also mod Oblivion to include a "Oblivionized" version of Morrowind (lovingly called "Morrowbliviion") that essentially lets you play through Morrowind with the Oblivion engine and interface.If you scratching your head still, maybe you need an overall idea of the game.  Basically, you are a nameless person who starts with nothing.  You have before you a plethora of options, not just following the main quest.  You can explore, fight, and interact with 100s of locations and characters in virtually any order you want.The only real drawback is that Oblivion has a leveling system that adjusts monsters to your level.  Overall, though, this game is a great deal and provides hours of fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Oblivion has a beautiful soundtrack, as the other Elder Scrolls games do. And Cyrodiil is itself beautiful.Oblivion is a work of art, each quest is interesting (excluding fetch quests, or escort missions... nobody really likes those) and the province of Cyrodiil is huge and can be explored to your hearts content.The lore with each and every Elder Scrolls game is deep and detailed, it is practically as if it were real. And Oblivion is no exception to this. Learning about the daedric princes, gods and different characters in the game is interesting and fun, and living a life in this fantasy world is so much better than real life. I would chose Nirn over Earth any day.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												Oblivion offers a massive world with tons of places to explore and lots of freedom to play as you like.Unfortunately, the vanilla game is incredibly buggy and unstable, and the leveling system is quite possibly the worst I've ever seen in a game--if you want to be a mighty warrior that uses warhammers and heavy armor, you'd better be ready to spend most of your time using swords and shields, light armor, and spells because if you don't your stats will stagnate as your level (and difficulty of opponents) skyrockets.  You can also expect to reach a point where every run-of-the-mill bandit you meet is decked out in end-game gear, making acquiring massive riches as simple as a quick walk down the road.Fortunately, the game has a modding community with a rich and ongoing history that has managed to create mods to fix everything wrong and add things you never knew you were missing.  The huge selection of mods for this game let you replace the leveling system, overhaul enemies, add much greater variety in equipment, improve battle mechanics, greatly enhance graphics and sound, stabilize the game, fix literally thousands of bugs, add new quests and areas, modify the game economy, bash open locks, replace the GUI, and so much more.In short, this game is certainly capable of giving countless hours of entertainment, provided you're willing to go to the trouble of finding and (correctly) installing a number of mods, depending on one's tastes.  Otherwise, you should probably just go for Skyrim.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2012
												I originally brought this game in disk form years ago and have racked up hundreds of hours on it, there are plenty of mods out there for this game and there is even a unofficial patch that improves stuff in the world. The story is really rather good, and there are also plenty of side quests that can be done aswell. The game gives you the freedome of choosing what to do and when, which it does pretty well without making you fail a quest for picking it up and not doing it right away which is useful at times. The only thing I did find annoying sometimes, is the Daedra gates that seem to open everywhere. But I also like going into them to get the stones and to use the stones to enchant my gear with. I find it funny to give my enchanted gear wacky names sometimes which also add's to the freedome of choice too.Also the difficulty can be adjusted really rather well, with no "Easy-medium-hard" preset just moving the difficulty bar from left to right (Left being easier-right being harder) it really does give you full control over the game! Overall I would say this game is a good buy and the expansions that come with the game of the year version make it a pretty nice and complete set. I think this game is deffonately worth a look, especially considering the mods it has to offer!

This game truly is a masterpiece for its time.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2010
												I'm not going to actually make a list of my top 5 PC singleplayer RPG games, but if I did, this would definately be somewhere in that top 5.Oblivion is amazing beacuse of it's "sandbox" gameplay. What's that? Getting bored of all the exploring, dungeons, monsters, loot, skills, etc.? Well, it also has it's main quest story line (optional), and a number of optional side stories.Oblivion is, in essence, the entire scope of an MMORPG, but without all the other people. As a singleplayer game, it's great since you can play it offline when your WoW/EQ/etc. server is down, or when your internet is on the fritz, etc.  On top of that, you can expect all sorts of awesome things you can't do in normal MMORPGs because of the problems that arise.For instance, you can steal from nearly any character, but beware the repurcussions if you're caught!With Oblivion you are the master of your own adventure. Oblivion is just the location where that adventure takes place.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2013
												One of the rare few games I truly never grow tired of. Despite playing countless hours of Oblivion on the ps3, I found myself entrhalled with the brand new possibilities offered on the PC. With an immense library of mods, ranging from game-changing to simply aesthetic in nature, there's a nigh infinite amount of creative content to discover. Though Oblivion may now be dwarfed by the success and popularity of its sequel, Skyrim, it remains uniquely captivating and highly immersive in its own right. Sure, you'll hear the same voice actors again and again, bear witness to the same awkward conversations and interactions between NPCs, cringe at the optional third person perspective (try to jump around in third person with a straight face), and find fault with some of the outdated game mechanics. But you'll also be treated to a lush, pure fantasy experience, an immensely memorable soundtrack, the thrill of exploring the vibrant province of Cyrodiil, and the freedom to play however you play. In my humble opinion, Oblivion is an essential gaming experience. Not perfect, but uniquely timeless. There's just something magic about it that's hard to put into words. Simultaneously encompassing and intimate, Oblivion is a must-buy.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2010
												Very good game, it is perfect to whoever is very fond of RPGs (Role Playing Games). You can spend over 100 hours playing this game....it is that great. There are many classes with lots of skills, you could become a evil rogue or a brave knight. Join the Dark Brotherhood or the classic Fighter's guild. And there is also the awesome Mage  but it is a tough class. There are TONS of caves, dungeons, settlements, and cities, and lots of side quests. The main quest is probably roughly 4 hours for those who just want to beat the game fast. Id suggest getting all the expansions including DLCs (Downloadable Content) and 3 mods for it including: Darker Dungeons, Harvest Flora, and the most important; Martigen Monster Mod. My rating to this is probably a 9 / 10. Thanks for reading my recommendation :D

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												I destroyed this game on my xbox.No honestly, like I did absolutely everything you can do in that game.Now I only have 20 or so hours on the PC version, but I can already tell that it is soo much better than the console version. Why's that? Mods my friend, mods.Mods are a total pain to install in this game if I'm being honest, but the payoff is incredible. I have mods that improve performance, and make the characters and landscapes look stunning again, even though this game is ancient at this point. Add on the fact that there are hundreds of content mods, and I'm sold.Now the gameplay is the only thing that really shows its age. Having played Skyrim and loving it, I couldn't help but miss the warm rolling hills of Cyrodil, but the combat in Skyrim is just so much better. There are a few mods to help, but it still isn't close to the other's intensity.Also magic casting in this game is straight up horrid.If you like having a neverending list of things to do, you really can't go wrong here. Like I said, the game is old, but mods really make it shine again.Pick it up for a low price during a sale.Also I might add a list of mods that you should download to really make this game feel new again.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												This is a Western RPG essential! though you don't see my over 1000 hours played on xbox you must take my word for it. This game immersed me for hours! I would sit there playing it and then look at the clock and it would be four hors later. That being said it is a mssive time sink. So now I willtell you what you will like and what you will be looking for if you want to play a game like this.Pros: - Massive world- Plenty of quests- A very free and sometimes terrifying character creation system- A huge Modding community, but does not support steam workshop. Quarl's Texture pack is a must! The nexus is great too!- A brillant sense of adventure! I felt like exploring and continuing which is brillant!- A great starter RPG. It's a great RPG to start with!- The emperor is PATRICK STEWART! HE IS THE ONLY UNIQUE VOICE ACTOR AND HE DIES VERY QUICKLY BUT HE'S STILL PATRICK STEWART!Now heres the part where I give you what is not so great about the game, because honestly no game is perfect no matter how much the rosey glasses of nostalgia say they are.Cons- Combat sucks. Theres no two was about it its really drab and boring and redundant it gets the job done though. Luckily there are mods that fix that! They're just a google search and a little research away! - The cities can feel a bit small and under populated. The biggest city in the empire only has about 30 or so people. Though the issue is prominent in most Bethesda games it's still an issue that deserve acknowledgement.- There are only 18 voice actors so it can be a bit imerssion breaking when you here people talking to each other with the same voice. Also the ambiant speech can be very redundant after while but tha might just be because I've played it for so much time.- The system for making people like you is actually rather comical. Just a few presses of a button and you have new best friend!Though there are certianly more little things wrong with this game such as how it is very buggy (Unnoffical oblivion patch fixes this issue and is easily installed on the nexus) It is still a game worth buying UNLESS ANY OF THOSE CONS ARE SO OFF PUTTING YOU DON'T WANT IT! However I have to say this is a brilliant game and is certianly worth buying! The DLC is awesome so if you get the chance and its on sale for oh say 5$ or 7.50$ it is an easy insta-buy. You will get your money's worth I promise, or it will sit in your back log because ya know steam. So all and all a good purchase!

content:

												Id like to first start off this bye saying The elder scrolls IV is indeed my favorite elder scrolls. content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												When I first played Skyrim, I wondered, "What are the other Elder Scrolls games like?". My brother told me about this game, and I wanted to play it. When I first started playing, I expected inferior graphics but that would not deter me. What I found was great story, interest mechanics, and it truly felt like an RPG. Skyrim was indeed good, but it lacked some great RPG elements that Oblivion had. I felt that Oblivion had more choices, which is a staple of TES series. The DLCs were great, so interesting, it made me love the game more. Skyrim had rushed DLCs. I finished Dragonborn in about an hour. I wouldn't say this game is a masterpiece, but it is definitely worth adding to your collection.

Starting with Elder Scrolls: Morrowind, Bethesda had saught to not only utilize consoles, but return home to its original platform the PC. This game is the epitome of the return home, beautifully designed, with a sandbox for players to follow their own paths, Elder Scrolls: Oblivion GOTY edition is a must. I recommend this game to anybody that doesn't want to be bound by the rules of regular RPGs but rather takes the story and places it in your hand.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23
												Don't let my hours on Steam fool you, I have played this game for thousands of hours on various platforms, (PS3, 360, PC). I started out on PS3 and I absolutely adored it, at the time it was revolutionary and amazing. I have 1,200 hours on just my first character on PS3, and that was without doing some questlines. The game features such amazing quests, characters, locations, roleplaying elements, dungeons, loot, guilds, etc. And it feels like a vibrant, breathing, real world. (Although a little bit on the derpy side.) No other game I have played have I felt like I can live inside of a city inside the game, (except maybe the Witcher 3, just because of the sheer size and realism of cities like Novigrad). This is my favorite Elder Scrolls game (although I still love all of them, Daggerfall is among one of my favorites as well as Morrowind), and one of my favorite games ever. The graphics are slightly dated but have a charm to them, the faces are ugly and the landscapes look a bit like a painting more than a game, but in my honest opinion the landscapes in this game hold up better than Skyrims. It looks gorgeous, (save for the characters and some dated textures). The humongous modding community Bethesda games is now known for started becoming huge with this game, there is an abundance of great mods. From new weapons, armor, quests, cities, and even entirely new guilds and dozens of hours long quests. The modding community isn't as big as it is for Skyrim, but it still has an overwhelming amount of mods. The dynamic AI is both amazing (at the time it came out), and absolutely hilarious. Every NPC in the game can have a conversation with every other NPC in the game, and this can result in some hilariously stupid conversations. Although it is funny and stupid and doesn't work how the Devs intended it, I still think it adds to the world. Hearing people have dynamic conversations as you walk through a city going on a quest or to the inn is very immsersive and adds so much more. The guilds and questlines in this game are insanely good. If you were impressed by Skyrim's guilds they don't hold anything on Oblivion's. I was frankly disappointed by Skyrim's guilds (and NPCs) compared to Oblivions. The Mage's Guild, Dark Brotherhood, and Thieve's Guild especially are really good. And Oblivion even has minor (guilds) you can join such as the Knights of the Thorn or the Order of The Virtuous Blood. Every thing I've mentioned so far you can avoid and not play, most people won't even come across all of the guilds in their first or second or even third playthrough, and they are all optional. Now then, onto the main quest. Oblivion (in my opinion) features the best Main Story besides Morrowind in the Elder Scrolls franchise. You are a prisoner (big surprise) and you are in the wrong cell at the wrong time and adventure ensues. That is all I will tell you, because I enjoyed Oblivion's main quest a lot and wish you to experience it on your own. This game's story progession works somewhat similar to Skyrim's. In terms of in Skyrim the Dragons don't show up until you do a certain quest and kill one, the same thing happens in Oblivion. When you destroy the first Oblivion gate, that is when they start showing up around the map. The great thing about Oblivion though is that you can easily avoid the main quest much more so than Skyrim's. In Oblivion you can leave the sewers and go anywhere and do anything you want without someone going, "You have to go here and do this!" Like Skyrim does, in Skyrim if you go to Whiterun you are basically thrusted to Dragonsreach to advance the plot, if you do the starter Civil War quest you are thrusted to Whiterun to do the main quest. Oblivion never does this to you, you hear about the events happening and it might remind you to do the main quest, but it never thrusts you to the main quest without your approval. Oblivion's expansions add a lot as well, Shivering Isles is known as one of the best expansion packs ever, and I can't deny that. Knights of the Nine is also really good. Now onto the gameplay, Oblivion features the standard mediocre combat with hits that feel like you're using a nerf sword, except for one exception. The magic in Oblivion is extremely fun and diverse, unlike Skyrim it doesn't take up a hand. You can be a battleaxe using, fireball casting, robe wearing assassin. You can also make your own spells in Oblivion, (after a certain Mages Guild quest). The character creation is what to expect from Elder Scrolls, various facial customization, (except beards. . . C'mon Bethesda really?) and all the races. And let's not forget what Skyrim left out, classes. There are preset classes and custom classes you yourself can make and name. They don't restrict what you can do or use. They just enhance your starting attributes and skills, and make certain attributes and skills easier to level up in. Overall Oblivion is an amazing RPG and an amazing game in general. I would recommend it to almost anyone.

												You'll find this hard to believe but I found this game better then Skyrim, you might ask are you mad how can oblivion be better then skyrim? well theres multiple things why. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Every time I load this game up, and the beautiful Cryodill atmosphere renders and the music starts to play, I lose track of everything around me. My girlfriend ceases to matter, stopping to eat becomes a torturous experience, and yesterday I found out that Osama Bin Laden had been killed (not really but you get the point). This game and it's sequel, Skyrim, are a momentous step forward in humanity's quest to become couch-dwelling creatures. The gameplay is nothing exactly new or innovative, just standard hack-and-slash-and-cast spells, but it is made tolerable and enjoyable when added with the overall package that is Oblivion.The atmosphere is where this game shines. Set in a medieval European setting with valleys, forests, mountains, swamps, and gates to Hell, this game succeeds at pulling you in completely, with an epic soundtrack to complete it all.The storyline is adequate and does give you a sense of purspo as you are playing.All in all a very good game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												This is, in my own humble opinion, one of the best RPGs of all time. From lush grass lands, to swampy wetlands, to snow covered tundra this game has all of the terrestrial elements a gamer could ask for. It shows its age, of course. Nonetheless, it is a graphically beautiful as well as beautiful  in its story line. This game has some of the best lore I have ever experienced. The characters are surprisingly immersive, the music is great. The comabt is somewhat dated, but is perfectly functional, effective, and somewhat challenging to master. There are a myriad of different kinds of quests, which sets this game apart from its younger brother: Skyrim. There are so many places to be, so many things to explore, one will never get bored with this game. I promise 200+ hours of gameplay including main quests. I seriously recoomend this game to really any kind of gamer. For some it may be boring and slow. But for those that like to take there time sometimes, this can be the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Oblivion is easily in the top five games for me in terms of TIME INVESTED. I have played and modded the hell out of it over countless avatars and playthroughs. Morrowind had the best gameplay, Skyrim was the prettiest and most immersive, but the WORLD of Oblivion is still my favorite hands down. Where Skyrim feels detached and lacking life (especially in it's city design, Oblivion's Cyrodiil felt lush and alive and worth fighting for. If you enjoy Bethesda RPGs (Fallout 3/NV, Skyrim, etc), I suggest you pick this title up and apply some of the mild graphical improvement mods out there. Cyrodiil is the world I most love in the Elder Scrolls universe, even if Skyrim is a more polished and entertaining title.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Oblivion is easily in the top five games for me in terms of TIME INVESTED. I have played and modded the hell out of it over countless avatars and playthroughs. Morrowind had the best gameplay, Skyrim was the prettiest and most immersive, but the WORLD of Oblivion is still my favorite hands down. Where Skyrim feels detached and lacking life (especially in it's city design, Oblivion's Cyrodiil felt lush and alive and worth fighting for. If you enjoy Bethesda RPGs (Fallout 3/NV, Skyrim, etc), I suggest you pick this title up and apply some of the mild graphical improvement mods out there. Cyrodiil is the world I most love in the Elder Scrolls universe, even if Skyrim is a more polished and entertaining title.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2013
												Being a prisoner in the Elder Scrolls series is a favorable thing. Again, you start as a prisoner rotting in a jail cell, are freed by random chance, and become a renowned hero and leader of multiple guilds, if you so choose. The main quest chain is exceptionally short, but the real fun is found in the many, many side quests and player-made content and mods. Everyone in Cyrodiil has a chubby face and the khajiit and argonians were given plantigrade legs as opposed to the digitigrade legs they had before. PCs and NPCs aside, the environments, dungeons and cities in this game look fantastic. The soundtrack for the game does well in drawing you into the world and was done by Jeremy Soule, who also made the soundtrack for Morrowind and one of my favorite RPGs, Secret of Evermore. Just because you own Skyrim doesn't mean you shouldn't also own and play Oblivion!

I wouldn't say this game is a masterpiece, but it is definitely worth adding to your collection.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Well, where to begin? Oh, I know! Let´s begin at the beginning....Back when the only true games I played were LEGO games, I heard of a game where you can play as cats, lizards, orcs, elves and humans, of course. My curiosity made me ask so many questions and I imagined how I am already playing it and bowing at its glory... Well, I expected something bigger and I was dissapointed at first. Perhaps it was because the only thing I could do was running, attacking and jumping.After I learned some info, I revisited this game... Now I knew how to interract, I knew how certain things work and I had great time. After more than year, I revisited it and BOOM! I bought it!So let´s talk ´bout some cons and pros...Graphics, environment, atmosphere and musicSpeaking of graphics, Oblivion is from 2006 which is a fact you can´t ignore. Game looks OK and some parts of it look great. Textures are kinda bad but when you play RPG you should focus on other things than looks. Reason why many people make fun of this masterpiece is NPC models. Some look atrocious. I am used to them but I can imagine it can turn some people away, although these people should expect worse graphics and models from 2006 game. Environment and atmosphere are made nearly perfectly. The game has a fantasy feel, dungeons are creepy and frustrating, cities are living and beautiful, and all these are so great mainly thanks to wonderful music. Check out some of them and you´ll see.Verdict: game looks amazing and runs OK on medium details. Despite being old, system requirements are quite high.Combat, controls, mechanics and difficultyNo matter how much I love this game, combat is horrific. One of few things made better in its successor is combat.Combat oriented character has very little chance on medium and higher. Even as an experienced player, I still struggle.Magic is super OP. Example : you start off with about 100 magicka. You start with spell that deals 5. Early, you can get a weapon that does 2 damage. Yep. It has limited durability and needs you to be up close. The highest damage weapon is Amber Hammer with max Blunt skill. It will do 33. At level 10, 30 damage is a crappy spell for you. At level 50, 33 weapon is a dream. Combat is dumb because when you encounter combat NPC and fight it, it is going to look like this: Hit, stagger, hit, stagger, heal, hit, stagger, block, enemy staggered, hit, heal, he dead. You´ll get the grip eventually but it is dumb and unfair IMO. Stealth characters will have the most fun. Guilds will be reviewed later. Stealth is really enjoyable and satisfying. Controls are good but if you are used to Skyrim, you might be confused- no sprint, dual-wield or shield bash...Alchemy and enchanting and spellcrafting are fun but bit complicated. Difficulty is really high and needs you to think. Sometimes it is too much and just as every Bethesda RPG, it has this stupid scaling system : The higher level you are, the harder game is, which in fact makes no sense...Quests, main story, guilds, charactersOh yeah! If there is a game with great and diverse quests, it is Oblivion. Quests may seem like dungeon raiding but they usually turn into discovering a cult of necromancers or finding a powerful artifact... Or just haunted ship with ghosts. People in this game are quite weird so they make you do crazy random sh*t like taking staff that constantly summons imps and return it to shrine of a Daedra... Or jsut go into a dream and complete four difficult tasks... Or... Ah play it yourself. Main story by writing is not worst in the series... But by quests and by the fact it is annoying, it is the worst gameplay wise. A big flaw on a beautiful diamond... My recommendation: don´t play it. It doesn´t give you many important items and is annoying, difficult and spawns Gates of Oblivion (if you believe dragons are the most annoying enemies in this series, play oblivion) (and if you believe Daedra are the most annoying enemies in this series, play Morrowind, these Cliff Racers are gonna drive you mad!) Guilds are best in series, just like quests! Be it Mage or Thieves Guild, they are all pretty good with Warriors being the worst one. Dark Brotherhood is a masterpiece. I won´t talk long about NPCs. Some are annoying and dull, some are memorable and great- Lucien Lachance, Sheogorath, Martin Spetim himself, Gray Fox and many others. Voice acting is often criticized but I like it. Wes Johnson is absolutely unmatched. Others are good but get annoying...The last thing-DLCsLittle ones are short and almost unnoticable. Knight of the Nine give you the best heavy set in the game and look great.Shivering Isles is a different story though. It is like a full, separate game. Since Sheogorath is most-likely the best daedric prince, this is a fairly unique experience. Flesh golems, people asking you for carrots and then yelling : Ni-Ni-Ni are quite normal in this DLC. Story is greta, Sheogorath and Jyggalag are good too and quests are better than base game. Items here are also pretty great. Would recommend playing this DLC after everything else.Verdict : buy the deluxe edition, tiny DLCs don´t matter but they are fun and give you some items. Knights of the Nine are OK. Shivering Isles is a masterpiece. Base game as well.Tiny DLCs-6/10KotN-7/10Shivering Isles-10/10-must playBase game-9/10- must playOverall you must buy this masterpiece. One of the best games ever made. Worth every dollar. Or Euro. Or whatever. And I think I don´t have to mention how amazing Elder Scrolls lore is, so if you enjoy good lore, chceck it out.PS: If you happen to find any grammar mistakes, please let me know.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22
												I remember learning about the Elder Scrolls series from my older brother, who purchased Morrowind on the original Xbox. I was never really interested in playing it because I was 7 years old at the time, but I always liked watching him play. About 3 years later, a friend of my brothers brought over another Elder Scrolls game, this one called "Oblivion". We all played it together, and I participated this time. And I fell in love with it. I still remember times from when I was 11 years old, all the lights turned off in my house, nothin' but me and my Xbox in my living room, playing Oblivion for 6 straight hours. Time well spent...Elder Scrolls, for those who are unaware, is an Action RPG. Imagine Fallout set back in Medieval times, but way better because there's swords and magic! There's not a single complaint I have about Oblivion; it's damn near flawless, at least in my opinion. There's a bit of bugginess here and there, such as getting stuck on mountains, disappearing items/NPC's, etc. But that's a Bethesda game for you! Jokes aside though, the number of times those kinds of glitches have happened to me are few and far between over 7 years of playing this game. The level-up system is fantastic, combat is so good, great set of sidequests, and you can even go to literally HELL.The one Elder Scrolls game everyone knows is Skyrim. But for those who have only played Skyrim and no other Elder Scrolls game, I strongly encourage you to give Oblivion a fair try. You will not be disappointed.9.5/10

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												Buggy, Ugly, and Deeply Flawed.Yet when using my playtime as a rubric, I've enjoyed this game more than 90% of my game library.So what keeps whales like me coming back to this title?  Let me go through the pros first.  These largely compare the game to others in the series, but can be taken on their own.- Great bombastic musical score.- Incredible Mod List (although it takes some dedication to getting everything to work.  If you don't want to download from third party sites, you can discount this point.)- Customization of characters, from their bone structure (though a character's height is race locked) , to their hair cut, to the spells they cast, and the skills they employ.  Patrick Stewart will even ask your birth sign, which isn't entirely out of the ordinary for those in regular contact with him, but I digress.- Big world.  Contrary to what many Morrowind fans say (and I'm one of them), the main cities, while sharing some characteristics do tend to stand out with their own architecture and style.- There's no radiant ai or refilling quests (without mods that is...) but you probably won't be able to complete all of them anyway in under a hundred hours of playtime.  One quest or one dungeon crawl can take over an hour.  Quests are largely self-defined as in Morrowind.- Elder Scrolls lore, but that's largely subjective and a matter of personal taste.- Bigger, less stupidly easy-to-navigate dungeons than Skyrim.- Combat feels more fluid than Skyrim.  But there's no way natively to unnock your arrows after you've taken aim.- Spells can be used while using two handed weapons and shields.- No dual weilding.Cons:- No dual weilding.- A quest system that gives less in the way of directions than morrowind, and as a result relies heavily on quest markers.- Ugly, potato-faced npcs and pcs if you aren't good at character customization.- Spell creation is less complex than morrowind or daggerfall, but still better than the abortion of magic in Skyrim.  And better balanced into the bargain.  So again, not really a con as much as a comparison.- DLC that if checked when you play the game, will inundate you with messages as soon as you're free of the tutoria... er, beginning sequence.-  A game that almost requires mods to be playable for most isn't what most would call a good game.  Yet I've rarely enjoyed a game for long that didn't allow for modding of vanilla.  Subjective.- Mods aren't always professional quality, and can destroy either your game or your computer if you load too many or the wrong ones.- No proper beards.It's a long list, but in the end, I've enjoyed the game enough to give it a reluctant recommendation.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												The first time I loaded this up, I had a chat with Patrick Stewart, got my head around the first quest, and sidestepped out of prison. Outside, I had a quick first peak at the world map. I turned it off and didn't go back for a year. I'll be honest, I was a little bit scared. Starting Oblivion is like discovering that your garage is packed to the roof with heroin, and then saying, "I'll just have a little taste. Just one little go." The game is so huge, it's ridiculous. And the content is all so brilliant! That's why I've nominated Oblivion for my very own Award. The 'This game works out at 3p an hour to play' Award. Go play, if you have a few hundred hours spare.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												If you haven't played Oblivion yet, then now's the time.  Although it has been recently eclipsed by Skyrim (it's sequel), this game has a lot to offer, from a very dedicated and active modding community to 100+ of gameplay.  If you happen to own the previous Elder Scrolls game, Morrowind, you can also mod Oblivion to include a "Oblivionized" version of Morrowind (lovingly called "Morrowbliviion") that essentially lets you play through Morrowind with the Oblivion engine and interface.If you scratching your head still, maybe you need an overall idea of the game.  Basically, you are a nameless person who starts with nothing.  You have before you a plethora of options, not just following the main quest.  You can explore, fight, and interact with 100s of locations and characters in virtually any order you want.The only real drawback is that Oblivion has a leveling system that adjusts monsters to your level.  Overall, though, this game is a great deal and provides hours of fun.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Oblivion has a beautiful soundtrack, as the other Elder Scrolls games do. And Cyrodiil is itself beautiful.Oblivion is a work of art, each quest is interesting (excluding fetch quests, or escort missions... nobody really likes those) and the province of Cyrodiil is huge and can be explored to your hearts content.The lore with each and every Elder Scrolls game is deep and detailed, it is practically as if it were real. And Oblivion is no exception to this. Learning about the daedric princes, gods and different characters in the game is interesting and fun, and living a life in this fantasy world is so much better than real life. I would chose Nirn over Earth any day.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												I've played all the Elder Scrolls games since Morrowind was released and I can honestly say that Oblivion was my favorite. Morrowind was by far the most advanced and in depth in the RPG genre and was more story driven, but Oblivion was the elder scroll game which I devoted the most playtime.It's graphics don't compare to Skyrim, but what do you expect for just short of a decade gap in technology. The graphics Oblivion has on max rendering and max settings (which can EASILY be run by modern graphics cards) is not cringeworthly to say the least. I still to this day prefer Oblivion to Skyrim for story content, modability, and GUI and skill advancement. It's truly a beautiful RPG game and is worth picking up when you're bored or looking for an RPG to play.10/10 would waste my childhood on this game again.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												Otherwise a great, classic RPG and a must-have for all fans of The Elder Scrolls games and lore. The only bad things I have to say about this game are that it was still really buggy, even after the final official patch, and that it has a funny way of scaling up the main quest difficulty way too fast if you plan on leveling your non-combat skills, like i did. Both of these can, of course, be remedied with fan-made mods and unofficial patches, but still you'd expect more effort from a giant like Bethesda. The DLC is a joke, though, but as a fan I still wanted to get everything Oblivion so I opted in for the GOTY edition. If you don't fancy the game or the dilly dally wonka doodles that much, you're better off with the regular edition of this game, if that helps you save a few bucks.

												Oblivion is easily in the top five games for me in terms of TIME INVESTED. I have played and modded the hell out of it over countless avatars and playthroughs. Morrowind had the best gameplay, Skyrim was the prettiest and most immersive, but the WORLD of Oblivion is still my favorite hands down. Where Skyrim feels detached and lacking life (especially in it's city design, Oblivion's Cyrodiil felt lush and alive and worth fighting for. If you enjoy Bethesda RPGs (Fallout 3/NV, Skyrim, etc), I suggest you pick this title up and apply some of the mild graphical improvement mods out there. Cyrodiil is the world I most love in the Elder Scrolls universe, even if Skyrim is a more polished and entertaining title.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2012
												No, it isn't Morrowind, sorry. And in my opinion, it isn't broken without mods. If you want to, you can mod it to hell and back, but I played the entire game (all guilds, and main quest) for the first time just last year, unmodded, and it was excellent. Just let go of all the misconceptions and crap people talk about it, and just try and get into it and enjoy it for what it is. It's a good game. I had to play differently than I normally would, to really enjoy myself. Played a brawler sort, with a two handed sword, who would rush people. Also used Nighteye pretty much constantly, when in dungeons. Maybe some people like the creepiness. I, however, prefer to see, so I can rush my enemies easier, before they can get their spells off, or arrows fired, etc. Great game. Give it a real chance, and you just might like it.
