number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22
												I remember learning about the Elder Scrolls series from my older brother, who purchased Morrowind on the original Xbox. I was never really interested in playing it because I was 7 years old at the time, but I always liked watching him play. About 3 years later, a friend of my brothers brought over another Elder Scrolls game, this one called "Oblivion". We all played it together, and I participated this time. And I fell in love with it. I still remember times from when I was 11 years old, all the lights turned off in my house, nothin' but me and my Xbox in my living room, playing Oblivion for 6 straight hours. Time well spent...Elder Scrolls, for those who are unaware, is an Action RPG. Imagine Fallout set back in Medieval times, but way better because there's swords and magic! There's not a single complaint I have about Oblivion; it's damn near flawless, at least in my opinion. There's a bit of bugginess here and there, such as getting stuck on mountains, disappearing items/NPC's, etc. But that's a Bethesda game for you! Jokes aside though, the number of times those kinds of glitches have happened to me are few and far between over 7 years of playing this game. The level-up system is fantastic, combat is so good, great set of sidequests, and you can even go to literally HELL.The one Elder Scrolls game everyone knows is Skyrim. But for those who have only played Skyrim and no other Elder Scrolls game, I strongly encourage you to give Oblivion a fair try. You will not be disappointed.9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Well, where to begin? Oh, I know! Let´s begin at the beginning....Back when the only true games I played were LEGO games, I heard of a game where you can play as cats, lizards, orcs, elves and humans, of course. My curiosity made me ask so many questions and I imagined how I am already playing it and bowing at its glory... Well, I expected something bigger and I was dissapointed at first. Perhaps it was because the only thing I could do was running, attacking and jumping.After I learned some info, I revisited this game... Now I knew how to interract, I knew how certain things work and I had great time. After more than year, I revisited it and BOOM! I bought it!So let´s talk ´bout some cons and pros...Graphics, environment, atmosphere and musicSpeaking of graphics, Oblivion is from 2006 which is a fact you can´t ignore. Game looks OK and some parts of it look great. Textures are kinda bad but when you play RPG you should focus on other things than looks. Reason why many people make fun of this masterpiece is NPC models. Some look atrocious. I am used to them but I can imagine it can turn some people away, although these people should expect worse graphics and models from 2006 game. Environment and atmosphere are made nearly perfectly. The game has a fantasy feel, dungeons are creepy and frustrating, cities are living and beautiful, and all these are so great mainly thanks to wonderful music. Check out some of them and you´ll see.Verdict: game looks amazing and runs OK on medium details. Despite being old, system requirements are quite high.Combat, controls, mechanics and difficultyNo matter how much I love this game, combat is horrific. One of few things made better in its successor is combat.Combat oriented character has very little chance on medium and higher. Even as an experienced player, I still struggle.Magic is super OP. Example : you start off with about 100 magicka. You start with spell that deals 5. Early, you can get a weapon that does 2 damage. Yep. It has limited durability and needs you to be up close. The highest damage weapon is Amber Hammer with max Blunt skill. It will do 33. At level 10, 30 damage is a crappy spell for you. At level 50, 33 weapon is a dream. Combat is dumb because when you encounter combat NPC and fight it, it is going to look like this: Hit, stagger, hit, stagger, heal, hit, stagger, block, enemy staggered, hit, heal, he dead. You´ll get the grip eventually but it is dumb and unfair IMO. Stealth characters will have the most fun. Guilds will be reviewed later. Stealth is really enjoyable and satisfying. Controls are good but if you are used to Skyrim, you might be confused- no sprint, dual-wield or shield bash...Alchemy and enchanting and spellcrafting are fun but bit complicated. Difficulty is really high and needs you to think. Sometimes it is too much and just as every Bethesda RPG, it has this stupid scaling system : The higher level you are, the harder game is, which in fact makes no sense...Quests, main story, guilds, charactersOh yeah! If there is a game with great and diverse quests, it is Oblivion. Quests may seem like dungeon raiding but they usually turn into discovering a cult of necromancers or finding a powerful artifact... Or just haunted ship with ghosts. People in this game are quite weird so they make you do crazy random sh*t like taking staff that constantly summons imps and return it to shrine of a Daedra... Or jsut go into a dream and complete four difficult tasks... Or... Ah play it yourself. Main story by writing is not worst in the series... But by quests and by the fact it is annoying, it is the worst gameplay wise. A big flaw on a beautiful diamond... My recommendation: don´t play it. It doesn´t give you many important items and is annoying, difficult and spawns Gates of Oblivion (if you believe dragons are the most annoying enemies in this series, play oblivion) (and if you believe Daedra are the most annoying enemies in this series, play Morrowind, these Cliff Racers are gonna drive you mad!) Guilds are best in series, just like quests! Be it Mage or Thieves Guild, they are all pretty good with Warriors being the worst one. Dark Brotherhood is a masterpiece. I won´t talk long about NPCs. Some are annoying and dull, some are memorable and great- Lucien Lachance, Sheogorath, Martin Spetim himself, Gray Fox and many others. Voice acting is often criticized but I like it. Wes Johnson is absolutely unmatched. Others are good but get annoying...The last thing-DLCsLittle ones are short and almost unnoticable. Knight of the Nine give you the best heavy set in the game and look great.Shivering Isles is a different story though. It is like a full, separate game. Since Sheogorath is most-likely the best daedric prince, this is a fairly unique experience. Flesh golems, people asking you for carrots and then yelling : Ni-Ni-Ni are quite normal in this DLC. Story is greta, Sheogorath and Jyggalag are good too and quests are better than base game. Items here are also pretty great. Would recommend playing this DLC after everything else.Verdict : buy the deluxe edition, tiny DLCs don´t matter but they are fun and give you some items. Knights of the Nine are OK. Shivering Isles is a masterpiece. Base game as well.Tiny DLCs-6/10KotN-7/10Shivering Isles-10/10-must playBase game-9/10- must playOverall you must buy this masterpiece. One of the best games ever made. Worth every dollar. Or Euro. Or whatever. And I think I don´t have to mention how amazing Elder Scrolls lore is, so if you enjoy good lore, chceck it out.PS: If you happen to find any grammar mistakes, please let me know.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												So my last review was made when I was fishing for attention so Im actually gonna review this game.I've played more than 14 hours on Steam, I've played about 300 hours on the 360 version alone and I've had a blast every single moment.I've beat the game multiple times and got so much enjoyment out of it, and that's without mods and just playing vanilla.So many books to read and steal, and so many tomes and stuff to learn. Guild quests and Arena challenges in the imperial colosseum.Some quests are actually time dependent, unlike Skyrim where you just meet them whenever and it doesn't matter. The dark humor, which Skyrim doesn't have, will keep you entertained for weeks, the weird robo animations and weird voice acting just add to the charm of this game. Which reminds me, if you liked Skyrim, play this game.If you haven't played either yet, play this game first, then play Skyrim.I'm kidding, but for real Skyrim is really just dumbed down Oblivion, nothing other than Morrowind really compares to this game.The amount of equipment and quests that you initially find to undertake is minimal compared to most games, but exploring the land and just experiencing the game is really the greatest part of Oblivion. Like accidentally contracting Vapirism and having to do this really hard quest to get rid of it, but in Skyrim you literally just talk to a guy and he cures you.There are so many mods out there for this game, I don't think it beats Skyrim but it's up there. You will have fun with this game.You do have to talk to civilians and get the lay of new towns and areas before you find hints where new quests might be, but they are all worth it.Enjoy breaking the law, and getting those stolen goods.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												No, I mean. No. A game literally can not be this damn good. There's a bias in my opinion of course, having played this game before I played Morrowind and Skyrim, but all things considered, Oblivion is the highlight of the series. With Morrowind you had great variation in the environment and a truly wonderful game. And then came Oblivion, offering many, many, many hours of gameplay [I have 2500+ on PS3] and an incredible replay value. A game is all about how it makes you feel. Oblivion, with it's bright and vivid colours, compelling story, and amazing design makes you feel like you're in the game. I don't want to sound completely biased, so I want to say some negative things about it, which is hard for me. There are [it being a Bethesda game, after all] a fair share of its bugs and glitches. A few quests in the game were scrapped halfway through, and hearing people reference these quests which can't be completed, initaded, or even alluded to more than once are bothersome. The design of caves, forts, and dungeons can get repetitve. Many people complain about the NPC's faces, which, in the reality of things, aren't bad. Some are absolutely revolting [Bruma guards, specifically. And this one guard in Anvil], but the majority are well done. The soundtrack is the best I've ever heard. The music is cheerful, and fits the environment perfectly. [Jeremy Soule has a talent for that, look at KotOR]. The variation in the wilderness and in the cities is delightful. Each city has its own style of architecture, influenced by various cultures from The Elder Scrolls series. Easily my favorite game of all time, no matter what genre you're interested in, give it a try. Put away any preconceived notions of the game's quality based on graphics [which aren't even that bad, especially for 2006] and experience that which is Oblivion.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												Let me preface this by saying I LOVE Elderscrolls games. Love them. Strapped a bedpan to my bum and played this game and Skyrim for months. First thing I do in every game is to get a feel for max difficulty. This game on max difficulty is legit hard. However, the only way to play on max difficulty is to create what I call "The Pokemon Master" build. Physical damage you do is soooooo reduced. Literally <1 damage. So the only way to play is to conjure pokemon to fight for you. Their damage is not reduced. So you let the pokemon fight until it despawns, then throw out another one. Lather, rinse, repeat. It prevents a lot of fun and creativity in a class. Sometimes you can poison your weapons and take them down with bug bites. It is boring.However! This game is GLORIOUS! Graphics may suck, but you will not care. The story lines are what grip you. The combat on everything but max difficulty is fun. The world does feel alive in this game. There is enough to entertain you for hundreds of hours, and that is just on one character. This was the first game in the series that I played back on that old crap box 360. There is a redesign mod that does improve graphics and models by a ton. It's on Nexus Mods. Definitely check that out. All in all, a great game worthy of every penny. It's like dirt cheap now so there is no reason not the pick this one up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15
												Oblivion was my first Elder Scrolls game, and I loved it so much that I fell in love with the franchise almost immediately.  It's got an engaging storyline, lots of sidequests to keep you occupied for a good long time, and a nice open world design.  Combat takes some getting used to, but it's not nearly as boring as some folks like to claim that it is.  You just have to adapt your combat strategies in real time, learn how and when to block and so on, and be prepared to take a few hits if you get staggered (and chances are you WILL get staggered).There are a few gripes I have about this game, though, and despite the fact that Bethesda is well known for buggy games, the bugs really aren't that big of a complaint for me.  What bothers me most about this game is that enemies scale up with you whenever you level up.  It's as if the whole wide world basically revolves around you.  At level 1 you're fighting wolves and bandits wearing cheap fur armor, but around level 6 you're fighting bandits in enchanted steel plate armor and every other bandit you encounter has magic... and then there are the trolls that you cannot kill because their health regenerates so ridiculously fast.  It's unnerving and it also really breaks any immersion that you might have gotten early on in the game. Thankfully, there are mods you can get for this game that will allow you to tone down the problems a bit, the Unofficial Patch is a definite must with this game as it takes out most of the bugs that Bethesda never dealt with.  There are also mods that will make the game more balanced.  The only gripes I have about mods is that installation tends to be a lot more complicated than with newer moddable games like Skyrim, and that mods on this game don't seem to work as well on the Steam version as they do on the retail version.  At the same time, though, the fact that there actually is a retail version that doesn't require a Steam account is a definite plus, especially given the problems with mods on the Steam version (and there are other problems I've encountered on the Steam version as well, usually having to do with the Steam Overlay).  So in short, Oblivion is a great Elder Scrolls game.  For a game that originally came out in 2006, it's aged pretty well, and while I do recommend this game I do so with a caveat: if you want to mod this game, buy the retail version instead of the Steam version.  You'll have a lot better time installing mods and getting them to actually work on the non-Steam version than you will on the Steam version.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												So my last review was made when I was fishing for attention so Im actually gonna review this game.I've played more than 14 hours on Steam, I've played about 300 hours on the 360 version alone and I've had a blast every single moment.I've beat the game multiple times and got so much enjoyment out of it, and that's without mods and just playing vanilla.So many books to read and steal, and so many tomes and stuff to learn. Guild quests and Arena challenges in the imperial colosseum.Some quests are actually time dependent, unlike Skyrim where you just meet them whenever and it doesn't matter. The dark humor, which Skyrim doesn't have, will keep you entertained for weeks, the weird robo animations and weird voice acting just add to the charm of this game. Which reminds me, if you liked Skyrim, play this game.If you haven't played either yet, play this game first, then play Skyrim.I'm kidding, but for real Skyrim is really just dumbed down Oblivion, nothing other than Morrowind really compares to this game.The amount of equipment and quests that you initially find to undertake is minimal compared to most games, but exploring the land and just experiencing the game is really the greatest part of Oblivion. Like accidentally contracting Vapirism and having to do this really hard quest to get rid of it, but in Skyrim you literally just talk to a guy and he cures you.There are so many mods out there for this game, I don't think it beats Skyrim but it's up there. You will have fun with this game.You do have to talk to civilians and get the lay of new towns and areas before you find hints where new quests might be, but they are all worth it.Enjoy breaking the law, and getting those stolen goods.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion was one of the first noteworthy games to come out of the Xbox 360/PS3/Wii era. It shows in the graphics, but there is a metric ton of fun to be had. The combat is fun and frantic. The world is pretty large, but dense, with dungeons, temples, and other structures of that kind around every corner, waiting to be explored and conquered. The citizens populating the game world are more intriguing than your typical video game space-fillers, showing an individuality, wit, and complexity that contradicts the lack of variety in voices. You're going to hear the same people, but they won't be saying the same things in the same way, and that personality helps to bring the world to life in ways that aren't simply technological. Oblivion may be less handsome than its successor, Skyrim, but it excels by giving you a more colorful, interesting swath of country to explore. Spring for the Deluxe Edition, too. The additional content is definitely worth the extra $5.

												This game is just epic.  I am not sure what exactly it is I like over Skyrim, but the game is just fun to me. I enjoy having to work on different aspects of life.  If you want to run faster you in need to run more or go swimming.  If you want to get better at swords make sure you hit.  The magic although one handed feels more powerful to start.  The only thing I hate is the whole zoom in to talk thing.  However, I do love the facial expressions and how they relate to your speechcrafting.  I want to make people like me more.  I need to learn how to talk to them.  Skyrim made me feel it was just all attributes.  I didn't feel the climb like in Oblivion. Morrowind was great as well.  Skyrim feels it took out something both of the games had.  So if your wondering should you buy this old title.  I say yes.  If you don't have it.  I personally say pick up Morrowind.

												By far the greatest game I have ever played. I first played Oblivion many years ago, getting the Game of the Year edition on two disk DVD Rom. Even with Skyrim and the Fallouts and all kinds of other things to play, Oblivion is the game that I always come back to. I can't recommend this game enough.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion was one of the first noteworthy games to come out of the Xbox 360/PS3/Wii era. It shows in the graphics, but there is a metric ton of fun to be had. The combat is fun and frantic. The world is pretty large, but dense, with dungeons, temples, and other structures of that kind around every corner, waiting to be explored and conquered. The citizens populating the game world are more intriguing than your typical video game space-fillers, showing an individuality, wit, and complexity that contradicts the lack of variety in voices. You're going to hear the same people, but they won't be saying the same things in the same way, and that personality helps to bring the world to life in ways that aren't simply technological. Oblivion may be less handsome than its successor, Skyrim, but it excels by giving you a more colorful, interesting swath of country to explore. Spring for the Deluxe Edition, too. The additional content is definitely worth the extra $5.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I would give this game 4.5/5 stars.First and foremost, there is a right way and a wrong way to play Oblivion. I don't know how to explain it, but the way you approach the game gives it the distinction of feeling monotonous and repetitive vs feeling engaging and rewarding.In comparison to Morrowind: The graphics and combat system have improved greatly, although obviously not as good as Skyrim has it. Unlike Morrowind, the quests in Oblivion make you feel important, and they are equally engaging, fascinating, and rewarding. Oblivion's environment isn't as diverse as Morrowind's, so travelling on foot can often feel tedious after a while. Fortunately, you can ride horses, which let you fly by terrain quickly (whereas horses in Skyrim are as slow as molasses).In comparison to Skyrim: Obviously Skyrim has numerous improvements over Oblivion, and has attained critical acclaim even greater than Oblivion has, thus bringing TES virgins into our fold. Having said that, there are some things that Oblivion got right that Skyrim totally screwed over. Skyrim has horrible quests: they're short, cliché, predictable, and unrewarding. Oblivion's questlines and sidequests, on the other hand, are very well tailored, immersive, surprising, and rewarding - certainly the best of the three. Skyrim's horses painfully slow, but Oblivion horses make a huge difference in travel time. Skyrim's towns are small and unvaried, whereas Oblivion towns are large, intricately detailed, and extravagent. Skyrim's monsters and dungeons are far more primative, predictable, and not as varied than those found in Morrowind and Oblivion; while the combat system isn't as good as Skyrim's, the types of monsters which you are fighting are more exciting in Oblivion.Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim all have different things to offer but I highly recommend that, if this is your kind of genre, you play them all.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I originally played this game for over 200 hours when it first came out. This is truly one of my favorites of favorites the story and scenery are far more superior to Skyrim, but the graphics are a little dated but well enough (before modding) as well as the game engine a little buggy (I recommend the unofficial patch to fix). I went through another play through and modded it to look better and I can really say it looks better with mods almost as good as Skyrim after I was done with it. I’m also using Xpadder to map the keyboard keys to a XBOX one controller and I seem to be getting great results with it. I would say all and all this game is a great experience 10/10 for an open world RPG with no remorse starting out. you will get lost or try to wander at first, but try to stick to the main quest for a little bit till you get a little more powerful before wandering off.The thieves guild and dark brotherhood quest are some of the best game play in the series to date, and the add on DLCs are some of the best pieces of work I’ve seen take an already brilliant captivating game to a whole other level over and beyond  11/10 what it is and make it that much better. Note: If you played this on Xbox or PS3 Port, you my friend were bamboozled with sub-par graphics and lower res that’s just atrocious and downright unplayable. The PC copy (GOTY) edition with some mods (not to many) to make it look nicer, I’ll play it all day long and revisit time and time again.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												After Morrowind, this game was a big step forward. Much-improved graphics and gameplay (plus, no cliff-gliders!).  In Morrowind,  I don't think had a truly central story-line. Oblivion changes all of that, giving a core story, many side-quests and the early stages of playing a monk character, which was even better in Skyrim thanks to a mod.Too bad the idea of The Workshop mods hadn't surfaced yet. Thank god for The Elder Scrolls Wiki, which finally gave you a bit of a leg up when you needed it. Good voice acting throughout, with Patrick Stewart and Sean Bean included, just to mention two.  My younger son refused to play the game for awhile, believing Morrowind was "pure" Elder Scroll game. After he got, he never looked backed.I've recently started a new game as I was having issues with Skyrim: Legendary Edition (some of my old Skyrim files still in the library caused it, I think) and i plan on playing this Bethesda game until I can get its sequel program up and running again.One nice thing: nowhere near as buggy as Elder Scrolls 3, with few crashes and I think its playability has stood the test of time. Having the game of the year helps, too.I give a 8 out of ten septims!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												What a game.  Ignore my steam hours, I recently rebought after losing my original disks.  I've put over a thousand hours into this game easily following it's original release.Oblivion isn't so much a game as it is a second life.  Cyrodil is like that perfect holiday destination that makes you wish you could retire and just go and live out the rest of your life taking in it's rolling beauty.  Bethesda will always tell you that the world is the star of their games and that sentiment shows through more so in Oblivion than any other game they have ever made imo.  Every city is unique with it's own distinctive architectural style that lends a tremendous air of believability to the environment.  The variety of the landscapes, from the chilly snow covered mountains of Bruma to the dense, marshy forests of Blackwood, this really is a thing of beauty.  A place where you can lose yourself, where time seems to stand still as you're completely absorbed in it's world.Yes, the AI is clunky, the conversations between them are often comical and have a tendency to repeat.  The combat is ok, but not brilliant.  Spell casting is less refined than in Skyrim.  The NPC's are ugly, sometimes disturbingly so.  Beggars will plead for assistance in the wavering tones of a 90 year old then discuss the Fighters Guild recruitment drive in the tones of an aristocratic socialite.  But these flaws become completely irrelevant and in most cases wonderfully charming once the sheer majesty of the game takes hold of you.For my money, Oblivion stands out as the jewel in Bethesda's crown, completely outshining everything else they have done.  Aside from the combat, every single aspect of this game eclipses it's younger sibling Skyrim completely.  The main quest is far more interesting, the side quests are far more interesting and often amusing, something which was sadly missing from Skyrim.  The faction quests, Fighters Guild, Thieves Guild, Mages Guild and especially the Dark Brotherhood are just superb and are main quest lines in their own right.  You're pretty much getting five main story lines for the price of one.If you have never played Oblivion but you enjoy the Bethesda style of the FPRPG then you simply must buy it, right now, seriously.  Do not allow yourself to miss out on what will probably go down in history as the best game Bethesda ever made.  I cannot recommend this game enough and I'm very picky about which games I invest my precious free time into.TL;DR.  Masterpiece, simple as that.

												Another great Elder Scrolls installment. I personally prefer to play Morrowind or Skryrim, but Oblivion holds plenty of inherent value. This value comes from a unique story and well established quests. Interesting characters and rewarding exploits add to the experience and make it exceptional.I prefer Elder Scrolls III and V because Morrowind has great charm in its very unique characters and its very rewarding exploration and Skyrim has great mechanics and an unforgettable landscape with virtually unlimited play value. Oblivion sits somewhere in the middle and is relatively strong when discussing RPGs but lacks in comparison to its predecessor and its sequel in strong features.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												In the spirit of brevity: I completely recommend this game to anyone with a computer capable of running it. Even if you never fight a single enemy or finish a quest, this game is beautiful and you could spend hours just exploring , talking to NPCs, running with the wildlife, mixing potions, or just cloudwatching.However, I suggest that you do attempt every quest and engage a large number of enemies. The fighting and enemy AI mechanics for the game, while sometimes  quirky, make combat , exploring, and even buying and selling items an utter delight. There is a difficulty selection scale that can be changed anytime, and console commands, enabled through the use of the tilde key (~), allow one to activate invincibility, set any attribute to the desired value, and even instantly kill any/all enemies in the area, thus ensuring that players of any and all skills levels can complete the game 100% with ease, or set overwhelming odds for themselves to triumph over, all at a whim and quick set of keystrokes.The game is fully voice acted, so there is considerable emersion, and dialouge can be enhanced through the use of mods (found on Oblivion Nexus mods site). Actually, there is a mod for just about everything the game offers, and, if you care to put in the time to get the mods running, or write your own, the game can be made into a practical sandbox.(Even adult mods are available, if that is what you desire.)The music is gorgeous, as are the scenic graphics.Battle music is invigorating and explortion music is inspire. Easy listening and living tunes fill the towns, and more sombre melodies fill the plains of Oblivion.In conclusion, I can't recommend this game enough; every gategory is either extremely well crafted, or readily improved through the addition of mods, and an avid gamer could easily clock hundreds of hours on this game, with mods or without.It is worth every penny, even when not on sale, but,  I believe it is actually on sale for $5 or less at the time of this posting, so, if you're on the ropes about this game, give a try now, and if you're one out of millions who finds it to not be worth it, you won't be out any more than  burger and coke at McDonalds would cost you.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												TESIV: Oblivion is a great game. Many TES fans refer to is as a classic, and I can see why.Quests in this game are absolutley wonderful. The quests are very interesting, and you can get different outcomes depending on how you play, which makes the game very replayable. There is a lot of different ways to play this game, and you get to choose how you want to play.The world is huge, and loading screens don't appear when you roam freely. The only time you will get a loading screen is if you enter a dwellin, so you can wonder all around Cyrodil without objections. The game world is enourmous, and with modifications, you can extend it even more. I doubt I will ever filly explore the map in Oblivion.There is an enormous modding community. Even though there is not a Steam Workshop for Oblivion, installing mods is quick and somple. Modifications are still being developed, even while everyone else is playing Skyrim. Mods range from silly and funny to serious lore to really useful changes. The websites planetelderscrolls.ign.com and nexusmods.com/oblivion are very good resources that I use often.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												This game is one of my personal favorites. It has great story combined with a massive world that you can freely explore and sidequests to keep you entertained long after you completed the main story.The combat is hard to the point that you WILL get scared of only seeing one goblin since it can and probably will kill if you are unprepared, but that makes it more fun and rewarding each time you win.There are many classes to choose from and combined with the different specialty of each race gives the game alot of replayability. Oblivion has no perk point system like in Skyrim wich may sound bad but this gives you a greater freedom of the equipment and magic that you wish to use, because there are more different kinds of magic that all are fun to use.But be prepared that it is a hard game and can sometimes be a chore to play because of it. The world of Oblivion is filled with many fearsome beast´s wich makes it sometimes necessary for farming enemies. Overall, it is a masterpiece that had thaught put into it and it it worth all the money.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I have played this game about 3 times now across PC and Xbox 360, and I put about 150 hours into each and every play.This was the first Elder Scrolls game for me and I can say with certainty it is probably my favorite. My Pros and cons are not comparing to other elder scrolls games, rather than just the game in itself.Where do I start?    +PROS+amazing weapons system+immersive open world +great soundtrack+fun storyline+plenty races + customization+memorable intro+crazy fun dark brotherhood+guilds! +ability to go to basically hell and fight it's inhabitants+skill system that I even prefer over skyrim!+one of the best DLC ever to be made!+countless hours of gameplay+runs on almost every pc there is+still looks great if you turn up the settings+mods (game is still amazing without em)+ability to create your own spells+WELCOME TO THE ARENA+gaurds able to find you anywhere.... and I mean ANYWHERE. (stomache painfully funny)+medievil theme that works very well+side-quests that are actually interesting+omg too many pros I dont want this review too long    -CONS-having to sleep in a bed to level up (can get annoying at times)-certain caves or dungeons not looking very unique from eachother (like the past 2 you were just in)-quest menus can be kindof confusing or not well-organized to some people (I personally don't mind)-character faces looking potatoey (I really do not think this is a problem at all, but is complained about all the time when the topic of Oblivion comes up)Overall I'd give this game a 9/10 One of my favorite games of all time for a reason. Now buy this game and CLOSE SHUT THE JAWS OF OBLIVION!!!!!!!!!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												I've been hooked on this game since I was like 9, and I consistently have difficulties pressing the "exit" button and going back to my real life. Thankfully, the game crashes every few hours for no reason, so I've never had to worry too much about it.Still, I just gotta say, the Dark Brotherhood questline in Oblivion is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing compared to Skyrim's♥♥♥♥♥♥"kill these random dudes anyway you want" spiel. The quests, in general, try not to take themselves too seriously and I'm glad they don't lay it heavy on the Grit. As long as you're not too miffed about the really ♥♥♥♥ing ugly faces (see: Hackdirt Brethren) or some of the glitches, it's a pretty fun game and has high nostalgic value. OH, also, Shivering Isles is pretty interesting visually and story-wise, but some parts of it made me rather uncomfortable (ah... the ableism... like if you have any mental illnesses like me, you'll definitely go "Yikes!" a few times). Buy this when it's on sale because it's not worth its posted $20 for how old it is. Also, practice Safe Saving.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												It hits that sweet spot.You know, that one right between morrowind and skyrim. Morrowind was great, but had just too many unnecessary hoops to jump through. Skyrim was also a platinum quality game, but it's instant gratification based gameplay left out that special something from the deeper aspects of traditional RPGs. Oblivion has fairly well aged graphics (even better with mod support), relatively lively combat, a lot of deeper RPG elements compacted and presented by a user friendly UI, and all that delicious Bethesda game freedom. Other RPGs might beat it in combat fluidity or graphic style, but this is as close as you'll get to ole pen-and-paper fun without sacrificing any ease of use. Doesn't have spears though.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												After Morrowind, this game was a big step forward. Much-improved graphics and gameplay (plus, no cliff-gliders!).  In Morrowind,  I don't think had a truly central story-line. Oblivion changes all of that, giving a core story, many side-quests and the early stages of playing a monk character, which was even better in Skyrim thanks to a mod.Too bad the idea of The Workshop mods hadn't surfaced yet. Thank god for The Elder Scrolls Wiki, which finally gave you a bit of a leg up when you needed it. Good voice acting throughout, with Patrick Stewart and Sean Bean included, just to mention two.  My younger son refused to play the game for awhile, believing Morrowind was "pure" Elder Scroll game. After he got, he never looked backed.I've recently started a new game as I was having issues with Skyrim: Legendary Edition (some of my old Skyrim files still in the library caused it, I think) and i plan on playing this Bethesda game until I can get its sequel program up and running again.One nice thing: nowhere near as buggy as Elder Scrolls 3, with few crashes and I think its playability has stood the test of time. Having the game of the year helps, too.I give a 8 out of ten septims!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												Let me preface this by saying I LOVE Elderscrolls games. Love them. Strapped a bedpan to my bum and played this game and Skyrim for months. First thing I do in every game is to get a feel for max difficulty. This game on max difficulty is legit hard. However, the only way to play on max difficulty is to create what I call "The Pokemon Master" build. Physical damage you do is soooooo reduced. Literally <1 damage. So the only way to play is to conjure pokemon to fight for you. Their damage is not reduced. So you let the pokemon fight until it despawns, then throw out another one. Lather, rinse, repeat. It prevents a lot of fun and creativity in a class. Sometimes you can poison your weapons and take them down with bug bites. It is boring.However! This game is GLORIOUS! Graphics may suck, but you will not care. The story lines are what grip you. The combat on everything but max difficulty is fun. The world does feel alive in this game. There is enough to entertain you for hundreds of hours, and that is just on one character. This was the first game in the series that I played back on that old crap box 360. There is a redesign mod that does improve graphics and models by a ton. It's on Nexus Mods. Definitely check that out. All in all, a great game worthy of every penny. It's like dirt cheap now so there is no reason not the pick this one up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												This and Age of Empires 2 were my two first and greatest loves. IMHO the game still holds up to this day, although I might be under the influence of nostalgia. The graphics are still good-looking, and at times even quite beautiful. Both expansions are worthwhile, with Shivering Isles being the greater of the two. There are a lot of interesting sidequests, dungeons, easter eggs. The guilds are fun, especially the Assassin one. The downsides may be centered around the main story, as well as dungeon conception. A lot of dungeons just look alike, and the Oblivion Gates quickly become tiresome to deal with. As for the story, it's not bad, but it's not very memorable either. I never really got attached to the main character, in fact I found some of the guild plotlines more compelling. However this might all come down to personnal preference.Still a great game to explore and enjoy, and I hope you do .

												So, I have had this game for a long time. I have started it over again and again trying to get into it, but I never could. The other day I decided to give it another go and avoid the entire main quest line and it has been a lot easier to enjoy.The main questline, though I have never finished it, is really repetative. Eventually all it has you do is attack slightly different gates at different places around the world, and it gets old fast.Some may really enjoy the main quests, it is worth at least one try.Even if you are like me and decide to skip the main quest, there is still a ton of quests and adventures to be had.Overall this game shows a lot of detail that most games lack.Anyway, I'd say give it a shot.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Do not let my lack of Steam hours fool you. I played TES 4 on the PS3 from 2008 until the present day, easily putting 50-100 hours on it. After 2009, I got a gaming PC and played the Non-Steam version for another 30+ hours. I've beaten the game a few times and done many things, but barely scraped the surface of the vast amount of content in this amazing game.I remember the first time I stepped out of the sewers at age 14 and saw just how powerful the next generation was compared to the PS2, Xbox, Gamecube era. The fact that I could go anywhere and do anything blew my mind. I remember walking into a shop for the first time and saying to myself "Wow all of this stuff is too expensive for me." So I picked it up and got the guards called on me for stealing. I remember fighting the guards with my weak iron sword that I found on the ground and being astounded that they actually chased me through hell and back. It was amazing to me that killing someone was so permanent. In other games, people respawned or were simply unkillable. I thought that teleporting away and coming back would respawn them, but I remember I realized that I had messed up when I killed certain people.The PC version opened my eyes even more when I saw the true power of the modding community and all the creative items they came out with. QUests, NPCs, Companions, Mounts, Weapons, Armors, ENTIRE land masses. THe possibilities are endless. And Bethesda actually listened to the community, incorporating certain mods into actual game features in the following game: Skyrim.Sure with Skyrim, there's more to do. The games get progressively better with each new release. But most people base their favorites off nostalgia. For most people my age, Morrowind was the first experience. For some even older, Arena and Daggerfall was the first adventure. For me, my adventure began with Oblivion. The countless hours I spent destroying gates, slaying ghosts, trolls wolves, becoming a vampire, buying houses, stealing EVERYTHING, and doing countless quests - each diverse in their own way- will forever be a part of me. Graphic and mechanic-wise, Skyrim is , of course, superior. But if you love this series and have yet to check it out. Most definitely give it a try. For the price it's at now, it's definitely worth it. 10/10
